headline: My Neighborhood Was on Fire. My Neighbors Came Together to Save It.
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: I spent five days last year fighting the California wildfires in Malibu. It felt like the combat patrols I had been on as a Marine in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: In boot camp, I was surprised by the pride the other recruits took in their no-name Midwest hometowns. By contrast, I had no love for Malibu, Calif., which seemed like only one thing to me: an isolated beach town too far from the city for me to escape. I did not surf. I had no luck with girls. Years before I was old enough to enlist, the Sept. 11 attacks gave me a sure direction away from a dysfunctional home: I was determined to join the Marine Corps. So I spent my youth running Malibu’s hills, swimming its coast, avoiding a home that smelled of stale white wine and counting the days until I could enlist in the military. But my antipathy toward Malibu did nothing to stem a stream of brotherly abuse from the other recruits for what they perceived as my star-studded hometown. Their idea of Malibu was very different from what my reality had been.

headline: When It’s Right, It’s Right
abstract: Neither Stefanie Joshua nor Jaime Cordova had ever felt an urgency to be married, until they matched and met.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years ago, Stefanie Joshua could easily have become a bride.

abstract: Interested in free and private accommodations while traveling? Here’s how to get started with house-sitting in the United States and overseas.
lead_paragraph: Free accommodations while vacationing clearly makes travel more affordable. But for travelers on any budget, house-sitting in exchange for lodging can provide a more intimate travel experience, plus an opportunity to experience life as a local.

headline: Humans Shipped an Awful Cargo Across the Seas: Cancer
abstract: A cancer afflicting mussels originated off the Pacific coast of Canada, but then crossed into other species in Europe and South America.

headline: The Right Kind of Exercise May Boost Memory and Lower Dementia Risk
abstract: Being physically fit may sharpen the memory and lower our risk of dementia, even if we do not start exercising until we are older.
lead_paragraph: Being physically fit may sharpen the memory and lower our risk of dementia, even if we do not start exercising until we are middle-aged or older, according to two stirring new studies of the interplay between exercise, aging, aerobic fitness and forgetting. But both studies, while underscoring the importance of activity for brain health, also suggest that some types of exercise may be better than others at safeguarding and even enhancing our memory.

headline: The Restrained Genius of a Joe Pesci Performance
abstract: Hollywood never really knew what to do with the actor and so it put him in broad comedies. But “The Irishman” shows what we’ve been missing for so long.
lead_paragraph: Tommy DeVito is entertaining fellow gangsters with stories of his exploits when one of his listeners, Henry Hill, tells him he’s funny. The laughter at the loudest table in the restaurant abruptly dies.

headline: His Victim Forgave Him Years Ago. Now the State Has, Too.

abstract: “The only thing that will stop me now is myself,” Eric Pizer said after getting a pardon from the governor of Wisconsin.

headline: The Exhaustion Is Real

I fell asleep at 9:30 p.m. local time and didn’t set an alarm, because I figured there was no way I would sleep past 7:30 a.m. Cue me waking with a jolt at 9:30 a.m., and only because housekeeping knocked on the door. I probably could have gone a solid 14 if left uninterrupted.

headline: How This 71-Year-Old Video Art Pioneer Became a TikTok Star
abstract: Cecelia Condit’s unsettling 1983 work “Possibly in Michigan” has found a home among Generation Z.
lead_paragraph: ONE RECENT WEEKDAY, I was sitting with the video artist and retired professor Cecelia Condit in the dining room of her fairly nondescript apartment in the upper-middle-class Milwaukee suburb of Shorewood, Wis. The space also doubles as Condit’s studio, but other than a laptop and a few hard drives, scant evidence of a working artist could be found. Over grapes and pudding, we watched my iPhone, which was spitting out audio from “Possibly in Michigan,” Condit’s brutal, surreal and darkly funny 1983 art musical that is in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art. Shot using then nascent video technology and set to an eerily chipper Casio-fueled soundtrack provided by Karen Skladany, who also acted in the film, the 12-minute “Possibly in Michigan” follows a masked cannibal named Arthur — played by, at different points, Condit and the actors Bill Blume and Stephen Vogel — as he stalks Jill Sands (playing a character named Sharon) and Skladany (as Sharon’s friend Janice) through a nondescript Middle American shopping mall. (Despite its name, the video was filmed in Cleveland, where Condit was living at the time.) The cannibal follows the women home, at which point he’s murdered and then eaten himself. The film ends with the body being disposed in a couple of trash bags and picked up by a local garbage collector.

Houston is a little more than 50 miles northwest.

headline: It’s Time to Take Down the Mona Lisa
abstract: Leonardo’s painting is a security hazard, an educational obstacle and not even a satisfying bucket-list item. It’s time the Louvre moved it out of the way.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Even in a city saturated with excellent fall exhibitions, from the Grand Palais’s retrospective of El Greco to the Fondation Louis Vuitton’s showcase of Charlotte Perriand, the show of the season here is the decade-in-the-works “Leonardo da Vinci,” at the Musée du Louvre. Mandatory timed tickets are sold out through November for this thorough, deeply serious exhibition, which sloughs off the myths that cling to this least productive of Renaissance masters. You will find here a cleaner, sprightlier Leonardo — or at least you will in the show downstairs, where four of the Louvre’s five paintings by the artist have been relocated.

headline: What to Know Before Buying Shares in Saudi Arabia’s Oil Company
abstract: The Saudi monarchy is pursuing its own interests, not those of the company, and that is where problems will arise for investors.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s Capital Market Authority on Sunday announced that the kingdom had approved plans for turning Saudi Aramco, its hugely profitable national oil company, into a publicly traded corporation. An initial public offering of 1 percent to 3 percent of Aramco’s shares is expected in December, but may come later.

headline: How Einstein Became the First Science Superstar
abstract: A century ago, astronomers proved the general theory of relativity — and made him a global household name.
lead_paragraph: Early in 1919, two teams of British astronomers embarked on a journey to the far reaches of the planet to observe a solar eclipse. Nearly eight months later, on Nov. 6, 1919, the teams presented their findings before a packed audience of scientists in London. Their announcement changed forever how humans view the universe.

headline: Early Problems as Trump’s Signature Veterans’ Health Plan Rolls Out
abstract: Officials administering the plan said they were unable to guarantee a network large enough to accommodate all the veterans who may seek care.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A health program for veterans that President Trump heralds as a triumphant success is struggling to make its network of doctors as large as required to meet an aggressive expansion of care outside the Department of Veterans Affairs health facilities, officials said. The company managing the new program in a majority of the states said it would probably need millions of dollars more to meet the plan’s coverage goals.

headline: What Trump Didn’t Say About the Massacre in Mexico
abstract: If the president wants to fight the cartels behind killings like Monday’s attack on a Mormon family, he can start with gun control.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The seven-month-old baby Faith Marie Johnson survived hours without food and water in a bullet-ridden SUV in northern Mexico until her family members arrived. She had miraculously escaped the bullets flying around her. Her mother was among the three women and six children killed on Monday when gunmen ambushed their cars after they left a nearby Mormon community. Five other children survived being shot in the back, jaw, leg, wrist and chest. Those killed were all American citizens. The attack has sparked outrage from Mexico to Utah to the White House and focused American attention once again on violence south of the border.

headline: A Mexican Restaurant in the Bronx Prepares for an Asylum Case

headline: The Thirty Meter Telescope Can Show Us the Universe. But at What Cost?
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Native Hawaiians', 'Navigation', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Indigenous People']
abstract: Locating a telescope on a sacred mountain is one more injustice against Native Hawaiian culture.
lead_paragraph: On the Big Island of Hawaii, Mauna Kea, a dormant volcano, rises nearly 14,000 feet above sea level. There are currently 13 telescopes on its slopes, on land managed by the University of Hawaii. Mauna Kea is ideal for astronomy: It is dry, has little turbulent air and a large fraction of clear viewing nights. But Native Hawaiians have long voiced concerns over the construction of telescopes on Mauna Kea. To them, the mountain is sacred.

headline: The Woman Who Flipped Off Trump Has Won an Election in Virginia

lead_paragraph: A catchall term for the work of self-taught artists isolated from the mainstream by poverty, mental disability or eccentricity, “outsider art” is more of a sociological phenomenon than a genre. But in “Memory Palaces: Inside the Collection of Audrey B. Heckler,” organized by Valérie Rousseau at the American Folk Art Museum, you do find a certain consistency.

lead_paragraph: For eight years, a digital media company called I’m Shmacked has posted viral videos of the college party scene. Beer bongs, booze, marijuana and scantily clad women are all featured prominently, in scenes set to upbeat party music. Cinematic shots of college campuses and university landmarks are interspersed with flip cup games and keg stands.

abstract: Understanding the art of the pan, with help from both a Times review and a student-written review.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

abstract: A Times look at one of many remixes of “Old Town Road,” and a student review of Greta Van Fleet’s debut album, demonstrate how cultural reviews can make a case.
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

lead_paragraph: Williamsburg, Brooklyn

abstract: One fancy watch isn’t enough for young Hollywood and watch geeks.
lead_paragraph: What fashion flourish is shared by Justin Bieber, Fidel Castro, Princess Diana and Drake?

headline: A Memorial for Jessye Norman at the Met Opera, Where She Reigned
abstract: The soprano, who died in September, will be remembered on Nov. 24 with performances, remarks and video highlights of her storied career.
lead_paragraph: When major figures in opera die, the Metropolitan Opera sometimes pays tribute to them with memorials at the opera house. Among those honored there over the years have been the composer Giacomo Puccini and the singers Enrico Caruso, Luciano Pavarotti and Beverly Sills.

headline: Addressing Audience: Two Book Reviews
abstract: Lessons in having a conversation with your readers, with help from a Times review of “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows” and a student review of “Counting Descent.”
lead_paragraph: Our new Mentor Text series spotlights writing from The Times that students can learn from and emulate.

headline: Surviving Droughts, Tornadoes and Racism
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Family Business', 'Families and Family Life', 'Discrimination', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: An African-American family has established a farming dynasty in Alabama. The trade war is just the latest challenge.
lead_paragraph: TANNER, Ala. — “There are easier ways to make a living than farming,” Greg Bridgeforth said as he drove a combine through fields he farms in northern Alabama. “But this is what I truly love to do — till the soil and grow things, just like my father, grandfather and great-grandfather did. You know, when problems get you down, you go out in the field and have time to think it through.”

headline: Unit 3: Analyzing Arts, Criticizing Culture: Writing Reviews With The New York Times
abstract: An invitation for students to write about food and fashion, movies and music, books and buildings for a global audience. Featuring writing prompts, mentor-text lesson plans and a culminating contest.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our third writing unit of the school year. Below you will find a detailed description of each element, as well as ways to put them together to make your own custom unit. To learn more, visit our writing curriculum overview.

headline: New WADA President Wants Sponsors to Help Finance Antidoping Efforts
abstract: Witold Banka’s idea to expand WADA’s reach into countries where testing is often nonexistent has run into immediate pushback.
lead_paragraph: KATOWICE, Poland — Witold Banka, the sports minister of Poland and president-elect of the World Anti-Doping Agency, is full of ideas. His biggest one, though, might be a tough sell.

headline: Change the Rules for Presidential Succession?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Impeachment', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: An Editorial Observer column argued that the speaker of the House should not be next in line after the vice president. Readers offer their opinions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Not Yet Ready for Retirement? Give Us One Week …
abstract: In our Seven Days to a Better Retirement challenge, we will get you on the path to a secure and successful post-work life.
lead_paragraph: Cooler weather has arrived, and many of us will soon be spending more time inside. It’s a good time to think about … retirement.

headline: Judge Voids Trump-Backed ‘Conscience Rule’ for Health Workers
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The administration’s policy would have protected doctors and others who refused to perform procedures on religious grounds.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday voided the Trump administration’s “conscience rule,” which would have made it easier for health care workers to avoid assisting with abortion or other medical procedures on religious or moral grounds.

headline: France Announces Tough New Measures on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: With municipal elections approaching, President Emmanuel Macron hopes the stricter stance will lure voters away from the far right.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France tried to seize control of the issue of immigration on Wednesday, as his government announced steps to make the country less attractive to migrants while cracking open the door to skilled foreign workers.

headline: Ayanna Pressley Endorses Elizabeth Warren for President
abstract: Ms. Pressley backed her home state senator, a longtime ally. “We find ourselves in a fight for the soul of our nation, and I know Elizabeth can win it,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ayanna S. Pressley of Massachusetts, the only member of the group of progressive first-term congresswomen nicknamed “the squad” who had not yet backed a Democratic presidential candidate, has endorsed Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, a longtime ally.

headline: Is This the Store for Grown-Up VSCO Girls?
abstract: Ganni, the Scandi label with a huge social presence, opens in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: According to the 2019 World Happiness Report, Denmark is the second happiest country in the world. I was the second happiest shopper inside the Ganni store in SoHo, the first stateside location for the Danish brand that has found a huge number of fans in the United States. (A second has just opened in Los Angeles.)

headline: Puerto Rico Senator Is Arrested in Corruption Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors said that when he was a mayor, Senator Abel Nazario and two aides illegally used tax money to pay five campaign workers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The federal authorities in Puerto Rico arrested Senator Abel Nazario Quiñones and seven other people on Wednesday, accusing them of theft or bribery during Mr. Nazario’s time as mayor of the town of Yauco. It was Mr. Nazario’s second corruption-related arrest in 14 months.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts, Houston Announces 7 Site-Specific Installations
abstract: The new pieces will be unveiled upon the completion of a $450 million redevelopment plan, which broke ground in 2012.
lead_paragraph: When the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston completes its $450 million multiyear redevelopment plan, projected for the fall of 2020, it will unveil the new Nancy and Rich Kinder Building for 20th- and 21st-century art, as well as seven new site-specific installations from a roster of international artists.

headline: The Lore of ‘The Godfather’ Resurfaces at Roger Stone’s Trial
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Movies', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Few films or books have entered the American lexicon as deeply as this mob chronicle, which is set to play a role at the Stone trial in Washington.
lead_paragraph: As Roger J. Stone Jr. goes on trial in Washington, accused of obstructing investigations into a possible conspiracy to influence the 2016 election, one piece of evidence has nothing to do with Russia, Hillary Clinton’s emails, WikiLeaks or the Trump administration.

headline: The Equal Rights Amendment May Pass Now. It’s Only Been 96 Years.
abstract: Virginia, soon to be under Democratic control, will likely be the 38th state to ratify the amendment. The Supreme Court could decide what happens next.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things that Virginia may pass now that Democrats have won control of the state legislature, none have been so long in the making as the Equal Rights Amendment.

headline: ‘Blue’s Clues’ Returns, and Silence Is Still the Star
abstract: But will today’s overstimulated preschooler find a springy dog and her human sidekick a little basic in a noisier digital age?
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Two decades ago, “Blue’s Clues” stormed children’s television with something colorless, low-tech and ordinary: silence.

headline: Luke Combs and Miranda Lambert, Both Bound by Country’s Gendered Rule Book
abstract: New albums by the country superstars show how Nashville prioritizes men at the expense of female creativity — or any creativity at all.
lead_paragraph: There’s a familiar kind of country song that functions essentially as a listicle. A laundry list of tropes about rural life. A slide show of small-town imagery. They’re a staple of the genre, an easy — too easy — go-to for performers hoping to trigger pleasure centers.

headline: Ambushed in Mexico, Mormon Children Tried to Save One Another
abstract: Children bore the brunt of a deadly shooting in Mexico. But some of them survived, and endured harrowing journeys to get help.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — About 10 hours after the massacre that claimed the lives of his grandchildren, Kenneth Miller drove his ATV through the northern Mexico wilderness in a frantic search for one last missing relative — a 9-year-old girl who had gone in search of help.

headline: California Sues Facebook for Documents in Privacy Investigation
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Attorneys General', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The state said Facebook had resisted or ignored dozens of requests for documents and internal correspondence about the company’s handling of personal data.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — California’s attorney general on Wednesday said he was investigating Facebook’s privacy practices and accused the company of failing to cooperate with his inquiry, in the social network’s latest fight over how it treats user information.

headline: Flint’s Children Suffer in Class After Years of Drinking the Lead-Poisoned Water
keywords: ['Special Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'Lead', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Water Pollution', 'Children and Childhood', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The city’s schools, stretched even before the lead crisis, are struggling with demands for individualized education programs and behavioral interventions for children with high lead exposure.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Nakiya Wakes could not understand how her wiry, toothy-grinned 6-year-old had gone from hyperactive one school year to what teachers described as hysterical the next. Then, in 2015, the state of Michigan delivered a diagnosis of sorts: Ms. Wakes’s neighborhood’s water — which her son, Jaylon, had been drinking and bathing in for more than a year — was saturated with lead, at some of the highest levels in the city.

headline: Mormon Massacre in Mexico May Be Tied to Gang War, Officials Say
keywords: ['Mormon Family Massacre (Mexico, 2019)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Drug Cartels']
abstract: Hours before six children and three women were killed, two rival gangs had a shootout near the U.S. border.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A conflict between two criminal groups fighting for control of a region in northern Mexico is a focus of the authorities in their investigation into the massacre of nine members of a Mormon family, officials said Wednesday.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Election Day Problem in the Suburbs Is Getting Worse
abstract: In Virginia, Pennsylvania and Kentucky, many voters in historically Republican suburbs supported Democratic candidates, in part because of antipathy toward President Trump.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — For the second Election Day in as many years, suburban voters demonstrated enormous political power in electing or aiding Democratic candidates in historically Republican areas, underscoring the drift of many moderate voters from the G.O.P. in the era of President Trump.

headline: Sandra Bullock and Ellen DeGeneres Sue Pop-Up Websites Over Misleading Ads
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Online Advertising', 'Consumer Protection', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Celebrities']
abstract: The stars filed a lawsuit on Wednesday as part of an effort to stop fake online endorsements, a growing problem for Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sandra Bullock and Ellen DeGeneres have spent the last two years in a behind-the-scenes battle with obscure internet companies that peddle beauty products with fabricated endorsements. As soon as one site is taken down, another pops up in its place.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Limits on Water Pollution Law
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Clean Water Act', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: The lively argument included discussions of whiskey punch and the novels of Agatha Christie.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered the reach of the Clean Water Act, debating how it applies to pollutants that reach the sea and other protected waters indirectly, through groundwater.

headline: The Kentucky Governor’s Race Was an Anomaly
abstract: The governor’s race was important, but national Democrats shouldn’t break out the bourbon.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — On Tuesday night, when it appeared Andy Beshear had opened an insurmountable but narrow lead over the incumbent Matt Bevin in the Kentucky governor’s race, my husband and I cracked open a bottle of bourbon and raised a glass in celebration. Pending the results of a likely recanvassing, it appears that our long, statewide nightmare may soon be over.

headline: False Hijacking Alarm Throws Amsterdam Airport Into Chaos
abstract: No, Air Europa Flight UX1094 was not hijacked, an apologetic airline said.
lead_paragraph: “False alarm,” the airline declared on Twitter — but by then it was too late.

abstract: Benefits were held for the New York Restoration Project and the New York Public Library.

headline: Bette Midler Vamped as Mae West
abstract: And cultural giants were lionized by the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to actors to nail a Hollywood-themed Halloween party.

headline: U Tun Lwin, Who Warned of Deadly Myanmar Cyclone, Dies at 71
abstract: “The people’s weatherman” said his forecasts had been played down by the government. At least 140,000 people perished in one of the most calamitous storms in recorded history.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — In the spring of 2008, U Tun Lwin, Myanmar’s top weather official, noticed that a tropical cyclone was barreling toward the country from the Indian Ocean.

headline: Read the Transcript of William Taylor’s Testimony
abstract: The top U.S. diplomat in Kiev described a quid pro quo pressure campaign on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The top U.S. diplomat in Kiev described a quid pro quo pressure campaign on Ukraine.

headline: Airbnb to Verify All Listings, C.E.O. Chesky Says
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: The company is planning more detailed checks of rentals on its site after five people were killed at a California Airbnb.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb plans to conduct a comprehensive review of every property listed on its platform as part of a series of initiatives to give customers “peace of mind,” Brian Chesky, the company’s chief executive, announced at the DealBook Conference in Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: Key Excerpts From William Taylor’s Testimony in the Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: House investigators released the interview transcript of a witness who provided one of the most damning accounts about the actions at the heart of the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committees leading the impeachment inquiry released a transcript on Wednesday from a closed-door deposition of a figure central to the investigation as the proceedings move to a more public phase. The first public hearings are scheduled for next week.

headline: ‘The Kingmaker’ Review: The Power and Vainglory of Imelda Marcos
abstract: Lauren Greenfield turns a cool, clinical eye on the seemingly unsinkable, unstoppable former first lady of the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: It was always a little too easy to laugh at Imelda Marcos. The gold and the kitsch, the fine art and the tchotchkes, the rows of bedazzled shoes and the towering dome of shellacked hair — it was all so very much, so very vulgar, so very, very expensive. During the roughly two decades that Marcos was the first lady of the Philippines, she became famous for lavish habits that make the Kardashians seem like skinflints. Even after the Marcos family fled the Philippines in 1986, her extravagance often received more attention than her role in what was called a “conjugal dictatorship.”

headline: Picture Books for the Wild at Heart
abstract: A shack in the forest. A good, long hike. A solstice celebration. Carson Ellis, Eliza Wheeler, Gary D. Schmidt and more remind us how to be at home in the wilderness.
lead_paragraph: This past summer bees were voted the most important living beings on earth. While I agree wholeheartedly, I also enjoy imagining this vote, conducted by scientists at the Royal Geographic Society of London, democratically including all living species. Imagine the mushrooms at the polls. Imagine the snakes and the sequoias casting their ballots.

headline: She Doubted Her Place in America. Now She’s Virginia’s First Muslim State Senator.
abstract: In helping to flip the General Assembly to Democrats, Ghazala Hashmi became part of a wave of Muslim women winning public office.
lead_paragraph: Ghazala Hashmi was on her way to work one winter morning in 2017 when she heard news on the radio that left her in a panic: President Trump’s order banning refugees from certain Muslim countries was making headlines, and she was concerned about the possibility of a Muslim registry being created in the United States.

headline: Trump’s Threat to Cut Aid to California as It Burns
abstract: A reader notes the president’s willingness to help battle wildfires in Siberia but not California. Also: Economic realities and climate; the traffic problem in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: With a Slave Rebellion Re-enactment, an Artist Revives Forgotten History
abstract: Dread Scott is organizing a re-enactment in Louisiana that asks people to think about who the real heroes were in the 19th-Century South.
lead_paragraph: LaPLACE, La. — The New York artist Dread Scott was standing in a tiny traffic island in this working-class suburb west of New Orleans on a recent afternoon near the EZ Stop convenience store. He had come to point out a single sentence on a historical marker, one unheeded by the truck drivers barreling down Airline Highway: “Major 1811 slave uprising organized here.”

headline: It’s the Year 2172: Time to Fight the Bloody Biafran War Again
abstract: Two sisters enter combat in Tochi Onyebuchi’s “War Girls,” a futuristic replay of the Nigerian conflict. Cue the flying robot warriors.
lead_paragraph: Onyii is all of 15, but she is battle-worn on every level. She sports a robotic arm — her human one was severed in conflict — and worries she’ll lose her sister, Ify, at any minute. As one of the oldest in a camp of rebel girls based in southeastern Nigeria in the year 2172, she’s an authority on wartime survival. Nigeria is in the grips of civil war, one very similar to the real Biafran War that ravaged the Igbo tribe in 1967-70 as they attempted to secede from Nigeria. In WAR GIRLS (Razorbill, 464 pp., $17.99; ages 12 and up) a series opener from Tochi Onyebuchi (“Beasts Made of Night”), the conflict drags on. Factor in climate change, nuclear disasters and space colonies, and the ultimate dystopian universe reveals itself — part tech-slick playground, part cautionary tale.

headline: ‘In Voguing, You’re the Author of Your Own Life’
abstract: Slim Xtravaganza and Pony Zion give a spontaneous performance for #SpeakingInDance.

headline: Tips to Ease Family Inheritance Tensions
abstract: Wealth coaches and financial advisers talk about how to avoid some uncomfortable situations.
lead_paragraph: Discussions with siblings about money-related issues can be fraught. Here are some tips from wealth coaches and financial advisers on how to tackle some of the potential obstacles.

headline: Stone Trial Links Trump More Closely to 2016 Effort to Obtain Stolen Emails
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Newly revealed calls between President Trump and Roger Stone dovetailed with key developments in the theft of Democratic emails, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was more personally involved in his campaign’s effort to obtain Democratic emails stolen by Russian operatives in 2016 than was previously known, phone records introduced in federal court on Wednesday suggested.

headline: How to Make Sure Your Assets Don’t Go Unclaimed
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Careful documentation and communication with loved ones are key.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a lifetime, many people accumulate assets that their loved ones might not know about, including banks accounts, retirement funds, insurance claims and Treasury bonds.

headline: Finding New Ways to Protect Right Whales With the Help of Fishermen
abstract: The decline of one of the world’s most endangered large whale species has pushed individual states and Canada to test new technologies, like ropeless fishing gear.
lead_paragraph: Marc Palombo has been fishing lobster for 41 years, and he wants fishermen who come after him to be able to do the same. That’s why he’s testing a new type of fishing gear that, along with other efforts in New England and Canada, is being designed to avoid harming North Atlantic right whales.

headline: There Are Billions in Unclaimed Assets Out There. Some Could Be Yours.
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Insurance', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Estimates vary, but government agencies have tens of billions of dollars’ worth of bank accounts, insurance policies and other forgotten holdings.
lead_paragraph: Before his mother died in 2018 at the age of 84, Thomas G. Plante used some of his time on frequent visits to her home in Rhode Island to help get her estate in order.

headline: One Thing You Can Do: Know Your Organic Food
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Elections', 'Environment']
abstract: Also this week, climate action and Tuesday’s elections
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox. (And find the website version of this week’s letter here.)

headline: At Bayern Munich, the Bill Comes Due
abstract: For a decade, the German champion operated as the most stable of the superclubs. But its mystique and financial might no longer overpower rivals the way they once did.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, representatives of one of the Bundesliga’s budding superstars met with a delegation from Bayern Munich. Their client is likely to move to a bigger club at the end of the current season, and Bayern, the German champion, is one of a half-dozen potential suitors. But first, his agents wanted to discover what plans the club’s hierarchy had for their player.

headline: Wait a Minute. How Can They Afford That When I Can’t?
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Income', 'Retirement', 'Credit and Debt', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Those expensive vacations and costly college educations may not be as hard-earned as you thought.
lead_paragraph: I’ve done it and you probably have, too: looked at a neighbor or friend who seemed to be in roughly the same financial bracket and wondered, “How do they do it?”

headline: When It Comes to Money, Silence Is Rarely Golden
abstract: No matter how difficult, honest financial conversations among family members are almost always the best choice. Here are some ways to do it.
lead_paragraph: Silence was breaking Charlotte Lamp’s family apart.

headline: Thinking About Giving Money to Adult Children? Think Again
abstract: While helping to support young adults might seem like the compassionate choice, it can often do more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas Gilbert Jr. received a 30-year sentence in September for killing his father over a money dispute, it ended a four-year-long case that sent a chilling warning to any parent who ever considered giving money to an adult child.

headline: Top Ukraine Diplomat Testified Giuliani Spearheaded Pressure for Investigations
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The top American diplomat in Ukraine, who is to be the first witness in public House impeachment hearings, told investigators it was Rudolph W. Giuliani who instigated the Ukraine pressure campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American diplomat in Ukraine identified Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, as the instigator behind the drive to get Ukraine’s president to announce investigations into Mr. Trump’s political rivals, telling impeachment investigators last month that Mr. Giuliani was acting on behalf of the president.

headline: How to (Gently) Help Your Aging Parents Manage Their Money
keywords: ['Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', 'Elderly', 'Families and Family Life', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Helping with their finances before a crisis erupts is a smart move, but a tricky one. Experts suggest some strategies that work.
lead_paragraph: When Reagan Alonso, a semiretired nurse living in Jacksonville, Fla., first gently offered to help her aging mother with her finances, she encountered resistance.

headline: Don’t Save Too Little, or Too Much
abstract: Finding the balance between financial security and enjoying life is tricky. Here are some suggestions for how to do it.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Maslowski has trouble sleeping, he cracks open a beer in his Wenonah, N.J., living room, watches old movies and does not worry about it.

headline: Dede Wilsey Asks the New Rich, ‘Why Don’t You Give Back?’
abstract: A member of one of the nation’s wealthiest families is a rare example of someone who speaks relatively openly about money.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the elegant sunroom of her Pacific Heights mansion with a view of the Golden Gate Bridge, the San Francisco socialite and philanthropist Dede Wilsey might seem an unlikely person to criticize the world of extraordinary wealth.

headline: If Keanu Reeves’s Date Can Embrace Looking Her Age, I Can Too
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Women and Girls', 'Age, Chronological', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Celebrities', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The actor’s rumored girlfriend Alexandra Grant is inspiring me to feel more comfortable with getting older.
lead_paragraph: The actor Keanu Reeves stepped out on the red carpet at an event on Saturday, holding hands with his longtime friend, the visual artist Alexandra Grant. When photos appeared online on Monday, the pair sparked rumors of romance and, predictably, Twitter users were ecstatic.

headline: Instead of a Generational Culture War, Let’s Fight the Rich
abstract: “Ok billionaire” is a better rallying cry than “ok boomer.”
lead_paragraph: Generations are pretty bogus. The labels we use to casually slice up society — boomer, millennial, Gen X, Gen Z — are a nearly useless way of thinking about politics, culture or business in America. The very idea that tens of millions of people across different classes and races and geographies might hold similar views on a range of subjects just because they happened to be born during the same 20-year span of American history — the whole thing sounds a bit too much like astrology, doesn’t it?

headline: The 100-Year Family: Here Are Some Tips for Becoming One
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Families and Family Life', 'Personal Finances', 'Family Business']
abstract: Research shows that one of the most important differences between those who maintain their wealth and those who don’t is communication.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Jaffe, a sociologist by training, has spent years trying to figure out the answer to a pressing question: what makes a hundred-year family?

headline: How to Talk About the Family Money
abstract: Fighting over the family assets is usually about far more than that. Money is often how we keep a tally of love, approval and fairness.
lead_paragraph: Sibling relationships can be a delicate dance, and when money gets tossed into the equation, they can get prickly.

headline: An Injury and a Red Card Put a Manchester City Defender in Goal
abstract: Manchester City held on for a draw with an unusual substitution, while Real Madrid, Juventus, Bayern Munich and P.S.G. advanced to the knockout rounds.
lead_paragraph: Manchester City’s starting goalkeeper left with an injury at halftime. His replacement departed after receiving a red card for a foul with 10 minutes left.

headline: Australia, Thailand, China: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Australia, Thailand, China.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Midway’ Review: Pacific Theater Action. Dinner Theater Accents.
abstract: An overstuffed war movie with characters who speak the language of exposition.
lead_paragraph: To say that “Midway,” a new cinematic re-creation of the decisive 1942 air and sea battle from Roland Emmerich, the director of “Independence Day,” soars to the heights of his best work is to say it sputters along at sea level. It is rousing and respectful in its best moments and faintly ridiculous in others.

headline: Narayana Reddy, YouTube Star as ‘Grandpa Kitchen,’ Has Died
abstract: Mr. Reddy, a cook in India, started a YouTube channel in 2017 featuring videos of him preparing huge portions of food for children. His channel has more than six million subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Narayana Reddy, an Indian cook whose YouTube channel, Grandpa Kitchen, garnered more than six million followers with videos of him preparing gargantuan amounts of food to feed orphaned children and other hungry people, died on Oct. 27 in India.

headline: Animal Cruelty Moves One Step Closer to Being a Federal Crime
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate unanimously passed a bill Tuesday that, if signed into law, would make the torture of animals a federal felony punishable by fines and up to seven years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A bill was unanimously passed in the Senate on Tuesday that, if signed into law, would make animal cruelty a federal felony punishable with fines and up to seven years in prison.

headline: Marciano Art Foundation Lays Off Employees Trying to Unionize
abstract: The museum said it was anticipating discussions. Then it laid off visitors services associates and said it was closed to the public.
lead_paragraph: Last week, after employees at the Marciano Art Foundation announced that they were taking steps to form a union, the museum issued a statement saying it looked forward to “engaging with them to learn more about their requests.”

headline: Tucson Rejects Sanctuary Status as Places Across U.S. Vote on Their Futures
keywords: ['Arizona Immigration Law (SB 1070)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gambling', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Referendums', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Taxation', 'Discrimination', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The city has historically supported immigrants’ rights, but voters thought Proposition 205 went too far. Here’s an overview of that and other notable referendum results across the United States.
lead_paragraph: In Arizona, a red state known for its strict immigration policies, Tucson has earned a reputation as a spot of blue.

headline: ‘Doctor Sleep’ Review: A Duller ‘Shining’
abstract: In this Stephen King adaptation, Ewan McGregor fights old and new demons.
lead_paragraph: “Doctor Sleep,” Mike Flanagan’s adaptation of the novel by Stephen King, catches up with Danny Torrance, who as a child was terrorized by demons and his own father at a spooky Rocky Mountain hotel.

headline: Marie Laforêt, French Actress and Singer, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Known as “the girl with the golden eyes,” she was seen in dozens of feature films and on television and sold more than 35 million records.

headline: ‘Last Christmas’ Review: Ho, Ho, Humbug
abstract: Emilia Clarke and Henry Golding star in a flatline of a romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Boy Meets Girl, So What?” That’s the title of a movie that Bertolt Brecht thought up when he was exiled in Hollywood in the 1940s. It’s also an evergreen question, one that I crankily mutter whenever I watch another romantic comedy that tries to reanimate a subgenre that’s fallen on hard times, largely because the old orthodoxies about human beings and love — and what constitutes happily ever after — no longer apply. It was apparently so much easier for filmmakers when female happiness meant men, marriage and babymaking.

headline: Eastern Europe’s Populist Scam
abstract: Demagogues like Hungary’s Viktor Orban denounce the European Union but corruptly exploit its farm subsidies.
lead_paragraph: What is galling is how openly Prime Minister Viktor Orban does it, blaming the European Union for every imagined indignity or interference in Hungary’s affairs, while milking billions from Brussels to enrich his cronies and prop up his illiberal rule. He is not alone, as a Times investigation of the bloc’s lavish farm subsidies demonstrates in shocking detail — the governments of several formerly Communist Eastern European states have also cynically taken advantage of the union’s largess through opaque deals, feeding a new class of land barons.

headline: Review: In ‘Reparations,’ Righting Wrongs Comes With a Cost
abstract: James Sheldon’s play examines what happens when trauma is used to material ends.

Two strangers meet at a book party; they end up at her Upper East Side condo, where they chitchat with flirtatious casualness before retiring to the bedroom; in the morning, she makes them breakfast. Reg is young and black, with the relaxed assurance of a guy about to score. Ginny is white and older, and ready to start dating again seven months after her husband’s death — Reg barely flinches upon learning she’s a grandmother.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘The King’ and ‘Farming’
abstract: Timothée Chalamet and Joel Edgerton star in “The King” on Netflix. And the recent drama “Farming” is available to rent.
lead_paragraph: THE KING (2019) Stream on Netflix. Falstaff looks as if he has cut down on the sack and sugar in this loose adaptation of Shakespeare’s Henry plays. Falstaff, the usually rotund companion to Prince Hal (the future King Henry V), is played here by a relatively lean Joel Edgerton, opposite Timothée Chalamet as a stylish Hal-Henry. The film focuses on Hal’s evolution from sot to sovereign, ditching Shakespeare’s language in favor of a modern English script by Edgerton and David Michôd, who also directs. The story builds up to a climactic Battle of Agincourt, with help from a supporting cast that includes Ben Mendelsohn, who plays an ailing King Henry IV, and Robert Pattinson. “Michôd has a gift for screen violence and is generally good with actors,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times, “yet time and again your attention drifts from Hal-Henry to the story’s edges, where the supporting actors nibble at their tasty bits.”

headline: The Loneliness of Frontotemporal Dementia
abstract: Since areas that dictate personality rather than memory are the first to suffer, people with the disease usually land on a therapist’s couch long before finding their way to a neurologist.
lead_paragraph: At 66, Bob Karger was losing language. It was not the tip-of-the-tongue feeling that melts when you recall a sought-after word. He had lost the connection between sounds and meaning — the way ba-na-na recalls a soft, yellow fruit or ea-gle calls to mind a large bird of prey. In a recent conversation, he had thought acorns grew on pine trees.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Proper Way to Wear a Wedding Band
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: Do you have to wear it facing the same direction as your other ring, which indicates you’re a member of the secret society that controls the world?
lead_paragraph: Aaron writes: My wife and I have an ongoing argument about my wedding band. My ring has a mountain motif running around it. I think the mountains should point toward my body. She insists they should point away from it. I also wear a Masonic ring, and she doesn’t care which way it faces.

headline: How to Set Up a Shell Company
abstract: Do it in Nevada or Delaware or Wyoming. Pick a bland, forgettable name for the company.
lead_paragraph: “If you’re looking for secrecy, the United States is a far better bet than the classic tropical-island tax haven,” says Jason Sharman, a professor of politics and international relations at the University of Cambridge. To study the effectiveness of international rules against anonymous, untraceable shell companies, Sharman and two other researchers impersonated 21 different fictitious consultants and sent 7,400 emails to 3,700 so-called corporate service providers (often law or accounting firms) in 182 countries, asking for help setting one up. Nearly half the respondents failed to comply with regulations requiring the collection of identity documents. The conclusion: It is more than three times as hard to put an untraceable shell company in an offshore tax haven than in a developed country. For anonymity, set up your company in Nevada, Delaware or Wyoming; it can be done in 10 to 40 minutes, and for as little as $200.

headline: A Couple Look to Upgrade Their Brooklyn Rental. Which One of These Would You Choose?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Tired of their sunless one-bedroom and its tiny kitchen, Mallory Harwardt and Max King stretched their budget to see if they could afford a place they liked better. Here’s where they landed.
lead_paragraph: Tired of their sunless one-bedroom and its tiny kitchen, Mallory Harwardt and Max King stretched their budget to see if they could afford a place they liked better. Here’s where they landed.

headline: Can a Woman Who Is an Artist Ever Just Be an Artist?
keywords: ['Art', 'Women and Girls', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The lives of two painters, Celia Paul and Cecily Brown, tell very different stories about what it takes to thrive in a medium historically dominated by men.
lead_paragraph: In a recent feature film about the sculptor Alberto Giacometti, we find the great man in his Paris studio, brooding over the difficulty of giving birth to his own genius. Fuming and raging, lashing out at his familiars, he is a chain-smoking wild beast being kept in cultural captivity. His growing fame brings admirers to his freezing workshop, where they wonder at his ascetic indifference to discomfort, and still more — gifted as he surely is — at his capacity for self-criticism. Not that his manhood can be in any doubt: He flaunts his ravishing young mistress before his careworn, miserable wife, who nonetheless remains his devoted slave in the fervent belief that she is the one who truly understands him. In one scene, in a fit of furious dissatisfaction, he hurls a sheaf of sketches into a flaming brazier before a group of astonished onlookers. The camera shows the horror on their faces as they watch the artworks burn, a horror it is assumed we share. It isn’t just the sight of Giacometti’s sketches going up in smoke that appalls us; it’s the fact that, to our retrospective eyes, he might as well be burning thousand-dollar bills.

headline: They Achieved the American Dream. Will the Supreme Court Let Them Keep It?
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Deportation']
abstract: Next week, the court will debate the program that allowed Jorge and Evelyn, and 700,000 other immigrants known as Dreamers, to build lives in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Next week, the court will debate the program that allowed Jorge and Evelyn, and 700,000 other immigrants known as Dreamers, to build lives in the United States.

headline: Cult of the Literary Sad Woman
abstract: From Jean Rhys to Joan Didion, fiction is awash in female suffering. Leslie Jamison considers affliction’s allure — and its more promising alternatives.
lead_paragraph: The first time I read Jean Rhys’s “Good Morning, Midnight,” I was 22 and deeply committed to a life of volcanic feeling: doomed love affairs, binge drinking and other tentatively self-destructive hobbies. I needed blueprints for my epic sadness, and no one captured epic sadness as well as Jean Rhys, especially — and unapologetically — in her 1939 novel, “Good Morning, Midnight.” The novel’s antiheroine, Sasha, tries to drink herself to death in a cheap Paris hotel room — haunted by her lost youth, her botched romances and the ghost of her infant son, who died at 5 weeks old. As soon as I read the first scene, in which a stranger chides Sasha for crying at a bar (“Sometimes I’m just as unhappy as you are. But that’s not to say that I let everybody see it”), I knew which team I was on: Team Sasha, Team Rhys, Team Drunk-Crying-in-Public.

abstract: “They are, by nature, storytellers. … Writing is magic, so to have people who can do the tricks talk about it makes for good conversation.”

abstract: “Akhnaten” is coming to the Metropolitan Opera for the first time. Here’s what it takes to hold an audience’s attention for three hours.
lead_paragraph: Everything about Philip Glass’s music seems to exist in extremes. As a listener, you either love it or you don’t. As a performer, you’re either flawless or a failure. Concerts can be transporting, near-religious experiences — or just an endless slog.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Flush With Cash. Here’s How He Plans to Spend It.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Television', 'Campaign Finance', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: As he steps up his efforts in Iowa, Mr. Sanders is using a traditional media platform to try to bring new voters into the political system to support him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bernie Sanders’s campaign plans to spend more than $30 million on TV advertising alone in the first four presidential nominating states and California, according to several people familiar with the strategy, a financial show of force that also suggests he needs to reach outside the traditional sphere of Democratic primary voters and caucusgoers for support.

headline: 36 Hours in Barolo, Italy
abstract: Sleepy villages, hillsides blanketed in grape vines, pasta dusted with shaved truffles, and wine that tastes of violets: just a few reasons to visit this gastronomic paradise in the Piedmont region.
lead_paragraph: As far as Italian wine regions go, it’s hard to beat Barolo. Crowds are thinner than in Chianti, the food better than in Friuli, the landscape lusher than in Umbria or Sicily. In the heart of Italy’s northwestern Piedmont region — a gastronomic paradise famous for its rich pastas and white truffles that are in season right now — this noble wine region encompasses the town of Barolo and 10 nearby municipalities. In addition to producing the most venerated of Italian wines — the robust, age-worthy Barolo — the region is also a delight to visit, especially in autumn after a trip to the annual truffle festival in the nearby city of Alba. Along winding roads that climb steep hillsides blanketed with neat rows of nebbiolo vines, there’s always an ancient castle up ahead, or a world-famous wine estate, or a storybook hamlet with swoon-worthy views. Just bring an appetite.

headline: Poem ‘Ghazal: Back Home’
abstract: This ghazal, a traditional Middle Eastern/Persian/Indian poem, creates a spell that builds in power and circles around mystery.
lead_paragraph: Bahr is Arabic for “sea” but means “meter” when applied to poetry. Zeina Hashem Beck weaves poems of deep longing that feel like whole worlds. This ghazal, a traditional Middle Eastern/Persian/Indian poem, creates a spell that builds in power and circles around mystery — “back home” being so hard to get to, for countless people on earth yearning for ways of passage, safety, arrival. Habibi means “darling.” Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: Claire Foy and Matt Smith Meet Again, Onstage
abstract: The stars of “The Crown” are back together in a production in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As proof that you can’t keep a good couple down, along comes “Lungs” at the Old Vic Theater to put center stage a screen pairing whose wattage shines even more brightly when experienced live. Claire Foy and Matt Smith came to attention together as the young royals of the blockbuster TV series “The Crown.” Their current stage assignment, smartly directed by Matthew Warchus and on view through Nov. 9, finds them in distinctly unregal street clothes, in a 90-minute two-hander from Duncan Macmillan that was first seen in 2011. Their characters, far from being known the world over, aren’t even named.

headline: The Supreme Court Confronts DACA
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Census', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Will the justices allow the Trump administration to toss out the Dreamers?
lead_paragraph: In the four months since the Supreme Court rejected the Trump administration’s cynical effort to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census, the decision — which the president came dangerously close to defying — has faded from view under the weight of all that has happened since. The census will proceed next spring in the usual way, without sorting the country’s population into citizen and noncitizen. That’s that, it would seem.

headline: Burrito Delivered by Bot, as Long as Students Don’t Trap It

lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Come lunchtime on the campus of the University of California, Berkeley, thousands of students rush out for a bite to eat and head back to class. But for more than a year, a few hundred have stayed put and instead summoned a knee-high robot bearing a burrito, a burger or other meals from a nearby restaurant.

headline: Airbnb’s New Rules and a Look at the Streaming Wars

lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. We held our annual DealBook “Playing for the Long Term” conference yesterday, featuring some of the biggest newsmakers in business and policy. Thanks to everyone who attended. Here’s what stood out to NYT reporters at the event, along with our regular Speed Read news roundup. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Crown Vic’ Review: A Cop Thriller Abounding in Cliché
abstract: The film, about a jaded veteran officer and his rookie partner, plays like an amalgam of the tropes of numerous TV and movie police procedurals.
lead_paragraph: “Crown Vic” begins in the midst of a kinetic shootout, the camera zipping back and forth as a pair of masked robbers careen away from the L.A.P.D. in a car. But the writer-director Joel Souza soon dissipates the adrenaline rush of this opening into a verbose, hackneyed thriller about a night in the lives of a veteran patrol officer and his trainee.

headline: ‘Honey Boy’ Review: Shia LaBeouf Lets Himself Off the Hook
abstract: In a film he wrote, the actor plays a version of his own father. Too bad the bullying character based on LaBeouf has little desire for introspection.
lead_paragraph: For years, the talented actor Shia LaBeouf, who started in film and television as a child, has been acting out his emotional disturbances and drug and alcohol issues in public. In the wake of a 2017 arrest during which he made racist remarks, he has been taking more sober stock of his life and art. He wrote the screenplay and plays a major role in “Honey Boy,” directed by Alma Har’el in her fiction feature debut.

headline: ‘16 Bars’ Review: Inmates Find the Beat
abstract: This film about a music workshop held at a city jail only sometimes transcends its role as an awareness tool.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “16 Bars” is constructed around a workshop that Todd Thomas — a.k.a. Speech of the Atlanta hip-hop group Arrested Development — led at a jail in Richmond, Va., in 2017. Thomas helped inmates make music in a recording studio on site; the workshop was part of a voluntary program designed to reduce recidivism rates.

headline: ‘Watson’ Review: Environmentalism on the High Seas
abstract: Lesley Chilcott’s documentary on Paul Watson includes snippets of his “eco-vigilante” group’s widely publicized skirmishes.
lead_paragraph: Paul Watson is a different sort of environmentalist than is typical in documentaries. In “Watson,” the director Lesley Chilcott’s profile of the maritime activist, he makes the case for direct confrontation on the high seas. If that meant ramming a boat he believed was engaged in poaching, then by god, that boat was getting rammed.

headline: ‘Earthquake Bird’ Review: Unlikely Friends Caught in a Mystery
abstract: The film is based on a novel about a reserved Englishwoman and a good-time American living in Japan.
lead_paragraph: British novelists do love their aptonyms. Dickens had Scrooge (and dozens of others), Martin Amis had Mary Lamb, and for her first novel, “The Earthquake Bird,” Susanna Jones had Lucy Fly. Lucy, for reasons illuminated in the unfolding of a missing-person mystery, zoomed from England to Japan as soon as she was legally able. But even in her new home she seems caged and eager to take wing.

headline: ‘Klaus’ Review: A Santa Origin Story
abstract: A postman dashes through the snow with a certain toymaker in this animated holiday film.
lead_paragraph: Jason Schwartzman does almost too good of a job voicing an irritating character in the animated movie “Klaus.” He plays Jesper, a student who is deliberately flunking out of the postal academy. He believes that his father, the academy’s head who’s been indulging the kid’s cushy lifestyle, will hand him a cushy position with an “as you were.” Not so.

headline: Here’s a Terrifying Thought for the N.B.A.: Giannis Looks Better
abstract: Antetokounmpo had 38 points in Milwaukee’s win over the Clippers on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Clippers have occupied a nice slice of the N.B.A. spotlight this season. They have two new stars and championship hopes. Their marketing department has spent considerable time and energy trolling the Lakers. It is big news when Kawhi Leonard plays and even bigger news when he does not, and that is when you know you have some serious cachet as an organization.

abstract: The gallery helped build an American market for artists like Käthe Kollwitz and Egon Schiele. It is winding down business and transitioning to a nonprofit foundation by the end of 2020.

headline: She Was Afraid of Her Husband. Days Later, She and Her 5-Year-Old Were Dead.

headline: Online Home Buying by Generation

abstract: From millennials to boomers, different age groups use the internet differently to buy homes — but they have more in common than you might think.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that the internet has changed the way people buy homes. The ability to research properties and neighborhoods, contact agents and sellers, do virtual walk-throughs, and even apply for mortgages online was the stuff of science fiction in recent memory.
