headline: Pompeo and Netanyahu Push to Scrap Iran Nuclear Pact
abstract: The Israeli leader claimed international inspectors knew Iran had hidden a secret nuclear site, and the American secretary of state accused Iran of ‘nuclear extortion.’
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Thursday that the International Atomic Energy Agency had validated his longstanding allegation that Iran has been maintaining a secret nuclear site in violation of the Non-Proliferation Treaty — a claim that the agency did not publicly confirm.

headline: The Trump Impeachment Inquiry: What Happened Today
abstract: A number of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s top diplomats have testified to impeachment investigators. Where does that leave him?
lead_paragraph: [Sign up to get the Impeachment Briefing in your email inbox every weeknight.]

headline: Saving Birds by Ruffling Some Feathers
abstract: In Celia C. Pérez’s “Strange Birds,” four girls are determined to stop a scout tradition involving real birds.
lead_paragraph: We hear so much about the challenges of young female friendships. But STRANGE BIRDS: A Field Guide to Ruffling Feathers (Kokila, 350 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), Celia C. Pérez’s second middle-grade novel (after “The First Rule of Punk”), is a story about the magic and beauty of these bonds, especially when they are created through commitments to something greater. We meet four girls who live in the fictional town of Sabal Palms, Fla. — girls who are beginning to learn about the world and forge their identities. But how do you do that in a place where you don’t feel encouraged to be yourself?

headline: Remember Family Films? Disney Plus Is Making ’Em Like They Used To
abstract: For its new streaming service, Disney is reviving small movies in the mold of “Old Yeller.” Expect to see another doggone hero, Santa’s daughter and remakes of classics like “Home Alone.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In 1957, millions of people plunked down 62 cents each to see “Old Yeller,” a simple, sentimental Disney movie about a boy and his doggone dog in post-Civil War Texas.

headline: Russia Raided a Physics Institute. Kremlin Watchers Are Mystified.
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The armed operation targeting scientists in Moscow prompted outrage and questions about over-the-top actions by the country’s increasingly aggressive security forces.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Lebedev Physics Institute in Moscow helped the Soviet Union detonate its first nuclear bomb, figured out how to build a hydrogen bomb and has stood for decades in the vanguard of Russian scientific achievement. Seven of its scientists have won Nobel Prizes.

headline: American Artists, Inspiring and Enchanting
abstract: New picture books about creators including Ruth Asawa, Maya Angelou and August Wilson let children get to know the real-life people behind great works.
lead_paragraph: Works of art engage our hearts and excite our imaginations, but often the creators behind the work remain a mystery. Lately, however, picture books have taken up that cause, giving children a chance to look into artists’ lives and begin to get to know their work. These new books about American artists and writers include some familiar names like Maya Angelou and William Carlos Williams. Others are less well known, like Ruth Asawa and Tyrus Wong. This diverse mix of makers have life stories that take us from coast to coast, and open doors and windows to the larger world. Best of all, each book offers insight and inspiration to young readers — and young creators — through dynamic, original art and great writing.

headline: Bill Gates Objects to Elizabeth Warren’s Wealth Tax, and She Offers to Explain
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate addressed Mr. Gates on Twitter after he questioned whether “she’d even be willing” to sit down with someone “who has large amounts of money.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday invited the billionaire Bill Gates to meet so she could allay his worries about her plans to raise taxes on the wealthy and explain “exactly how much” he would pay.

headline: Gates on Warren’s Wealth Tax: ‘I’ve Paid More Than Anyone’
keywords: ['Taxation', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Bill Gates, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, expressed skepticism over Senator Elizabeth Warren’s plan to raise taxes on the wealthy. Ms. Warren has offered to meet with Mr. Gates to explain her ideas.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, expressed skepticism over Senator Elizabeth Warren’s plan to raise taxes on the wealthy. Ms. Warren has offered to meet with Mr. Gates to explain her ideas.

headline: Jennifer Lee, Queen of the ‘Frozen’ Franchise
abstract: Strengthening Disney’s historically not-so-great sisterhood.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — For decades, Disney hypnotized us into thinking that someday our prince would come. We would get a wake-up kiss, don the glass slipper, let down our locks so he could clamber up the tower and rescue us. True love would break the spell, chase away the bad spirits.

headline: A House With Art From the Kitchen to the Garden
abstract: Leticia and Miky Grendene seek out the happy and uplifting in the photographs and contemporary works they collect.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The kitchen is where all the action happens at the waterfront home of Leticia and Miky (pronounced Mickey) Grendene. For that reason they have used the large and inviting space as a canvas for their art collection, which is largely made up of photographs. “We spend so much time in here cooking, which Miky does every night, and enjoying great meals and wine with our family and friends,” Ms. Grendene said. “Why not display beautiful art here?”

headline: Chicago Police Superintendent to Retire. He Guided a Department in Crisis.
abstract: Eddie Johnson helped stabilize the country’s second-largest municipal police force as it faced mounting protests and an uptick in homicides.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Eddie Johnson, who took over Chicago’s police department at a time of cratering public confidence and a spike in homicides, announced on Thursday that he would retire, saying at an emotional news conference that after 31 years of police work, “it’s time.”

headline: Malbecs From Argentina Fight the Stereotypes
abstract: Once a wine establishes a reputation, is it bound by it forever? Or can ambitious producers explore a wine’s potential, even if it will cost more?
lead_paragraph: Many cuisines brought by immigrants to the United States have long been pigeonholed as cheap and plentiful, part of a high-volume, low-margin business.

headline: Champagne-Style Sparklers, Made in America
abstract: Sparkling wines come from all over the world, in many different styles. But what about those made here using the same grapes and method as Champagne?
lead_paragraph: I’ll drink sparkling wine almost anytime, wherever it comes from, however it’s served.

headline: Wake
abstract: We examine hidden histories in HBO’s “Watchmen” and Bong Joon Ho’s “Parasite.”
lead_paragraph: We examine how HBO’s series “Watchmen” and Bong Joon Ho’s film “Parasite” bring to light the hidden histories that shape our modern lives.

headline: Suspect Charged With Hate Crime in Acid Attack on Hispanic Man
abstract: A 61-year-old white man is accused of calling a Peruvian-born U.S. citizen an “illegal” and throwing acid at him outside a taqueria in Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: A 61-year-old white man who is accused of splashing acid on a Hispanic man’s face and telling him to “go back” to his country has been charged with a hate crime by prosecutors in Milwaukee.

headline: For a Los Angeles Dance Festival, Reviving a Homegrown Modernist
abstract: Bella Lewitzky’s “Kinaesonata” from 1970 is nothing short of a revelation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bella Lewitzky was a fervently Californian choreographer, a force-of-nature creator who had no particular desire to make it in New York. Instead, she believed in her own center of choreographic gravity, in Los Angeles. So it seems fitting that “Kinaesonata,” not seen for more than 20 years, has been revived for L.A. Dances, a festival at L.A. Dance Project.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 13, 2019
abstract: How much political experience does it take to be elected president?
lead_paragraph: This graph originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com. By Friday morning, Nov. 15, we will provide the “Reveal” — the graph’s free online link, additional background and questions, shout-outs highlighting student comments and headlines, and Stat Nuggets.

headline: Is There a Right Way to Be Deaf?
abstract: I’ve always felt like the object of a constant tug of war between the deaf and the hearing communities.
lead_paragraph: “Your whole life, they’ve been trying to take you away from me,” my father says to me, referring to the deaf community.

headline: We Can Help Men Live Longer
keywords: ['Longevity', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Men and Boys', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Elderly']
abstract: We need to pay more attention to the factors that contribute to earlier deaths for men.
lead_paragraph: All over the country, men are dying. Every kind of man: rich and poor, blue collar and white collar, men of all races, religions and ethnicities. In addition to sex, these dying Americans share another trait: They are no longer young. How can it be that men by the millions are dying while their female counterparts are not — and no one seems to notice or care?

headline: Hillary Clinton on Medicare for All: ‘The Goal Is the Right Goal,’ but It Won’t Pass
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The 2016 Democratic nominee said she viewed two central policies embraced by the left in the 2020 primary — single-payer health care and a wealth tax — as unworkable or politically impractical.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton said Wednesday she hoped for a return to “boring, normal times” after the 2020 election, voicing skepticism of her party’s populist wing and predicting that Senator Elizabeth Warren’s proposal for single-payer health care would never get enacted.

headline: Police Officer Is Charged With Murder of British Soccer Player
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Soccer']
abstract: Dalian Atkinson, a star of the English Premier League in the 1990s, died after being shot by a Taser during a late-night altercation three years ago.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A police officer has been charged with the murder of a former Premier League soccer player who died in 2016 after being shot by a Taser gun during a confrontation outside his father’s home in western England, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: FKA twigs Is a Creature of Desire on ‘Magdalene’
abstract: The singer, dancer and video artist’s new album fixates on selfless devotion that expresses faith.
lead_paragraph: For some performers, sexiness is the whole story. For FKA twigs, it’s only where the questions begin.

headline: Hilary Clinton Discusses Medicare for All and Taxing the Wealthy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Taxation', 'Medicare']
abstract: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton suggested that “Medicare for all”-style health care and higher taxes on the very wealthy were politically impractical.
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton suggested that “Medicare for all”-style health care and higher taxes on the very wealthy were politically impractical.

headline: The Real Cost of Diversifying College Rosters
abstract: College coaches struggle to find athletes who can’t pay to play elite youth sports. So Amherst College administrators have reconsidered what it takes to recruit.
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — Kaetu Wleh, who emigrated from Liberia to Boston with his mother as a newborn, never had a favorite sport growing up. But six years ago, as a middle school student, he took a chance on an after-school program called SquashBusters, which is financed by donations and provides students from challenged communities with academic tutoring and expert coaching in squash.

headline: Xerox Makes Takeover Offer for HP
abstract: A merger would combine two once-formidable, print-focused companies as demand for printed documents and ink has waned.
lead_paragraph: Xerox became synonymous with photocopying and printing. HP’s business today is built, in large part, on its printers. Now Xerox wants to combine the two companies.

headline: Pho, Unadorned
abstract: There’s an austere clarity to the broth at Just Pho, a Midtown restaurant specializing in northern-style pho, at once more carnal and delicate than its southern counterpart.
lead_paragraph: There’s an austere clarity to the broth at Just Pho, a Midtown restaurant specializing in northern-style pho, at once more carnal and delicate than its southern counterpart.

headline: Hurricane Tweet That Angered Trump Wasn’t About Trump, Forecasters Say
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Hurricane Dorian (2019)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Meteorologists were addressing public concern, not the president's tweets, when they assured Alabamians that a hurricane would not hit them, according to new documents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When officials at a government weather forecasting office assured Alabama residents that a September hurricane would not hit their state, they did not intend to contradict President Trump’s insistence that it would, according to newly disclosed documents.

headline: A Soup That Needs No Accompaniment at Just Pho
abstract: The pho most Americans know is from Vietnam’s south, but Just Pho, in Midtown, serves northern-style pho, without extras like lime and bean sprouts.
lead_paragraph: On every table at Just Pho stands a jar of dam toi, white vinegar steeped with whole garlic cloves, drifts of chopped garlic and bright, ragged stubs of red chile. Stir it, and the chile seeds swirl.

headline: Football’s Longest Drive: 1,000 Miles Across Australia
abstract: For Indigenous Australians in isolated towns, “bush footy” is more religion than sport. Neither distance, the police nor even death can keep teams from competing.
lead_paragraph: LAJAMANU, Australia — Halfway into a 400-mile journey through a dusty stretch of the Australian desert, the team’s minibus ran into trouble.

headline: Whitney Houston’s Confidante Robyn Crawford Breaks Her Silence
abstract: In “A Song for You,” Crawford publicly acknowledges her turbulent, and at times romantic, relationship with the pop icon.
lead_paragraph: A SONG FOR YOU My Life With Whitney Houston By Robyn CrawfordRead by the author

headline: How Many Lines Can a Politician Cross? Kentucky Governor Is a Cautionary Tale
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Even with President Trump’s support, Matt Bevin’s poor showing in Kentucky served notice that unpopular candidates from a dominant party can struggle to survive.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Donna Jimenez, a registered Republican, voted for Matt Bevin when he successfully ran for governor of Kentucky in 2015, heartened by his support for foster care and adoption. But a lot can happen in four years.

headline: Spike Lee Will Be Given Film at Lincoln Center’s Highest Honor
abstract: The director is the 46th winner of the Chaplin Award. Past recipients include Martin Scorsese and Alfred Hitchcock.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan institution is getting ready to honor one of Brooklyn’s foremost exports.

headline: Terrorism Financing Charge Upheld Against French Company Lafarge
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Terrorism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The case is the first in France to have led to a criminal inquiry into a company’s liability for its activities abroad.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Thursday upheld preliminary criminal charges against one of France’s biggest companies over allegations that it financed the Islamic State and other armed groups in Syria, while putting the lives of its employees there in danger.

headline: Asterix and the New Translated Editions
abstract: The French comic book series centered on the clever and brave Gaul warrior will be published in new Americanized versions by Papercutz.
lead_paragraph: Asterix, the long-running, best selling French comic book series about a village of Gauls resisting Roman occupation, is getting a new publisher in the United States: Papercutz. The publishing house, which specializes in graphic novels for all ages, will republish all of Asterix — which began in October 1959 and whose story is currently at Volume 38 — in a set of collected editions and with Americanized translations.

headline: A Forgotten Pioneer’s Art World Is Resurrected at the Jewish Museum
abstract: The dealer Edith Gregor Halpert helped put American art on the map — and then she vanished.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a good sign when you step into an art exhibition and immediately begin to reinstall it in your head. But don’t hold that against “Edith Halpert and the Rise of American Art,” a crowded, enthralling exhibition at the Jewish Museum with a fascinating back story that is rarely told on this scale. It recounts the life of a long-running influential art gallery and, by extension, of the person who willed it into existence.

headline: Most Hackers Aren’t Criminals
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Professional hackers work to keep people safe by finding security vulnerabilities before criminals do.
lead_paragraph: When asked what his father did for a living, my son explained to his kindergarten teacher that “he steals things, but it’s O.K. because he gets paid to do it.”

headline: Review: The Lighter Side of Life After Prison
abstract: The Showtime comedy “Back to Life,” from producers of “Fleabag,” looks at a woman trying to fit into a world that no longer wants her.
lead_paragraph: Women starting their lives over on television are usually emerging from some sort of long-term domestic captivity — marriage, child rearing, an illness of body or mind. Miri Matteson, the heroine of the BBC comedy “Back to Life” (beginning with two episodes Sunday night on Showtime), was a captive of another sort: She spent 18 years, half her life, in prison for a violent crime. Back at her parents’ house, in her time capsule of a bedroom, she scans the posters of David Bowie, Prince and George Michael before arriving at a smiling likeness of the TV chef Jamie Oliver. “Thank God he’s still with us,” she murmurs.

headline: The Baymen’s Nightmare: All the Scallops Are Dead
abstract: There have been lean years in Peconic Bay, on Long Island. But fishermen have never seen a failed harvest like this one.
lead_paragraph: You could tell it was going to be a bad scallop season just by looking in the parking lot of the Shelter Island Yacht Club.

headline: He Can’t See All the Art, but He’s One of Germany’s Top Dealers
abstract: “I don’t choose artworks, I choose artists”: Johann König says his near-blindness makes him a smarter gallerist.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With a fashion label, a magazine and a roster of up-and-coming artists who regularly pick up awards, prestigious commissions and solo museum exhibitions, Johann König has a reputation as one of Germany’s most influential young art dealers. His customers include the Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim in New York. On Nov. 9 he will open a gallery in Tokyo, adding a new outpost to an empire that already includes spaces in Berlin and London.

headline: Stolen Without a Trace, Artwork Turns Up 7 Years Later in Los Angeles
abstract: A woman taking stock of inherited goods discovered signed prints worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Seven years later, Michael Flaum still remembers the shock when he opened his storage locker in Los Angeles.

headline: Wash Your Hands in the Kitchen and the Bathroom
keywords: ['E Coli (Bacteria)', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'ANTIBIOTICS']
abstract: The most dangerous antibiotic-resistant strains of E. coli are transmitted not through food but through contact with human feces.
lead_paragraph: While it’s important to wash your hands carefully after handling raw chicken, it may be even more important to wash them after going to the bathroom. The most dangerous antibiotic-resistant strains of E. coli, called ESBLs, are transmitted not through food, according to new research, but through contact of human feces with human mouths.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: November 2019
abstract: At least 103 pro-government forces and 96 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
lead_paragraph: [Read the Afghan War Casualty Report from previous weeks.]

headline: What the Highway in Northeast Syria Tells Us About Who’s in Power Now
abstract: On northeast Syria’s main highway, a rapidly shifting power dynamic is on display, as U.S. combat vehicles zoom past tanks flying Russian and Syrian government flags.
lead_paragraph: On northeast Syria’s main highway, a rapidly shifting power dynamic is on display, as U.S. combat vehicles zoom past tanks flying Russian and Syrian government flags.

headline: Rapper T.I.’s Daughter Should Never Have Had a ‘Virginity Test’
abstract: There is no exam to verify virginity, medical experts say, and the attempt violates a woman’s rights.
lead_paragraph: The rapper and actor T.I. prompted widespread outrage after revealing on a podcast that he has accompanied his daughter, now 18, to a yearly doctor’s appointment to ensure that her hymen is still intact.

headline: The Small French Farm Supplying Produce to Paris’s Most Exciting Kitchens
abstract: The chefs James Henry and Shaun Kelly grow over 100 heirloom vegetable varieties in their market garden, which they personally deliver to restaurants each week.
lead_paragraph: The chefs James Henry and Shaun Kelly grow over 100 heirloom vegetable varieties in their market garden, which they personally deliver to restaurants each week.

headline: The Chefs Growing Vegetables for Paris’s Best Restaurants
abstract: As they prepare to open their own ambitious farm-to-table project, James Henry and Shaun Kelly have discovered a sideline as sought-after producers.
lead_paragraph: At around 8 a.m. on a recent Tuesday morning, the Australian chefs James Henry, 36, and Shaun Kelly, 35, fired up a mud-splattered Renault van and set off from the French village of Saint-Vrain, where they live, to Paris, 30 miles north. Once a week, for the past six months, the pair has crawled through the commuter traffic to deliver the produce they harvest from their three-acre vegetable garden to some of the capital’s most exciting restaurants. Today, crates of heirloom carrots, Hokkaido pumpkins, icicle radishes, white beets, Korean Nogak cucumbers and sprays of coriander are destined for the kitchens at chef Bertrand Grébaut’s Michelin-starred bistro Septime, the wildly popular market-driven cafe Mokonuts and the chef Iñaki Aizpitarte’s trailblazing neo-bistro Le Chateaubriand, among others.

headline: Kim, Kris and Kanye on Business, Social Media and Trump
abstract: Kim Kardashian West and Kris Jenner discussed the rise of their multimedia empire at The New York Times DealBook Conference with Andrew Ross Sorkin. Kanye West was in attendance as well.
lead_paragraph: Kim Kardashian West and Kris Jenner discussed the rise of their multimedia empire at The New York Times DealBook Conference with Andrew Ross Sorkin. Kanye West was in attendance as well.

headline: Mining Company Blamed ‘Bandits or Terrorists’ for Prior Attacks
abstract: Employees of the mining company, Semafo, have suffered three attacks in Burkina Faso in 15 months, including one on Wednesday that left at least 37 dead.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian mining company that employed workers who were fatally ambushed Wednesday in the West African nation of Burkina Faso offered no explanation on Thursday for the attack or the possible motives of the killers.

headline: Macron Says NATO Is Experiencing ‘Brain Death’ Because of Trump
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The French president wonders whether NATO is still committed to collective defense, denounces American unilateralism and calls for more European autonomy.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — French President Emmanuel Macron shocked allies in an interview published on Thursday, saying that he did not know whether NATO’s commitment to collective defense was still valid and that the alliance was experiencing “brain death” because of a lack of strategic coordination and leadership from the United States.

headline: Review: Mythical Twins Inspire Music Divided in Two
abstract: Esa-Pekka Salonen’s new “Gemini” anchored a politically charged program at the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: A whole is divided into two parts, nearly equal in size. While sharing a fundamental character, they diverge just as fundamentally. A section that could be described as recalling the color blue — even if it’s the midnight variety — is connected by a tiny, fragile bridge to an evocation of dark, churning red.

headline: Trump’s Pet Problem
abstract: A reader says you can’t be a narcissist and love a dog at the same time.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Envoy in Syria Says Not Enough Was Done to Avert Turkish Attack
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: In an internal memo, the senior American diplomat in northern Syria criticized the Trump administration for failing to try harder to deter Turkey from invading northern Syria last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American diplomat on the ground in northern Syria has criticized the Trump administration for not trying harder to prevent Turkey’s military offensive there last month — and said Turkish-backed militia fighters committed “war crimes and ethnic cleansing.”

headline: Sweetie, Where’s My Paycheck?
abstract: A reader wonders how to stand up for herself in the workplace when her boss is also her husband.
lead_paragraph: My husband started a successful business 22 years ago. I joined his staff as a full-time employee 13 years ago. I have an advanced degree in a field that is relevant to the business. The problem: He won’t give me a paycheck! He simply puts random amounts of money into our checking accounts at random times. He says, “You are paid $x a year.” But I never know if I can afford to buy a new lamp because I don’t see any accounts. He brushes off the subject when I raise it with him. How can I convince my husband that his behavior is paternalistic and demeaning?

headline: Trump Ordered to Pay $2 Million to Charities for Misuse of Foundation
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The president admitted he had used funds raised by the Donald J. Trump Foundation to promote his campaign and pay business debts.
lead_paragraph: A state judge ordered President Trump to pay $2 million in damages to nonprofit groups on Thursday after the president admitted misusing money raised by the Donald J. Trump Foundation to promote his presidential bid, pay off business debts and purchase a portrait of himself for one of his hotels.

headline: ‘Harpoon’ Review: Three Friends, One Yacht, Copious Blood
abstract: Some friendships just aren’t made to last — an understatement for the one at the center of this sharp and stylish thriller.
lead_paragraph: Rob Grant’s “Harpoon” opens with a voice-over paraphrasing Aristotle: Some friendships, the philosopher theorized, are maintained out of convenience, some for pleasure, some for fulfillment. But sometimes, we are friends with people merely because, well, we used to be friends.

headline: In the British Election, a Series of Missteps
keywords: ['Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: In a bitter and divisive campaign, the Conservatives stumbled first. Labour soon followed, with resignations and charges of anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nobody expected Britain’s general election to follow a smooth script, and by the end of a second hectic day of campaigning both of the country’s major parties had suffered a series of unexpected bumps and blows. On Thursday, it was the opposition Labour Party’s turn.

headline: Far From the Spotlight, a Boeing Partner Feels the Heat
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Military Aircraft', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Collins Aerospace provided software that has been blamed in the crashes of two 737 Max jets. Investigators and lawyers are asking what Collins knew, and when.
lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — The top executive for commercial airplanes has been ousted. The chief executive last week endured withering questioning from members of Congress. Earnings are sharply down.

headline: Hail to the Chief of Staff
abstract: The title is suddenly everywhere. It can mean almost anything.
lead_paragraph: “There wasn’t an obvious position for me,” Scott Amenta said.

headline: Bernie Sanders Wants to ‘Break Up’ ICE
abstract: Mr. Sanders released a plan on Thursday that vowed to create a “swift, fair pathway to citizenship” for undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders on Thursday called for ending virtually all of the Trump administration’s immigration policies and creating a “swift, fair pathway to citizenship” for undocumented immigrants, including by allowing people who have been in the United States illegally for five years to stay without the risk of deportation.

headline: How Kentucky Will Decide Who Won the Governor’s Race
abstract: There will be a recanvass but no recount, and then maybe a contest judged by lawmakers rather than voters. Here is how it all works.
lead_paragraph: When the election returns came in Tuesday evening, the tallies for governor were razor-close, with the Democratic challenger, Attorney General Andy Beshear, ahead of the Republican incumbent, Gov. Matt Bevin, by 5,086 votes out of more than 1.4 million cast. Mr. Beshear claimed victory, but Mr. Bevin has refused to concede defeat.

headline: Sleep Cycles: It’s 4 A.M. Why Am I Still Awake?
abstract: Readers share their stories of sleep patterns outside the norm.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can You Still #Resist When Your State’s on Fire?
abstract: A postcard from the Californiapocalypse.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When I first came to California 17 years ago, I used to laugh because the very best argument people could summon for living here was the weather. This seemed sad and pathetic for a city as big and as important as Los Angeles. The weather was nice, however.

headline: The Climate Crisis in Terms Trump Can Understand
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The president is abandoning America’s future by quitting the Paris climate accord.
lead_paragraph: President Trump made good on his promise this week to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement. This wasn’t a surprise. But it still baffles us. Try as we might, we cannot see how America’s interests are served by this decision.

headline: Ralph Nader: Why Elizabeth Warren Scares Wall Street
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Privacy']
abstract: The consumer advocate says she will hold the financial industry accountable for its misdeeds. Also: The F.T.C. and privacy; China’s looting of technology; the future of the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Film Club: ‘How a Teen Rapper With Braces Took Over the Streaming World’
abstract: What does it take to create a hit song in the internet age?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: Please watch the film before showing it to your class to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: China, Australia, Queen Elizabeth: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: China, Australia, Queen Elizabeth II
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Tom Steyer Aide Apologizes for ‘Miscommunication’ on Endorsement Solicitation
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The aide reportedly offered campaign contributions to Iowa candidates who endorsed Mr. Steyer.
lead_paragraph: Tom Steyer’s presidential campaign apologized on Thursday for “any miscommunication” it might have conveyed following a report that a top aide had privately offered campaign contributions to local candidates who would endorse Mr. Steyer.

headline: Don’t Let Party Hacks Hijack Election Reform
abstract: A nine-member commission is poised to squander a chance at needed changes.
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, New York could adopt a strong system of public financing of elections and help bring good government to Albany.

headline: The Brilliantly Eccentric Apartments of the Chelsea Hotel, in Photographs
abstract: Colin Miller has spent four years documenting the bohemian homes of the famous hotel’s remaining residents.
lead_paragraph: Colin Miller has spent four years documenting the bohemian homes of the famous hotel’s remaining residents.

headline: Inside the Last Occupied Apartments of the Chelsea Hotel
abstract: A new book celebrates the colorful living spaces of the New Yorkers who still call the legendary building home.
lead_paragraph: Few spaces inspire nostalgia for New York’s free-spirited past like the red-brick Beaux-Arts Chelsea Hotel. Yet, on his first visit to this fabled enclave of creativity, where Jack Kerouac wrote “On The Road” (1957) and Leonard Cohen and Janis Joplin famously met in 1968, the New Jersey-based photographer Colin Miller admits to being unfazed. “It wasn’t that meaningful to me at the time,” he says of touring the space in 2001. “It just seemed like a grungy, rundown hotel.” It was only on his return visit to the building more than a decade later — on commission to document its latest round of renovations (the 250-room hotel has been under construction since its legendary former manager Sidney Bard was ousted in 2007) — that he first felt its significance. “As I was shooting, I could see right into one of the apartments and it was wildly colorful,” he says. “That’s when I realized that there’s still something really interesting going on at the Chelsea.”

headline: Read the Memo by a U.S. Diplomat Criticizing Trump Policy on Syria and Turkey
abstract: “Could we have stopped Turkey from coming in?” William V. Roebuck asked in an internal memo.
lead_paragraph: In an internal memo, the senior American diplomat in northern Syria criticized the Trump administration for failing to try harder to deter Turkey from invading northern Syria last month.

headline: Buyer of G.M. Lordstown Plant Promises Union Work and Wages
abstract: The Ohio factory will be taken over by a venture that plans to hire 400 employees next year to make electric pickup trucks.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has sold its factory in Lordstown, Ohio, to a company that says it will make electric pickup trucks with union labor at wages comparable to those of the Detroit automakers.

headline: ‘Playing With Fire’ Review: A Firefighter Comedy Running on Embers
abstract: John Cena and Judy Greer elevate this family comedy that won’t quite ignite.
lead_paragraph: The hero of “Playing With Fire,” Jake Carson (John Cena), is forever pointing out that he’s not a firefighter. He’s a smokejumper, and with the help of his quirky crew, played by John Leguizamo and Keegan-Michael Key, Jake drops from helicopters to put out forest fires. With single-minded focus, he seeks out the most dangerous blazes. Unfortunately, the flat-footed family comedy around him fails to produce sparks.

lead_paragraph: Here is the October edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: George Kent Testimony: Key Excerpts From the Impeachment Inquiry Transcripts
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: House investigators released the interview transcript of a witness who provided insight into the Trump administration’s approach to foreign policy on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: House impeachment investigators on Thursday released a transcript of the testimony of George P. Kent, a senior State Department official in charge of Ukraine policy. Mr. Kent said in his deposition that he was all but cut out of decisions regarding the country after a May meeting organized by Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff.

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Who’s out of touch with reality, again?
lead_paragraph: Will the Democratic presidential nomination go to a centrist or a progressive? Which choice would give the party the best chance in next year’s election? Honestly, I have no idea.

headline: At 88, Agnes Denes Finally Gets the Retrospective She Deserves
abstract: She set out to change humanity. Now a superbly installed survey at the Shed charts this visionary artist’s 50-year journey.
lead_paragraph: We’ll be lucky this art season if we get another exhibition as tautly beautiful as “Agnes Denes: Absolutes and Intermediates” at the Shed. And we’ll be right to ponder why this artist, who was born in Budapest 88 years ago and has lived in New York City for more than 60 years, is only now having a retrospective here.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Have you read Zadie Smith’s essay in defense of fiction yet, from the Oct. 24 issue of The New York Review of Books? You’ll need a subscription, but Smith is always worth it for her thoughts on the intersection of art and culture — here, she’s grappling with the vexed question of identity and appropriation, and siding (as she has before) with creative license and the primacy of the sentence over any kind of political calculation. Chew on that while you read Smith’s new story collection, “Grand Union,” which is one of our recommended books this week.

headline: A New Book From the Creator of ‘Wonder’ Tells a Holocaust Story
abstract: In R.J. Palacio’s graphic novel “White Bird,” a grandmother finally shares her harrowing tale of survival under the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: What kind of literature do we owe our young readers? Should it aspire to artfulness, or is that a luxury when there are American educators who don’t believe the Holocaust happened?

lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg is actively preparing to enter the Democratic presidential primary and is expected to file paperwork this week designating himself as a candidate in at least one state with an early filing deadline, people briefed on Mr. Bloomberg’s plans said.

headline: Secrets and Lies
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cold War Era', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: “Spies,” by Marc Favreau, introduces the danger, sacrifice and ingenuity of 20th-century espionage to a new generation of readers.
lead_paragraph: “The lessons of the Cold War, once consigned to the history books and to the memories of aging spies, suddenly seemed shockingly relevant,” Marc Favreau writes about the discovery of Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election. Too true, and SPIES: The Secret Showdown Between America and Russia (Little, Brown, 306 pp., $17.99; ages 12 and up), his terse Y.A. account of the silent war of Soviet-American espionage, does an excellent job of introducing that story of danger, sacrifice and ingenuity to a new generation of readers.

headline: She’s Seeking Power, But She’s Not Power-Seeking
abstract: A young protagonist is up against strange creatures and authoritarian rulers in Erin Entrada Kelly’s “Lalani of the Distant Sea,” a fantasy based on Filipino folklore.
lead_paragraph: Those who live on islands understand the lore and the lure of shores. The borders between the edge of the land and the beginning of the sea lend themselves to storytelling, as the creatures of the land yearn for what lies beyond the horizon. In true island fashion, Erin Entrada Kelly’s latest, LALANI OF THE DISTANT SEA (Greenwillow, 400 pp., $16.99; ages 8 to 12), is built on the folklore of her island Filipino culture, as traditional oral lore is built on the remembrances of all the tellings that came before it.

headline: Why Spy on Twitter? For Saudi Arabia, It’s the Town Square
abstract: The indictment of two former Twitter employees accused of spying for the Saudis highlights the platform’s power and the kingdom’s efforts to control it.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In Saudi Arabia, where a relatively closed culture leaves citizens few public forums to discuss news and politics, Twitter has become a kind of town square, the place where citizens meet to swap information and debate the latest issues.

headline: These Books Deliver Fables to Live By Today
abstract: In deeply satisfying picture books by Oliver Jeffers, Bernard Villiot and Antoine Guilloppé, and more, the greedy and the vain get their comeuppance.
lead_paragraph: Fables give us archetypes to live by in nutshell form. Need a reason to press on against overwhelming odds? Just see how persistence paid off for Aesop’s slow but steady tortoise. Feeling a tad smug? Consider the comeuppance that awaited that same fable’s haughty hare. While Aesop did not work his magic expressly with young audiences in mind, the pithy, visually arresting narrative mode he left his indelible mark on has proved a good match for the children’s picture book, a genre that likewise thrives on brevity and the wish to reveal the essences of things in their clearest possible form.

headline: Can an Advice Columnist Help This Middle Schooler?
abstract: The protagonist of Julie Murphy’s endearing “Dear Sweet Pea” is used to dispensing the advice. Now her life is a mess, and she needs guidance fast.
lead_paragraph: Before her parents’ divorce, Patricia “Sweet Pea” DiMarco’s favorite family tradition was reading a popular advice column called “Miss Flora Mae I?” over breakfast. Her father read the questions aloud, while Sweet Pea and her mother took turns coming up with advice. Sweet Pea’s mother is a therapist, and Sweet Pea finds her advice “a little too perfect. The kind of stuff that sounds easy but is hard to actually do.” Sweet Pea’s style is more practical. “Nobody’s perfect. What’s the use in pretending?”

headline: Her Home Burned, and All Was Lost. Until Firefighters Found a Wedding Ring.
abstract: Patty Shales believed that everything inside her house in the Los Angeles hills was destroyed by a wildfire. But a treasured possession of her late mother’s survived.
lead_paragraph: Patty Shales was asleep in her home in the Brentwood hills of Los Angeles when her neighbor called to say a fire was burning near the Getty Center art museum.

headline: Detroit’s Schools Are Unconstitutionally Unequal
abstract: Does the Constitution permit such shoddy treatment of schoolchildren? We may soon learn a federal court’s answer.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past decade, schoolchildren in Detroit were forced to endure conditions that can only be described as abhorrent. In many schools, classroom temperatures exceeded 90 degrees during the spring and summer, and neared freezing during frigid Michigan winters. Mold was endemic in some school buildings, and vermin was common in others.

lead_paragraph: Democrats, buoyed by their party’s electoral sweep in Virginia this week, plan on Friday to revive the Equal Rights Amendment in Congress, embarking on what they hope is a final push to add the nearly century-old measure to enshrine equality of the sexes into the Constitution.

But the relationship between President Trump and Attorney General William P. Barr may be growing more complicated with the rising threat of impeachment.

lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — In a spasm of violence related to last month’s disputed presidential election, protesters kidnapped the mayor of a small town in central Bolivia on Wednesday, forcibly cut her hair, drenched her with red paint, made her sign an improvised resignation letter, then marched her through the streets barefoot, witnesses said.

headline: Take One’s Turn
abstract: Peter Wentz spins us all around in his Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Weekends are familiar territory for Pete Wentz, as are slangy and buzzy debut entries. He is one of those constructors with an ear for lingo and cheesy humor, so you have to roll up your sleeves and blow up your whoopee cushion to really soak it all in.

headline: Review: Peter Dinklage Tackles ‘Cyrano’ Without the Nose
abstract: The Emmy-winning “Game of Thrones” star shows off his abundant charisma in a lachrymose musical adaptation of Rostand’s classic.
lead_paragraph: Deep, imperious and thundering with an angry irony, the voice precedes the man. When it first tears through the darkness, amplified to eardrum-rattling volume, you sense a collective quickening of pulses at the Daryl Roth Theater, where a somber and monotonous new variation on “Cyrano de Bergerac” opened on Thursday night.

headline: Anger in Hong Kong After Student Dies From Fall Following Clash With Police
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Falls', 'Tear Gas']

headline: The Unexpected Joy of Repeat Experiences
abstract: Novelty is overrated.
lead_paragraph: Scrolling through Instagram can quickly convince you that everyone’s life is more interesting than yours. During a particularly adventurous week on Instagram Stories recently, I saw water skiing in Maui, hiking in Yosemite and swimming with wild pigs in Bermuda. Wild pigs!

lead_paragraph: The last time neighbors saw 71-year-old Robert Hisashi Nishimoto was Saturday, when he was doing yardwork in front of his home in Hilo, Hawaii.

abstract: My father’s midlife transition taught me that if life is about change, love is about constancy.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘One Child Nation’ and ‘Great Performances’
abstract: An acclaimed documentary hits Amazon. And a recent revival of “The King and I” airs as part of PBS’s “Great Performances.”
lead_paragraph: ONE CHILD NATION (2019) Stream on Amazon. The filmmakers Nanfu Wang and Jialing Zhang explore China’s long-running one-child policy in this searing documentary, which was applauded at this year’s Sundance Film Festival. The film focuses on the toll that the policy took during its decades of enforcement (China embraced the policy in the late 1970s and ended it in 2015). It uses Wang’s own family and story as a way in, combining her narration with interviews with people who felt the effects of the policy in different, troubling ways. It’s an emotionally intense topic that Wang and Zhang address “with clarity, concision and strategically restrained outrage,” Manohla Dargis wrote in her review for The New York Times. “I’ve watched ‘One Child Nation’ twice, at times through tears,” she added, “but there’s nothing in it that’s gratuitously exploitative. It is instead an essential account of one battle in the continuing war over women’s bodies, one that, Wang forcefully observes, is in no way limited to China.”

headline: Louis Vuitton to Go, a New Kyoto Hotel and More
keywords: ['Art', 'Design', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Owls']
abstract: T’s roundup of people, places and things to know now.
lead_paragraph: Virgil Abloh, the artistic director of Louis Vuitton’s men’s wear, is nothing if not intellectually nimble. He trained as an architect and has worked as a D.J., artist, musician and Kanye West whisperer. When it comes to fashion, his references are equally wide-ranging, and he’s proved as likely to send trench coats and pleated pants down the runway as mesh tees and floral harnesses. With his latest capsule collection, he’s baked versatility into individual pieces. Included in the 14-item line, called Louis Vuitton 2054 (the year the brand will turn 200), is a shirt that turns into a pillow, a weekend bag that morphs into a sleeping bag and a coat that doubles as a backpack. It was, according to Abloh, an exercise in rethinking the nature of apparel and what the future of fashion will be. He arrived at his answer — technical and transformable — after looking at collapsible camping equipment. “I was very much inspired by the materials and folding ingenuity that exists in that world of products,” Abloh said, in comments emailed by the brand. Indeed, folding is an integral component in experiencing these multifunctional items: The shirt, papery nylon with removable arms and plexiglass zipper pulls, can be tucked into its own back pocket, and the sleeping bag rolls out of the side compartment of an oversize lambskin duffel.

None of that dissuaded Mr. Gates from pouring himself into his business, nor discouraged his investors from pouring in their money.

headline: Europeans Bewildered as Trump Stomps Off
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The spectacle of an American president breaking trust with NATO allies as he tries to avoid impeachment is hard to grasp. When will it all end?
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Now it’s impeachment. To many of the world’s ordinary citizens, not well versed in American constitutional procedures, it means one thing only: Donald Trump, 45th president of the United States, is accused of serious foul play. Pressuring the Ukrainian president to dig up dirt on a political rival’s son? Unbelievable. Is the impeachment investigation, which  took shape as October yielded to November,  an attempt to “overturn” the 2016 presidential election? The European far right will say that, of course. But most people in Italy — and in Europe — will sit back and watch the show. Without fully understanding it. Nor enjoying it.

headline: Don’t Let the New START Treaty Lapse
keywords: ['Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Treaties', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty']
abstract: In a little more than a year, the last nuclear arms limitation pact with Russia expires. Losing its guarantees would be a heavy blow to American security.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The New START Treaty, the last and most important nuclear arms limitation agreement still in force between Russia and the United States, expires early in 2021. Perhaps it can be extended. But it has long been criticized by the Trump administration, on two points: The treaty does not limit new nuclear weapons systems that the Russians are threatening to use against us; and it does not include the Chinese, who are busily modernizing their nuclear arsenal.

headline: On Hawaii, the Fight for Taro’s Revival
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Taro (Vegetable)', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Land Use Policies', 'Native Hawaiians']
abstract: The root vegetable was a staple food for centuries until contact with the West. Its return signals a reclamation of not just land but a culture — and a way of life.
lead_paragraph: FROM ABOVE, THE blue is forever. There’s not a continent for more than 2,000 miles, only these tiny knuckles of green: the Hawaiian Islands, one of the most remote yet most visited archipelagos on earth. An island is defined by the sea that surrounds it; tourists tend to gaze outward, at the waves, toward what separates them from the world they’ve left behind. But on Kauai, at the northwestern end of the chain, it’s the mountains that command the eye, streaked with waterfalls and so furrowed that in satellite photos they look like fossils. Here, on the north shore, the flanks of tall Mamalahoa are steaming, night rains turning to mist in the morning sun. Thousands of feet down lies the river plain of Waipa and its flooded fields filled with leaves like broad, crinkled hearts, each larger than a human face. Among the thick, blushing stalks, a snail.

headline: Trump Rules Out Complete Rollback of China Tariffs as Talks Continue

headline: Where to Eat Hawaii’s Most Sacred Ingredient
abstract: Once a staple of Native Hawaiian cuisine, taro is no longer as easily accessible, but a new wave of chefs is rediscovering its power.
lead_paragraph: Of all the culinary staples to be found at a luau, poi — a nutrient-rich paste made from mashed taro root — is the most divisive. As purple as a fading bruise, with the texture of baby food, the sweet and sometimes sour starch, once a pillar of the Native Hawaiian diet, offends the average American palate — which is exactly what prompted chef Lee Anne Wong to get creative with it. At Koko Head Cafe, her popular all-day brunch restaurant in Honolulu, she ferments poi into yogurt, sours it into hollandaise sauce, and bakes the koena, or the outer scrapings off the taro’s corm, the plant’s fuzzy underground stem, into dense but flaky biscuits.

headline: Watch Opening Ceremony’s Founders Create Hats Inspired by Their Mothers
abstract: Carol Lim and Humberto Leon are the latest subjects to take the “Make T Something “ challenge.
lead_paragraph: Carol Lim and Humberto Leon founded Opening Ceremony, their concept boutique in New York’s SoHo, in 2002, with a simple but novel idea: They would source under-the-radar design from their travels around the world and bring it together under one roof. Over the years, Opening Ceremony has featured unsung talents from countries such as Russia, Argentina, Korea and China, and earned a reputation for its colorful, off-kilter aesthetic and D.I.Y. approach to style (Leon’s mother once sewed sweatshirts for the store’s own clothing line). In recent seasons, Lim and Leon have also ramped up their political messaging and activism, presenting in-house collections that have tackled pressing issues, albeit through playful high-spectacle presentations. The brand’s spring 2019 collection, for example, was a celebration of the gay and trans communities and proceeds from a raffle at the show went to the Transgender Law Center. “Representation is a pillar of how we work,” says Leon.

headline: The ‘Lost Cause’ That Built Jim Crow
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Reconstruction Era', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Lynching']
abstract: Southern “Redeemers” snuffed out the first black power movement.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden launched his presidential bid in April with a bold defense of the principle that “all men are created equal,” a principle he rightly argued that, from Thomas Jefferson on, “we haven’t always lived up to.” But, Mr. Biden added, this is something “we have never before walked away from,” and that’s where he went wrong. Like most Americans, the former vice president forgets the period ironically known as Redemption, the movement that followed the abolition of slavery and ended 12 years of America’s first experiment in interracial democracy — Reconstruction — with a systematic, multitiered, terrorist-backed rollback, when the defeated Confederate South, as the saying went, “rose again.”

headline: Kusama Arrives. Is It Worth Your Time to Wait in Line?
abstract: You’ll get to spend one minute in the artist’s newest “Infinity Mirrored Room” at David Zwirner in Chelsea. Expect dancing lights to infinity, or as far as your cameraphone allows.
lead_paragraph: The Eiffel Tower or the Great Mosque of Mecca; the new iPhone or the latest Harry Potter book; Di Fara Pizza or that bakery that made Cronuts happen a few years back. For some experiences you just have to wait — and the exhibitions of Yayoi Kusama, the 90-year-old Japanese mastermind of obsessively dotted paintings, hallucinatory pumpkins and sometimes blandly decorative installations, have become the art world’s equivalent of Star Wars premieres.

headline: From Nabokov and Lawrence, Giants of 20th-Century Fiction, New Volumes of Nonfiction
abstract: “Think, Write, Speak” collects Vladimir Nabokov’s interviews and incidental prose. “The Bad Side of Books” collects D.H. Lawrence’s most memorable essays.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Nabokov and D. H. Lawrence each wrote a major novel (“Lolita,” “Lady Chatterley’s Lover”) that was banned and unbanned and banned again before being cut free.

headline: A Prisoner Who Briefly Died Argues That He’s Served His Life Sentence
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A court in Iowa found that a murderer who was revived “is either still alive, in which case he must remain in prison, or he is actually dead, in which case this appeal is moot.”
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to complete a sentence of life in prison? One prisoner claims he has done it by serving time until the moment of his death — plus another four years since — and says it is well past time to set him free.

headline: ‘No Longer a Disease for Our Moms and Grandmas’: Women on Early Breast Cancer
abstract: After a Styles column about one woman’s experience with an early diagnosis, readers shared poignant stories of fear and survival.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 41, Jenny Rose Ryan was shocked to learn she had breast cancer.

headline: Gillian Jagger, Sculptor Whose Medium Was Nature, Dies at 88
abstract: Her sculptures, which often incorporated tree trunks and animal carcasses, emphasized commonality and connection between humans, animals and the earth.
lead_paragraph: Gillian Jagger, an artist guided by a deep-seated connection to nature and best known for imposing sculptures and installations that often incorporated tree trunks and animal carcasses, died on Oct. 21 in Ellenville, in upstate New York. She was 88.

headline: The Strange Things You Find on Authors’ Websites
abstract: A quick survey of the writers on the fiction best-seller list turned up Spotify playlists, blogs “written” by their dogs, movie reviews and merchandise.
lead_paragraph: Authors’ websites aren’t just for reviews any more. A quick survey of the writers on the fiction best-seller list turned up Spotify playlists, blogs “written” by their dogs, movie reviews and more.

headline: Why Do We Tolerate Saudi Money in Tech?
abstract: Saudi Arabia may have had spies at Twitter. And the country’s oligarchs keep investing in American tech companies. When will we learn?
lead_paragraph: Are you so poor that all you have is money?

headline: The Monster Next Door
abstract: An artist read Ann Rule’s “The Stranger Beside Me” during a pivotal time. Here’s her look inside that memorable book.

headline: We’re Living Act 1 of the Disaster Films We Grew Up With
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Global Warming', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: There is a tension in the air as we practically lunge for the last bag of ice or can of food.
lead_paragraph: MARIN COUNTY, Calif. — Another year, another fall, and our skies have turned hazy orange once again — ash from the Kincade fire, which first sparked about 60 miles away, began slowly falling onto my windshield in mid-October, like some perverse first snow of the season.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Team Granted Class Status in Equal Pay Lawsuit
abstract: A federal judge rejected U.S. Soccer’s argument that no discrimination existed. Megan Rapinoe praised the decision as a validation of their campaign.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing the United States women’s national soccer team’s gender discrimination lawsuit against U.S. Soccer granted the players class status on Friday, an important victory for the women that appeared to support the claim that they are subjected to unequal working conditions and unequal pay when they played games for their country.

headline: ‘A Warning’ by ‘Anonymous’: 5 Takeaways
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The book seems to be the product of a Republican with access to the White House who grew increasingly upset by President Trump.
lead_paragraph: [Former Homeland Security official, Miles Taylor, reveals himself as “anonymous.”]

headline: How Scientists Got Climate Change So Wrong
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Weather', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Methane', 'Floods']
abstract: Few thought it would arrive so quickly. Now we’re facing consequences once viewed as fringe scenarios.
lead_paragraph: For decades, most scientists saw climate change as a distant prospect. We now know that thinking was wrong. This summer, for instance, a heat wave in Europe penetrated the Arctic, pushing temperatures into the 80s across much of the Far North and, according to the Belgian climate scientist Xavier Fettweis, melting some 40 billion tons of Greenland’s ice sheet.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The Twitter presidency. “A Warning”reviewed. Joe Pesci comes into his own. The Popeyes sandwich strikes a chord for African-Americans. And more.
lead_paragraph: Baby, it’s cold outside — at least at NYT HQ. Might be a good weekend to stay under the covers and catch up on some amazing articles you may have missed.

headline: Among the Trolls
abstract: Andrew Marantz talks about “Antisocial,” and Gail Collins discusses “No Stopping Us Now.”
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: For Quebec, a French Woman May Not Be French Enough
abstract: A French woman was denied a certificate she needed before she can settle permanently in Quebec on the grounds that she had not demonstrated sufficient proficiency in French.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Is a French woman who grew up speaking the language of Molière not French enough for Quebec?

headline: Houston Prosecutor Fired for Asking Assault Victim’s Immigration Status
abstract: Police officers said John Denholm, an assistant district attorney, declined to file charges in a sexual assault case because he believed that the victim was “illegal.”
lead_paragraph: To the police officer who was there, what happened Halloween night inside a Houston jail certainly qualified as a crime: An inmate locked up on suspicion of drunken driving tried to pull another inmate toward him while exposing himself.

headline: U.S. Education Dept. Cancels Loans for 1,500 Defrauded Students
abstract: The department sent millions of dollars to two schools that had lost their accreditation and were no longer eligible for the federal loans.
lead_paragraph: About 1,500 students who attended two art institutes that were part of the sudden collapse of a career-school chain this year will have their federal loans canceled, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos said on Friday.

headline: The Scene In Iowa
abstract: What we saw at the state’s biggest political event of the year.
lead_paragraph: For Monday’s episode, our producers Monika Evstatieva and Clare Toeniskoetter traveled to Iowa for the Democratic Party’s biggest political event yet in the run-up to the presidential election. Monika shared her observations about the ups and downs she witnessed at the event:

headline: With Medical Bills Skyrocketing, More Hospitals Are Suing for Payment
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Debt Collection', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: As deductibles and co-pays grow, insured patients owe a larger share of their medical bills. More and more are being taken to court.
lead_paragraph: WISE, Va. — When a judge hears civil cases at the courthouse in this southwest Virginia town two days a month, many of the lawsuits have a common plaintiff: the local hospital, Ballad Health, suing patients over unpaid medical bills.

headline: Marciano Art Foundation Is Accused of Unfair Labor Practices
abstract: Employees were laid off after moving to unionize. Now a union is filing a charge at the National Labor Relations Board.
lead_paragraph: Labor organizers in Los Angeles have accused the Marciano Art Foundation, a private museum, of violating federal law by dismissing dozens of employees after they announced that they wanted to form a union.

headline: Ukraine Affair Thrusts White House Lawyer Into Center of Crisis
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: John Eisenberg played down aides’ complaints about Ukraine policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The complaints came to the National Security Council’s top lawyer within hours of each other in early July. Two senior aides said they feared that one of President Trump’s top political appointees was improperly pressuring Ukrainian officials to help the president’s political fortunes.

headline: Peter Collier, Author and Leading Conservative Voice, Dies at 80
abstract: He and David Horowitz wrote well-regarded biographies of prominent families. They also drew attention for their ideological shift from left to right.
lead_paragraph: Peter Collier, a prolific writer who midway into his career made a high-profile ideological shift from left to right, becoming a leading conservative voice as well as a publisher of others, died on Nov. 1 in a hospital in Sacramento, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Tucked in WADA Rules, a Ticking Bomb for European Soccer
abstract: A Russian doping scandal could force organizers of next year’s continental soccer championship to bar Russia’s team and move matches scheduled for St. Petersburg.
lead_paragraph: KATOWICE, Poland — Buried on page 49 of a dry procedural document published by the World Anti-Doping Agency last year is a paragraph that threatens to be a major headache for the organizers of next summer’s European soccer championship.

headline: Norman Myers Dies at 85; Sounded Early Alarm on Environment
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Research', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: He lobbied governments and wrote books, papers and articles to alert the public to looming disasters like mass extinction well before they were common knowledge.
lead_paragraph: The British conservationist Norman Myers drew public attention to mass extinction, disappearing habitats and environmental refugees long before they became common topics in the news and causes of widespread concern.

headline: Billie Eilish, Keanu Reeves and Leonardo DiCaprio at Lacma Gala
abstract: Benefits were also held for Pencils of Promise and the New York Landmarks Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were also held for Pencils of Promise and the New York Landmarks Conservancy.

headline: Hollywood Turns Out for Lacma
abstract: Benefits were also held for Pencils of Promise and the New York Landmarks Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art and Gucci held the Art+Film Gala on Nov. 2. Pencils of Promise, a nonprofit that builds schools in the developing world, held a benefit on Nov. 4 at Cipriani Wall Street. And the New York Landmarks Conservancy honored preservationists at its benefit at the Plaza on Nov. 6.

headline: Indigenous Art That Targets Stereotypes
abstract: The National Gallery of Canada has gathered contemporary Indigenous art from around the world for a major exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The National Gallery of Canada had a rusty start when it came to Indigenous people and their art. It had been around for 47 years before it finally showed any works by Indigenous people in 1927 as part of a West Coast exhibit that is most remembered for introducing much of Canada to Emily Carr, a non-Indigenous woman whose paintings often portrayed Indigenous art.

headline: Maria Perego, Topo Gigio’s Creator, Dies at 95
abstract: The mouse puppet that she made in the late 1950s in Italy became a worldwide phenomenon, with the help of “The Ed Sullivan Show.”
lead_paragraph: Maria Perego, an Italian puppeteer and the creator of Topo Gigio, the lovable mouse who became famous to American audiences as a frequent guest on “The Ed Sullivan Show” in the 1960s and early ’70s and was known worldwide, died on Thursday in Milan. She was 95.

headline: Make the Most of Your Credit Card Rewards for Gift Season
keywords: ['Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Credit Cards', 'Personal Finances', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Shopping and Retail', 'your-feed-wirecutter']
abstract: Credit card rewards such as discounted travel and cash back can help take some of the sting out of your holiday budget.
lead_paragraph: Your credit card bills may not inspire visions of holiday cheer — but the good news is, your credit card spending has likely earned you at least a small trove of points, miles, or cash back. According to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s latest Consumer Credit Card Market report (PDF), more than 80 percent of all credit card spending in 2018 was done on a rewards card.

headline: Run, Mike, Run!
abstract: A Bloomberg-Trump contest would be one between a maker and a faker.
lead_paragraph: Mike Bloomberg should run for president, for two reasons that ought to be dispositive. First, he would be a very good president, potentially a great one. Second, he stands a much better chance of beating Donald Trump than anyone in the current Democratic field.

headline: Logan Paul. KSI. YouTube. Fight. Logan Paul. KSI. Boxing.
abstract: This is both a legitimate headline and a naked chase for viewership. Just like this boxing match that is actually being sanctioned in California.
lead_paragraph: Boxing is no stranger to the cynical cash grab.

headline: President Reagan Returns to Berlin, This Time in Bronze
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Berlin Wall', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: After a decade of lobbying to place a statue of Ronald Reagan in Berlin, the Gipper was given a place beside the Brandenburg Gate, atop the U.S. Embassy.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Germans mark the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall on Saturday, an American who was intertwined with the events of that day  will be looking on, figuratively at least.

lead_paragraph: Climate change is risky business — including for officials at the Federal Reserve.

headline: Watch Reagan’s 1987 ‘Tear Down This Wall’ Speech
keywords: ['Berlin Wall', 'Cold War Era', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In June 1987, President Ronald Reagan spoke at Berlin’s iconic Brandenburg Gate in view of the Berlin Wall, and delivered a message to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader at the time.
lead_paragraph: In June 1987, President Ronald Reagan spoke at Berlin’s iconic Brandenburg Gate in view of the Berlin Wall, and delivered a message to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader at the time.

headline: As Campaign Season Heats Up, Trump Has Turned the Official Into the Political
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Hatch Act (1939)', 'AIR FORCE ONE (JET)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Previous presidents made an effort to make a distinction between the two and had their campaigns, not taxpayers, foot the bill for political events.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump traveled on Air Force One to Florida one day last month  to pitch an executive order aimed at improving private Medicare plans when he launched into a series of broadsides against some of his possible Democratic opponents.

headline: Judge Rules Prosecutors Misrepresented Evidence From C.I.A. Sites
keywords: ['Military Tribunals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Torture', 'Cole (USS)', 'Terrorism', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A military judge for Guantánamo’s war court found that the handling of classified information from secret prisons was deeply flawed, complicating the Cole case.
lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

headline: Turkey Vows to Send ISIS Militants Home
abstract: The interior minister declared that Turkey was “not a hotel” for captured Islamic State fighters as it began to pressure reluctant European states to take back their citizens.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey said Friday that it would begin sending captured Islamic State militants to their home countries in 72 hours, part of an effort aimed at pressuring reluctant European states to take back citizens recruited by the violent extremist group.

headline: McKinsey Faces Criminal Inquiry Over Bankruptcy Case Conduct
abstract: Prosecutors are examining the consulting company’s behavior in at least two bankruptcy cases.
lead_paragraph: McKinsey & Company, the elite consulting firm that advises many of the world’s largest and most powerful institutions, is facing a federal criminal investigation of its conduct advising bankrupt companies, according to five people familiar with the matter.

headline: A Billy Joel-Themed Look at the Knicks and the Nets
abstract: The N.B.A. season is off to a rough start in New York City, but there is reason for hope — really — no matter the borough.
lead_paragraph: Both N.B.A. teams in New York City are in transition right now — on and off the floor.

headline: Science Funds for Minority Colleges Become Political Football in the Senate
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Minority-serving colleges and universities are looking on helplessly as vital funding for their science, engineering and math programs are bogged down in the Senate morass.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal program to bolster science, mathematics and engineering at minority-serving colleges has been caught in a partisan tug of war in the Senate, where inaction and gridlock are starting to have real-world consequences.

headline: Where Michael Bloomberg Stands on the Issues
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Gun Control', 'Green New Deal', 'Income Tax', 'Racial Profiling', 'Search and Seizure', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Mr. Bloomberg has been an outspoken voice on gun control and climate change, but his views on taxes would put him on the conservative end of the Democratic field.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York and a billionaire, is likely to enter the Democratic presidential primary. Here’s a look at where he stands on some of the major issues in the race.

headline: Senate Democrats Face Their Own Risks Over Impeachment
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Elections, Senate', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: While Republicans get most of the attention, a Senate trial could complicate Democrats’ drive for the majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Senator Jeanne Shaheen, a New Hampshire Democrat seeking a third term next year in a traditional swing state, a vote on whether to oust President Trump months before they both face voters would be difficult under any circumstances.
