headline: Deval Patrick Makes a Late Bid in the 2020 Presidential Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Patrick, the former Massachusetts governor, entered the Democratic primary with less than three months to go before the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — There is almost no campaign staff or ground operation. Some volunteers mobilized on one day’s notice. The announcement video was not finished until the middle of the night, and an email with instructions for Day 1 was sent to a small inner circle at 2:48 a.m.

headline: ISIS Suspect Trapped at Turkish-Greek Border Is to Be Deported to U.S.
abstract: Turkey said it had received assurances from Washington that the American would not be refused entry.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey announced on Thursday that it would repatriate an American suspected of being a member of the Islamic State, after a commitment from the United States that his entry would not be blocked.

headline: ‘Radioflash’ Review: The Hills Have Spies
abstract: Ben McPherson’s generic survival story aims for post-apocalyptic dread and lands on hill-dweller horseplay.
lead_paragraph: “Radioflash” is selling itself as a survival thriller, which is half right. In truth, this “Deliverance”-style clash between Reese (Brighton Sharbino), a savvy teenager, and a passel of backwoods archetypes is only marginally more thrilling than the average wine tasting.

headline: ‘The Warrior Queen of Jhansi’ Review: Freedom Fighter
abstract: The gifted Devika Bhise and an unrecognizable Rupert Everett face off in this awkward, declamatory tribute to an inspirational Indian ruler.
lead_paragraph: Myth and history mesh in “The Warrior Queen of Jhansi,” an unfortunately clunky, relentlessly corny salute to Rani Laxmibai (Devika Bhise), the still-celebrated Indian ruler who joined the 1857 rebellion against the country’s British overseers.

headline: ‘The Good Liar’ Review: For Helen Mirren and Ian McKellen, the Truth Hurts
abstract: This thriller doesn’t need a spoiler warning. It spoils itself.
lead_paragraph: “The Good Liar” requires something stricter than a standard spoiler warning. To avoid ruining the film, you should not only stop reading this review, but also pass on seeing the movie, which tips its hand practically from the moment the main characters meet.

headline: ‘Scandalous’ Review: Riches From a Supermarket Rag
abstract: A documentary on the National Enquirer pays tribute to a halcyon era of dirt digging.
lead_paragraph: Shocker! Could even a tawdry supermarket tabloid be worthy of a gushy, nostalgic tribute? “Scandalous: The Untold Story of the National Enquirer,” a documentary from Mark Landsman, presents The Enquirer as an unlikely haven of bona fide shoe-leather journalism, or at the very least a fun place to work, until — in this telling — David J. Pecker became the owner and sullied a halcyon tradition of dirt digging.

headline: ‘To Kid or Not to Kid’ Review: Maybe, Baby
abstract: Maxine Trump’s deeply personal documentary explores the pros and cons of motherhood with candor and empathy.
lead_paragraph: If you can overlook the rather cumbersome title, Maxine Trump’s sophomore feature, “To Kid or Not to Kid,” has an appealingly scattered charm. Like the issue it obsesses over — whether or not she should have a child — this deeply personal documentary is messy, emotionally complicated and a magnet for strong opinions.

headline: ‘Recorder: The Marion Stokes Project’ Review: A VCR Obsession
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'News and News Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Matt Wolf’s documentary shows how one woman captured history by recording television news. The results are compelling.
lead_paragraph: Can one become a historian merely by pressing a button? The documentary “Recorder: The Marion Stokes Project” says yes. It also demonstrates that pressing a button is not such a mere thing.

headline: ‘I Lost My Body’ Review: The Quest of a Severed Hand
abstract: There is no shortage of imagination in this animated feature. In fact, there may be more than you can stomach.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of the unsettling animated feature “I Lost My Body,” a young man, Naoufel, lies on the ground covered in his own blood. From that traumatic moment on, his consciousness will be split into two perspectives.

headline: In Kentucky, a Governor Who Picked Fights Loses a Big One
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Matt Bevin, Kentucky’s sharp-elbowed governor conceded defeat after a recanvass of votes confirmed the victory of Andy Beshear, son of a two-term Democratic governor.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Ky. — For a governor who had invariably made the political personal, it was a pointedly personal outcome on Thursday when Gov. Matt Bevin of Kentucky bowed to the inevitable and conceded after a recanvass of votes showed clearly that the Democrat Andy Beshear would be the state’s next governor.

headline: The Clippers Lost, but the Dream Duo Is Coming
abstract: Sometime soon, Kawhi Leonard and Paul George will take the court at the same time.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Los Angeles Clippers have 71 games to go before the N.B.A. playoffs after Wednesday night’s fourth-quarter unraveling against the Houston Rockets.

headline: Social Climbing Has a Whole New Meaning
abstract: The nubbly fitness obsession that forces you to unplug and concentrate or — AAAAH!
lead_paragraph: On a Friday evening last spring, Zack Woodruff picked up two college friends and drove seven hours down Interstate 65: through Indianapolis, bourbon country and the rolling hills of Appalachia.

headline: Is This the End of ‘Days of Our Lives’?
abstract: Cast members of the long-running soap opera jumped in to counter rumors of the show’s demise. Its producers are currently in renewal talks with NBC.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the most dramatic scenes of a soap opera happen off-camera.

headline: Family to Get $10 Million After Death of Man Left in Jail Cell With a Broken Neck
abstract: An Oklahoma county agreed to pay the estate of Elliott Williams, whose complaints were ignored by members of the detention and medical staff for five days.
lead_paragraph: Elliott Williams tried to tell guards at an Oklahoma jail that he had broken his neck.

headline: Highways on Fire. Semesters Cut Short. A Recession. Can Hong Kong Heal?
abstract: Months of antigovernment protests and increasingly violent clashes with the police have upended daily life, with the potential to alter the city’s character.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Storefronts closed for weekend demonstrations are now shuttered, for weeks or even permanently. Protesters are occupying major roads, rail tracks, bridges and tunnels, cutting off critical thoroughfares for commuters and commerce on a daily basis. Universities are telling students not to come back for the rest of the semester.

headline: Smith & Wesson’s Owner to Break Away From Gun Business
abstract: The move separates the broader company from the challenges the gun industry faces. It was announced shortly before another mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: The gun-maker Smith & Wesson was once an iconic national brand, a symbol of Americana and rugged individualism dating back to the battlefields of the Civil War.

headline: Refugee and Author Detained by Australia Is Given Visa to Travel
abstract: Behrouz Boochani, who was held for years as part of Australia’s offshore immigration detention program, arrived in New Zealand for a literary festival.
lead_paragraph: A Kurdish-Iranian refugee and award-winning writer who was held by Australia for years at a detention center on a remote Pacific island arrived in New Zealand late Thursday, after becoming a cause célèbre for rights activists.

headline: Apple’s Reach Reshapes Medical Research
abstract: The company’s tools enable researchers to track huge numbers of people. But doctors do not yet know if it will significantly improve health outcomes.
lead_paragraph: In 1976, the Harvard School of Public Health and two other major medical institutions started a study on nurses that has become one of the largest and longest research efforts ever conducted on women’s health. They have so far enrolled more than 275,000 participants.

headline: It’s the Monthly Fees That Get You

abstract: Comparing home prices in New York City? Look hard at the common charges.

headline: Anything Goes in Berlin’s Clubs. But Are Bouncers Killing the Vibe?
abstract: Some partygoers say heavy-handed security staff and racist door policies are ruining the tolerant atmosphere of the city’s club scene.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Every weekend (and many weeknights), Berlin’s clubs open up as spaces where anything goes. Fetish wear, nudity and sex? No big deal. Closing times, sometimes days after the party started, are determined by how many records the D.J. has in their bag.

headline: Qatar Faces a Tight Squeeze for Its Compact World Cup
abstract: The tiny Gulf country will host the world’s biggest soccer tournament in 2022. But three years before the first match, organizers have concerns about where fans will sit and where they will sleep.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Since the day Qatar was named the host of the 2022 World Cup, it was obvious the tournament would be different from the ones that had preceded it.

headline: Eddie Murphy Will Star in ‘Beverly Hills Cop 4’ for Netflix
abstract: The comedy sequel is part of a continuing deal between the streaming giant and Paramount, a studio without a streaming service of its own.

headline: CMA Awards 2019: 5 Key Moments, From Kacey Musgraves to Kris Kristofferson
abstract: Nashville’s big night focused on women and genre legends, leaving Lil Nas X and his smash “Old Town Road” largely uncelebrated.
lead_paragraph: For the 53rd annual Country Music Association Awards, held Wednesday night at the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville, the organization made a pledge to celebrate “legendary women in country music throughout the ceremony” — though the topic of the industry’s much-criticized gender disparity would have been in the air regardless. But in a night of grand performances by the genre’s female leaders, something ended up pushed to the side: the year’s biggest country smash. Here are the show’s notable moments.

headline: New York to Use 18,000 City Workers to Identify and Help Homeless
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Three-One-One (311) (NYC Hot Line)', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing']
abstract: The effort is the latest attempt from Mayor Bill de Blasio to tackle street homelessness, an intractable problem throughout his administration.
lead_paragraph: New York City will direct more than 18,000 of its municipal workers to use 311 to give social service workers real-time information to help them steer the almost 4,000 people who live on the streets into shelters.

headline: ‘The Hottest August’ Review: Ordinary New Yorkers Facing Extreme Heat
abstract: The director draws on texts from Zadie Smith, Annie Dillard and Karl Marx for narration, but ospreys and a solar eclipse take more of a center stage.
lead_paragraph: This documentary, for all of its considerable discrete moments and insights, is most fascinating because of its vivid demonstration of how the future is never really as we expect it to be.

headline: A Sprawling Menu and Goan Cuisine at Cardamom in Queens
abstract: The chef at this Indian restaurant offers dishes from across the subcontinent.
lead_paragraph: At Cardamom, an Indian restaurant in Sunnyside, Queens, aromatic green pods of cardamom — one of the world’s most expensive spices, alongside saffron and vanilla — flavor everything from basmati rice to dessert. But for the chef Alwyn Gudhino, naming his restaurant was partly about phonetics. “Mom is the last three letters,” he said, spelling it out. “I miss my mom, so I said, ‘Let me use this name.’”

headline: The Most Watched Show at the Office? Sexual Harassment Training Videos

headline: Germany Mandates Measles Vaccine
keywords: ['Measles', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Politics and Government', 'Epidemics', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: All children attending preschool or higher in the country must be immunized, with fines for parents who do not comply, under a law that is to take effect next spring.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Parents in Germany must vaccinate their children against measles or face fines of several thousand euros under a law passed on Thursday that aims to stop the spread of a disease that has returned in recent years after decades of decline.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 20, 2019
abstract: What story do these graphs tell about greenhouse gas emissions in the United States?
lead_paragraph: These graphs of carbon dioxide emissions in the United States by sector and by type of transportation originally appeared elsewhere on NYTimes.com.

headline: Around Milos, Swimming the Aegean Sea
abstract: One writer explores the Greek island, discovering not just volcanic caves or ancient ruins but also a deeper connection to the past.
lead_paragraph: I FLOAT INSIDE a cave, deep beneath the white volcanic beach of Sarakiniko. With each surge of the waves, my head rises unnervingly close to the rock ceiling. I dive beneath the water’s surface, kick deeper, allow myself to be pulled out through the cave’s mouth. The sharp green sea grass waves 30 feet below, the surface a roiling mirror overhead.

headline: How Did Plants Conquer Land? These Humble Algae Hold Clues
keywords: ['ALGAE', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Bacteria', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Flowers and Plants', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Two algal species share important genes with all modern land plants, a new analysis finds.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever noticed a slimy film of algae on a rock, chances are you didn’t pay it much attention. But some of these overlooked species hold clues to one of the greatest mysteries of evolution, scientists have found: how plants arrived on land.

headline: The Brief and Inspiring Life of James Le Mesurier
abstract: The British humanitarian accomplished enormous feats in alleviating the suffering of civilians in Syria.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, James Le Mesurier, the founder of Mayday Rescue, a charity that supported and trained the White Helmets, the Syrian civil defense group, was found dead in Istanbul. His body was found outside a building in the Beyoglu district where he had an apartment and office. It is unclear whether Mr. Le Mesurier, who was 48 and healthy, fell or was pushed from the balcony of his apartment. The Turkish authorities have started an investigation.

headline: Out of Africa, a Collection and a Dedication to Giving Back
abstract: Mercedes Vilardell fell in love with the art when she visited Malick Sidibé’s studio. Now she travels to Africa several times a year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As a philanthropist and as a collector, Mercedes Vilardell has distinguished herself by her focus. In the former arena, there is a consistent mission; in the latter, a tight aesthetic.

headline: Student Kills 2 at California High School
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Santa Clarita, Calif, Shooting (2019)']
abstract: A suspect was in custody after a shooting at a high school north of Los Angeles, the police said. They said the suspect was a student and he carried out the attack on his birthday.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old student pulled a handgun from his backpack at a high school in Santa Clarita, Calif., on Thursday morning and shot five students, killing two, the authorities said. The gunman was in grave condition after shooting himself in the head, they said.

headline: A Black Hole Threw a Star Out of the Milky Way Galaxy
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Sagittarius A*', 'Milky Way Galaxy', 'Solar System', 'Black Holes (Space)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: So long, S5-HVS1, we hardly knew you.
lead_paragraph: There are fastballs, and then there are cosmic fastballs. Now it seems that the strongest arm in our galaxy might belong to a supermassive black hole that lives smack in the middle of the Milky Way.

headline: North Korea Says U.S. Sought More Talks, but Calls It a ‘Trick’
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The top North Korean envoy to the negotiations with Washington said he was not interested unless the United States was ready to make substantial concessions.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Thursday that the United States had proposed resuming talks on denuclearization in December, but warned that Pyongyang was not interested unless Washington was ready to meet its terms. And a top envoy said he believed the proposal was merely “a trick to earn time.”

headline: And Now the Easy Part: Selecting Thanksgiving Wines
abstract: Good wines for the long haul of the holiday feast can come from anywhere in the world. Plan on a white and a red, and plenty of both.
lead_paragraph: For more than 15 years, the wine panel has been celebrating Thanksgiving early. We gather over a representative holiday meal to examine how a variety of wines will fare at the feast.

headline: Trump and the Military: A Dysfunctional Marriage, but They Stay Together
abstract: The Pentagon is learning how to work with a president whose orders can whipsaw by the hour.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Days after President Trump’s abrupt decision to withdraw 1,000 American troops from Syria, Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, saw a way to turn it around.

headline: Gaetano Pesce Adds ‘Performance Artist’ to His Portfolio
abstract: Like Geppetto in his workshop, the Italian design iconoclast “performs” a chair in New York, complemented by a show of rarely seen works in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: From immersive art in pop-up storefronts to operas at the Met, performances in New York come in many forms. Recently, Gaetano Pesce — the 79-year-old, Italian-born, perennial enfant terrible of iconoclastic design — performed a chair.

headline: In Praise of Jennifer Nettles’s Equal Play Pants
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'COUNTRY MUSIC ASSN AWARDS', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Her red carpet style at the Country Music Awards did the talking for her. Others should follow her example.
lead_paragraph: Back in January 2018, the Golden Globes’ all-black fashion moment in support of the Time’s Up movement briefly seemed to hold so much promise as a flexion point in red carpet dressing.

headline: Trump’s Choice: National Security or Political Obsession
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The impeachment inquiry is the first to involve an issue of geopolitical gravity: Whether the president was undercutting American national interests — containing Russia — to bolster his campaign.
lead_paragraph: The last two impeachment investigations of the past half-century began with a third-rate burglary and an extramarital affair. They quickly expanded to question the credibility and ethics of the president, but never touched on America’s national interests in the weightiest geopolitical confrontations of their eras.

headline: Why a ‘Republican Economist’ Plans to Vote in the Democratic Primary
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Medicare']
abstract: The Harvard economist N. Gregory Mankiw, once an adviser to Republican leaders, has been disappointed by Trump. Here’s what he’s seeking in economic policy.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I drove to my local city hall and changed my voter registration from Republican to independent. That was a momentous change for me, a lifelong Republican.

headline: ‘The Report’ Review: Inconvenient Truths
abstract: Adam Driver’s gracefully intelligent performance as an investigator never quite zaps this dramatically frozen procedural to life.
lead_paragraph: The very title of “The Report” lays out the movie’s most daunting challenge: How do you engage, never mind excite, an audience with sheafs of classified documents, vaultlike work spaces and reams of expository dialogue — chunks of it delivered by impassive men in identical gray suits? Well, you could start by giving Adam Driver the starring role, hiring Jon Hamm to lope in and out of otherwise stagnant scenes, and threading shocking flashbacks through the more arid patches.

headline: Twin Girls, Born in Budapest, Navigate Modern Times
abstract: Newly restored, Ildiko Enyedi’s confident debut feature, “My 20th Century,” is a sparkling Hungarian fable of theft, anarchy and electric light.
lead_paragraph: “My 20th Century” — a first feature by Ildiko Enyedi, made in the waning days of Hungarian Communism — looked back to the last fin-de-siècle even as it heralded a new beginning.

headline: Why Voters Don’t Seem Interested in Barrier-Breaking Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Indian-Americans', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Julián Castro and Kamala Harris are pitching themselves partially on being a ‘first,’ but neither is gaining traction.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Julián Castro’s fund-raising appeal last month was blunt. “Tragic mistake,” the subject line read, emphatically written in all capital letters. “Only Latino candidate could be cut from debate stage.”

headline: A ‘Circus’ or an ‘Education’: How Impeachment Is Playing on the Radio
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Radio', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Americans heard the first public testimony in the Ukraine inquiry, some turned to talk radio shows with reactions.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — They all watched the same hearing. They just saw it differently. Very differently.

headline: Review: A Conductor and Soprano Test Wagnerian Waters
abstract: Gianandrea Noseda led Christine Goerke and the National Symphony Orchestra in Act II of “Tristan und Isolde.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A lot was at stake for the soprano Christine Goerke and the conductor Gianandrea Noseda on Wednesday, when they performed Act II of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” in concert here with the National Symphony Orchestra.

headline: The Tropical Conclave Where Politicians and Lobbyists Go to Make Deals
abstract: “More business happens here in one weekend than in three months in City Hall or in Albany,” one attendee said of the spring-break-like event in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — It was 11 p.m. on the Friday after Election Day, and two likely candidates to be New York City’s next mayor — Corey Johnson, the Council speaker, and Ruben Diaz Jr., the Bronx borough president — were deep in conversation under purple-lit palms outside a beachfront hotel.

headline: This Is Not a Game
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: The first public hearing in the impeachment proceedings was sad, yet necessary.

headline: James Wiseman Drops Lawsuit Against Memphis and the N.C.A.A. and Will Sit
abstract: The university said the prospect who could be the top pick in the N.B.A. draft next year will not play while his eligibility case over moving expenses is considered.
lead_paragraph: James Wiseman, expected to be a top pick in the N.B.A. draft next June, dropped a lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. on Thursday and will be ineligible to play for the University of Memphis while the N.C.A.A. reviews the school’s appeal of his eligibility.

headline: ‘Atlantics’ Review: Haunted by Ghosts and Injustice in Senegal
abstract: Mati Diop’s Cannes prize winner is a potent mix of genres and moods.
lead_paragraph: In its first scenes, “Atlantics,” the French-Senegalese director Mati Diop’s remarkable debut feature, slides gracefully between moods and genres, teasing the viewer’s assumptions about what kind of film it might be. Construction workers demand their unpaid wages and then ride home empty-handed in the open bed of a pickup truck. One of them, Souleiman (Ibrahima Traoré), meets his girlfriend, Ada (Mama Sané), in an abandoned building near the beach. They kiss, they argue and she goes off with her friends, not all of whom get along with one another.

headline: Pelosi Points to Possible Bribery Charge Against Trump
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Impeachment', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The day after the first public impeachment hearing, Speaker Nancy Pelosi used the word “bribery,” mentioned in the Constitution’s impeachment clause, to describe President Trump’s conduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi sharpened the focus of Democrats’ impeachment case against President Trump on Thursday, accusing the president of committing bribery when he withheld vital military assistance from Ukraine at the same time he was seeking its commitment to publicly investigate his political rivals.

headline: After Its Merger, Gannett Will Be the Largest Newspaper Publisher in the U.S.
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Shareholders approved a deal to combine GateHouse Media, which has received SoftBank funding, with the publisher of USA Today.
lead_paragraph: Roughly one in four newspapers in the United States has closed since 2004, and many that managed to survive have been cut to the bone. Now, more than 260 dailies will be controlled by the same company.

headline: A Guide to Milos, a Greek Island With Fewer Crowds and More Beaches
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restaurants', 'Swimming', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: Often overlooked in favor of its flashier neighbors, Mykonos and Santorini, the small volcanic isle offers a more peaceful way to experience the Aegean.
lead_paragraph: Milos, the southernmost of the sun-baked Cyclades islands off mainland Greece, is a volcanic oasis home to picturesque whitewashed villages and hidden cliff-ringed coves. Formed around a central caldera and characterized by lunar-like rock formations, it has the highest concentration of beaches in the entire island group — and yet, it’s delightfully untrodden compared to its more famous neighbors, Santorini and Mykonos. It was once a critical location for the mineral trade — during the Neolithic period, the ancient Minoans exported Milos’s obsidian to the neighboring Aegean island of Crete, whose residents used the volcanic glass to make weapons — but the island is best known because of an event from more recent history. It was while digging near the Roman amphitheater in Klima, in 1820, that the amateur archaeologist Olivier Voutier discovered the marble statue known as the “Venus de Milo.” The celebrated work now lives at the Louvre in Paris, but Milos’s mystique remains intact. Thanks to its serene fishing villages, secluded caves, innumerable swimming beaches (many accessible only by boat) and an abundance of locally run restaurants offering fresh catch and regional Greek wines, this tranquil island is quickly gaining appeal for travelers who want Aegean charm without the crowds.

headline: ‘Waves’ Review: The Shattering Ebb and Flow of Family Life
abstract: The writer-director Trey Edward Shults tells the story of a family held together by love and nearly undone by tragedy.
lead_paragraph: The camera doesn’t just move in “Waves,” it hurtles with terrific urgency. As you’re swept up in the immersive motion, the kinetic energy, you notice the passing beauty of the images, their compositional elegance. Mostly, though, you just try to keep up as voices boom and the camera pushes in, pulls out, flows in circles or sprints forward. This great whoosh creates a contact high even if, as one shot rapidly gives way to another, it feels as if time is running out.

headline: ‘Lady and the Tramp’ Review: Seconds of Spaghetti and Furballs
abstract: Disney’s latest live-action remake is sweet and tastefully rendered, but it lacks the liveliness of the animated original.
lead_paragraph: “Lady and the Tramp” is the fourth live-action remake of an animated Disney hit to come out this year. Unlike “Dumbo,” “Aladdin” and “The Lion King,” however, this latest offering is going straight to streaming as part of the inaugural slate on the new Disney Plus service.

headline: When ‘Incorrigible’ Teen Girls Were Jailed
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Criminal Justice']
abstract: At 15, my grandmother was locked up alongside young women committed for “immorality.” Her story taught me about a little-known history.
lead_paragraph: In 1932, at the age of 12, my maternal grandmother, a talented young singer, was a victim of sexual abuse. By the time she was 15, she was performing in a Minneapolis nightclub to earn money to help her family survive. It was the Depression, and she was the youngest daughter of a widowed mother, a Norwegian immigrant seamstress.

headline: I’m No Doctor, but My Sister Definitely Has Autism
abstract: Our advice columnist explains to a reader the trouble with armchair diagnoses.
lead_paragraph: My sister is in her 50s. She suffers (and has benefited) from autism spectrum disorder. It’s given her brilliance at the expense of social functioning. Sadly, she is not aware of her A.S.D. or formally diagnosed. But she gets furious if anyone challenges her; she is unable to forgive small slights and doesn’t perceive other people’s intentions correctly. I think she would benefit from understanding her condition, but she brushed off my suggestion that she is on the spectrum. Meanwhile, she is alienating herself from our family with her behavior. I feel like shouting: “You have Asperger’s! Embrace it!” How can we fix this situation?

headline: Keith Haring’s Stairwell Mural Auctioned for $3.9 Million
abstract: An anonymous buyer purchased the piece, painted on the walls of a Manhattan youth center. It is unclear where the work will end up.
lead_paragraph: It took Keith Haring one evening in the early 1980s — and zero planning — to paint an 85-foot mural up the walls of a Catholic youth center stairwell on Manhattan’s Upper West Side.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: There’s a funny moment in Kevin Wilson’s new novel, “Nothing to See Here” — it’s one of two novels we recommend this week — in which a 10-year-old girl tells her new caretaker that she loves reading but had nothing good to choose from at her grandparents’ house, where she and her twin brother had been living. “What did they have?” her caretaker asks, and the girl answers: “Books about World War II. Two different books about Hitler. Wait, four books about Hitler. And other books about Nazis. And books about Stalin. Patton. People like that.”

headline: ‘Everybody’s Everything’ Review: The Life and Songs of Lil Peep
abstract: The documentary looks and listens to the emo-rapper, who died two years ago following an accidental overdose.
lead_paragraph: Tales of musicians crushed by fame and drugs have, regrettably, become common to the point of cliché. Yet something feels especially sad about the death of Lil Peep after an accidental overdose in 2017 at 21. The documentary “Everybody’s Everything” is steeped in that sadness, even as it celebrates the rapper’s life.

headline: Review: Perfume Genius and Kate Wallich in a World of Angst
abstract: In “The Sun Still Burns Here,” a musician and a choreographer moodily unite, but the result is far from transcendent.
lead_paragraph: It’s happened again. A musician, lured by the nonverbal language of movement, has given dance a not-so-casual try. Mike Hadreas, who goes by the stage name of Perfume Genius, is serious about unleashing his inner dancer — so much so that he teamed up with the choreographer Kate Wallich to create “The Sun Still Burns Here,” an evening-length work in which he sings and dances. Ms. Wallich, who also performs in the work, did the choreography; Mr. Hadreas composed the plaintive music. (They directed together.)

headline: Another of Alberto Salazar’s Runners Says He Ridiculed Her Body for Years
keywords: ['Coaches and Managers', 'Weight', 'Running', 'Track and Field', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Amy Yoder Begley says she was criticized for being overweight, told her laugh was annoying and made to sign a contract promising not to become friends with her teammates.
lead_paragraph: For Amy Yoder Begley, an Olympic middle-distance runner, four tumultuous years with Alberto Salazar’s Nike Oregon Project came to an abrupt end in September 2011.

headline: These Artists Refuse to Forget the Wars in Iraq
abstract: A powerful new show at MoMA PS1, featuring artists from the U.S. and the Persian Gulf, revisits two conflicts most Americans have tuned out.
lead_paragraph: Over the last month, Iraqis fed up with corruption and unemployment have staged the country’s largest protests since the fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003. Hundreds of them have died at the hands of national security forces. The Iraq conflict is still going on — and yet the country has largely disappeared from America’s news broadcasts, social media streams and campaign trails.

lead_paragraph: Who keeps your town running while you sleep?

lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, we asked you what you wanted to know about California’s gaping economic inequality, and many of you raised questions about homelessness.

headline: Here’s a List of School Shootings in 2019
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The attack at Oshkosh West High School in Wisconsin on Dec. 3 is at least the 13th this year on a high school or college campus, which have resulted in at least six deaths.
lead_paragraph: Across the country this year, according to media reports, at least 11 shootings have taken place on American high school or college campuses, including the attack in Santa Clarita, Calif., on Thursday. And school officials and law enforcement agencies have responded to dozens more credible threats of attacks.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Sports Blowouts, Laughing at Others’ Pain, and Dream Homes
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Last week was The Learning Network’s first-ever “Review Week,” a week when we published the many pieces of our writing curriculum’s unit on review writing. The unit includes five new mentor texts and our fifth annual student review contest — plus four new writing prompts about reviews.

headline: Comedian Hospitalized for Depression. Hilarity Ensues.
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Gary Gulman is showing us how to bring our inner selves out into the open.
lead_paragraph: If I were a comedy obsessive, I would already have known about the sneaky genius of Gary Gulman. He’s got a devoted following, a winning smile, a corkscrew imagination; in 2016, when he did a six-minute bit on “Conan” about how the states got their two-letter abbreviations, it became a viral sensation, pure catnip for nerds.

headline: Put the Vandalized Emmett Till Signs in Museums
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Vandalism', 'Signs and Signage', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes', 'Museums']
abstract: They convey the truth more completely than the pristine signs by refusing us the comfort of believing that racism is a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming something of a cycle. Every time a new sign is erected to mark the spot where, in 1955, Emmett Till’s body was pulled from the Tallahatchie River in Mississippi, the sign gets vandalized, it gets replaced and it gets vandalized again. And replaced again.

abstract: The United Nations is investigating attacks on seven humanitarian sites in Syria. Diplomats say Russia is trying to keep the U.N. findings secret.
lead_paragraph: The aerial bombings of hospitals in rebel areas of Syria have long stood out as possible war crimes, so brazen that the leader of the United Nations ordered a special inquiry three months ago, raising hope of some accountability.

headline: Peas, Socks and Sidewalk-Trash Sculptures: Just Keep Looking
abstract: Rachel Harrison’s midcareer survey at the Whitney Museum includes pieces that defy description. You feel things will come clear if you just hang out longer. And people do.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday there was strong foot traffic on the fifth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art where the New York artist Rachel Harrison’s exuberant midcareer survey is installed. And the traffic wasn’t moving fast. Visitors were spending time with sculpture that, despite — or because of — its enigmatic zaniness, inspired a slow look. And people seemed to be having fun looking, even if they weren’t exactly sure why.

abstract: Gazella Bensreiti said she was at the Pepsi Center to watch her daughter sing the national anthem. The company that owns the venue reportedly said it was a misunderstanding.
lead_paragraph: A Muslim woman said she was discriminated against before an N.B.A. game in Denver when she was told that she had to remove her hijab.

headline: ‘Ernie & Joe: Crisis Cops’ Review: Keeping Calm Is Their Secret Weapon
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Jenifer McShane’s documentary introduces an empathetic method for policing.
lead_paragraph: “Ernie & Joe: Crisis Cops,” Jenifer McShane’s nonfiction portrait of two officers working in the San Antonio police department’s mental health unit, arrives at a time of continued debate about what constitutes excessive policing. For Ernie Stevens and Joe Smarro, the goal is to defuse potentially violent encounters with the mentally ill and steer them into treatment instead of jail.

headline: American-Born Woman Who Joined ISIS Is Not a Citizen, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Diplomatic Immunity', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A surprise ruling from the bench is a blow to a bid to bring Hoda Muthana and her 2-year-old son, the child of a slain ISIS fighter, back from a refugee camp in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled on Thursday that Hoda Muthana, an American-born woman who joined the Islamic State in 2014 and says she now wants to return home to her family in Alabama, is not an American citizen.

headline: Netflix to Amend Maps After Complaint From Poland
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Maps', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: The company will add a note to some maps in the documentary series “The Devil Next Door” clarifying that death camps located in modern-day Poland were run by Nazi Germany.
lead_paragraph: Days after public criticism from Poland’s prime minister, Netflix said that it will modify some of the maps shown in the new documentary series, “The Devil Next Door,” to clarify that concentration camps shown within the boundaries of modern-day Poland were built and operated by Nazi Germany.

headline: Sanders’s Climate Ambitions Thrill Supporters. Experts Aren’t Impressed.
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Green New Deal', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Bernie Sanders' plan to tackle climate change would nationalize power plants and end fossil fuels. His supporters are thrilled. Climate experts are not.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders’s $16 trillion vision for arresting global warming would put the government in charge of the power sector and promise that, by 2030, the country’s electricity and transportation systems would run entirely on wind, solar, hydropower or geothermal energy, with the fossil fuel industry footing much of the bill much as Mexico was to pay for the border wall.

headline: The Razr’s Back, Flipping Open an Old Love Story
abstract: Tapping into nostalgia, Motorola announced the return of the sleek foldable phone. Some praised the update, while others sneered at the $1,500 price.
lead_paragraph: Everything old is new again, sort of. Television shows from decades ago are getting the reboot treatment. Animated films from yesteryear are back in theaters with a digital makeover. And now the Razr, the unmistakable slim flip phone from the 2000s, has returned, hoping to ride the fad for foldable tech back into people’s pockets.

headline: Here Are Good Ways Yoga Teachers Manage Touch and Consent
abstract: We heard from readers about local yoga studios addressing touch, communication and consent.
lead_paragraph: “There might be no grayer gray zone than a yoga studio, where physical intimacy, spirituality and power dynamics all come together in a sweaty little room,” Katherine Rosman, a New York Times reporter, said on the latest episode of “The Weekly,” our new TV show.

headline: Notre Dame’s Football Sellout Streak Ending at 273 Games
abstract: The streak at Notre Dame Stadium dated to Thanksgiving Day in 1973. The stadium holds nearly 78,000 fans.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 46 years, there will be empty seats at a Notre Dame home football game.

headline: A Designer’s Satisfying, Adaptable Year-Round Salad
abstract: Gabriel Hendifar of the New York lighting and design studio Apparatus describes himself as an “assembler” — perfect for working with fresh vegetables.
lead_paragraph: In One Good Meal, we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: Boris Johnson Was Supposed to Be an Ace Campaigner. So Why Is He Stumbling?
abstract: Exposed to hostile voices on the campaign trail, he has seemed at times unsure, tone deaf and gaffe prone. It could leave an opening for the underdog Labour Party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For months, Prime Minister Boris Johnson planned on calling a general election in Britain, figuring he could break the logjam in Parliament by taking his case for Brexit directly to the people. Instead, as he has floundered in the early stages of the campaign, Mr. Johnson has discovered that the people are taking their case to him.

headline: Dr. Wayne Bardin, 85, Innovative Researcher on Birth Control, Dies
abstract: He helped develop long-acting implanted contraceptive devices — like Norplant, Jadelle and Mirena — used by millions of women around the world.
lead_paragraph: Dr. C. Wayne Bardin, a groundbreaking researcher in reproductive physiology, who was instrumental in the development of long-acting contraceptive methods — like Norplant, Jadelle and Mirena — used by millions of women around the world, died on Oct. 10 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Stephanie Parze’s Car Is at Home. So Is Her Phone. But She’s Missing.
abstract: The 25-year-old woman from Freehold Township, N.J., has been missing since the night before Halloween.
lead_paragraph: Her car was in the driveway. Her phone was on the couch. Her dog was running around. Everything about Stephanie Parze’s home in New Jersey, her father says, seemed undisturbed — except that she was not there.

keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Having stooped low to protect the president, administration officials are vulnerable to one another.

headline: How to Build a 2020 Campaign in Less Than 90 Days: Deval Patrick Edition
abstract: Mr. Patrick, the former governor of Massachusetts, announced on Thursday his intention to run for president a mere three months before the Iowa caucuses. Here’s what he needs to do next.
lead_paragraph: So Deval Patrick has declared he is running for president. Now comes the hard part: actually running for president.

headline: A-Rod Didn't Want It, So Marilyn Minter Had to Buy It
abstract: The artist and photographer talks about her favorite piece of heartbreaking art.
lead_paragraph: The artist and photographer talks about her favorite piece of heartbreaking art.

headline: Noel Ignatiev, 78, Persistent Voice Against White Privilege, Dies
abstract: In the journal Race Traitor and in a provocative book, Dr. Ignatiev argued that the white race should, in a sense, be abolished.
lead_paragraph: Noel Ignatiev, a provocative scholar who argued that the idea of a white race is a false construct that society would be better off without, died on Nov. 9in Tucson, Ariz., where he was visiting a family member. He was 78.

headline: An Artist Who Makes Absurdist Paintings in a Former Church
abstract: Calvin Marcus’s color-washed works, which feature surfers, bodybuilders and dead fish, defy narrative.
lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, daylight sifts into Calvin Marcus’s studio through panes of pastel-stained glass set in lancet windows. The San Francisco-born artist has lived and worked in this cavernous former synagogue turned Baptist church, constructed in 1928, since May. He found the property in 2016, by which time unknown years of neglect had led to severe structural damage. Nevertheless, “I had a vision for how it could be a great studio,” Marcus said recently, ahead of the opening of his current solo show, “Go Hang a Salami Im a Lasagna Hog,” at David Kordansky Gallery. During a painstaking three-year renovation, he transformed the building’s mezzanine level into a private living space for himself, his girlfriend and their two dogs (Bill, a giant schnauzer, and Francis, a small mutt), while the vast ground floor is now a studio with towering exposed wood-beam ceilings. There’s ample room for both dogs to blow off steam, and for Marcus, 31, to make the unexpected, often absurd paintings and mixed-media sculptures for which he’s known.

headline: The Kentucky Governor’s Race Was Close. Some Have Been Much Closer.
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Some were resolved with statesmanship and others were fought tooth and nail. Here is how some of the closest governor’s races in the nation’s history turned out.
lead_paragraph: For a while, Kentucky seemed headed for a lengthy partisan battle over its election for governor. Matt Bevin, the Republican incumbent, had finished about 5,000 votes behind his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Andy Beshear, and refused to concede; he began talking about voting irregularities, and demanded a recanvass of the county tallies.

headline: Andrew Yang: Yes, Robots Are Stealing Your Job
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Self-driving trucks will be great for the G.D.P. They’ll be terrible for millions of truck drivers.
lead_paragraph: During the last Democratic debate, in Ohio, there was a moment that stood out. Elizabeth Warren and I got into a debate over the impact of automation versus trade on the elimination of manufacturing jobs. Joe Biden also chimed in, agreeing that the fourth industrial revolution is costing jobs, so it’s important to deal with the root causes.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?

keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

lead_paragraph: A South Carolina teenager who in 2016, at age 14, killed his father before driving to an elementary school and fatally shooting a 6-year-old boy and injuring two other people was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison without parole.

headline: James I. Robertson Jr., Exacting Civil War Historian, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Robertson, who wrote or edited dozens of books, was best known for his monumental biography of Stonewall Jackson.
lead_paragraph: James I. Robertson Jr., an authority on the Civil War who published several dozen deeply researched books that humanized historical figures like Stonewall Jackson, died on Nov. 2 at a hospital in Richmond, Va. He was 89.

headline: After Reports of Astros’ Cheating, M.L.B. Is Left to Restore Trust
abstract: Pitcher Mike Fiers broke a code of silence among players by reporting the Astros’ sign-stealing, forcing baseball to reckon with an issue that has deep roots in the sport.
lead_paragraph: A.J. Hinch was defiant before Game 4 of the American League Championship Series at Yankee Stadium last month. Hinch, the manager of the Houston Astros, denied reports that his team had been relaying catchers’ signs by whistling from the bench during the series opener in Houston. He was especially upset that the reports were based on anonymous sources.

headline: Iraqi Protesters Cheer Victory Over Iran, at Least on the Soccer Field
abstract: The police and the politicians joined protesters in celebrating Iraq’s defeat of Iran in a World Cup qualifying match. Tensions between the countries are running high.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The protesters massed and shouted against Iran again on Thursday in Baghdad’s Tahrir Square and elsewhere, much as they have done over the past six weeks. But this time they were shouting with euphoria.

headline: Review: ‘Slava’s Snowshow’ Delivers Flurries of Joy
abstract: A critic who once resisted the charms of this holiday clownfest found herself floating on happiness this time around.
lead_paragraph: The clown incursion began as a stealth operation, first with one and then another peering tentatively out at us from the wings. Intermission music was still playing, and the audience still milling, as the clowns assembled, until gradually a whole pack of them (a gaggle? a murder? a herd?) stood at the lip of the stage, gazing quizzically at us.

headline: Message From Pro-Booker Super PAC: We Don’t Need More Candidates. We Have Cory.
abstract: With Cory Booker’s campaign still struggling to break through, a new super PAC has emerged from the swamps of Jersey to support him.

Its message: We don’t need more candidates, we’ve got Cory.

keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Santa Clarita, Calif, Shooting (2019)', 'Firearms']

lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARITA, Calif. — Frantic parents texted with teenagers barricaded in classrooms. Others offered shelter to students fleeing their high school in this sleepy suburb north of Los Angeles on Thursday. It was the latest example of a wrenching sequence that has become a recurring nightmare for families in America.

headline: Carrie Saxon Perry, Barrier-Breaking Mayor, Dies at 87
abstract: The first African-American woman to run a major New England city, Hartford, she died a year ago, but the death was reported only recently.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Saxon Perry, the first African-American woman to lead a major New England city as the mayor of Hartford and a civil rights advocate who had rubbed shoulders with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Jesse Jackson, has died at 87.

headline: Emails Outline Anti-Immigration Group’s Connection to Stephen Miller
abstract: A new batch of leaked emails illustrates the degree to which Mr. Miller used a think tank’s work to shape coverage at Breitbart News and policy at the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stephen Miller, President Trump’s hard-line immigration adviser, has long relied on data produced by the Center for Immigration Studies, a right-leaning think tank, to shape policy at the White House. Shortly after Mr. Trump was elected, Mr. Miller became well-known in the West Wing for putting printouts of studies published by the group on the president’s desk.

headline: Two Days Before Louisiana Governor’s Race, Trump Pleads for Win
abstract: President Trump is in Louisiana two days before the election hoping to break open a deadlocked race between the Democratic incumbent and the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: BOSSIER CITY, La. — President Trump urged Louisiana voters on Thursday to “send a message to the corrupt Democrats in Washington” by electing to governor the Republican nominee, Eddie Rispone, directly linking the impeachment inquiry to a state election that will test his clout in the Deep South.

abstract: A little care can make your sneakers last for the long haul.

And while many of our sneakers can look a little better a bit banged up (Chuck Taylors, hello!), there are times when — for the sake of appearances or smells — your sneakers need a cleaning. (And, for a visual step-by-step guide on how to wash your sneakers, click here.)

Constructors typically place one very lively entry near each corner and, if possible, one in the middle, so no matter where you are solving, there is at least one showstopper.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: Santa Claus and Sonny Liston
abstract: An animated Santa origin story hits Netflix. And a boxing documentary airs on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: KLAUS (2019) Stream on Netflix. The abrupt drop in temperatures across the Eastern United States this week may make this animated Santa origin story uncomfortably relatable, as it is set on an island above the Arctic Circle. The movie centers on Jesper, a mailman voiced by Jason Schwartzman who partners with a hermitlike toymaker named Klaus (J.K. Simmons) to deliver trinkets to children on the island. It is the first feature directed by Sergio Pablos, an animator and screenwriter whose decades-long history working with Disney informs this movie’s look. “It all moves along so amiably, and offers such consistently delightful visuals, that the conventional plot points, up to and including an inevitable ‘but I can explain’ bit, are entirely digestible,” Glenn Kenny wrote in his review for The New York Times. “These clichés inhibit ‘Klaus’ from achieving instant-classic status, but the film is winning enough that it’s worth a place in a family Christmas-movie library (not that, as a Netflix offering, it will take up any physical space).”

headline: Arkady Renko Has Been Sent to Siberia. And He’s Fine With That.
abstract: Martin Cruz Smith’s latest Russian thriller leads off Marilyn Stasio’s Crime column, which also includes a new Jack Reacher novel from Lee Child.
lead_paragraph: If this is a Martin Cruz Smith mystery, we must be in Moscow, maybe in Gorky Park. But in a thrilling change of pace, THE SIBERIAN DILEMMA (Simon & Schuster, $27) takes us out of the city and into Russia’s untamed wilderness in search of a journalist who’s gone missing while on a dangerous, perhaps foolhardy, assignment. The case is of special importance to Smith’s detective, Arkady Renko, because the reporter, Tatiana Petrovna, is his lover. Tatiana’s boss, Sergei Obolensky, publisher of the newsmagazine Russia Now, laughingly dismisses Arkady as an anxious boyfriend, but Arkady is well aware of the dangers facing Russian journalists. If it isn’t a cup of poisoned tea today, it could be a shot between the eyes tomorrow.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Vietnam’ and ‘Upstream’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: VIETNAM: An Epic Tragedy, 1945-1975, by Max Hastings. (Harper Perennial, $22.99.) Hastings, a British journalist and military historian who reported on the war, chronicles the conflict and its staggering destruction, excoriating both sides for corruption and inhumanity. The United States, he argues, failed most egregiously in not helping create a viable South Vietnam. Our reviewer, Mark Atwood Lawrence, called the book “monumental.”

headline: Behind Closed Doors in Washington, Here’s What Colleges Fight For
abstract: Think of them as College, Inc. Like most industries, higher education prefers less regulation (and accountability).
lead_paragraph: Anyone familiar with the back rooms of Washington politics knows about the industry associations. Staffed by lobbyists, these groups usually pursue different versions of the same agenda: ensuring their clients’ access to the public treasury while shielding them from public regulation. Energy companies lobby for lucrative write-offs on equipment and lax restrictions on pollution. Wall Street firms fight for the freedom to market risky financial products while paying low taxes on the profits. And so on.

headline: Hibernation Works for Bears. Could It Work for Us, Too?
abstract: A grizzly’s body can slow down for months without damage. Researchers wonder if the ability can be harnessed to aid human health.
lead_paragraph: There are three major seasons in the life of a bear: the active season, beginning in May; a period of intense eating, in late September, and hibernation, from January into spring.

headline: ‘The Report’ and the Untold Story of a Senate-C.I.A. Conflict

headline: Luxury for Less: The Travel Advisor Gambit
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Travel Agencies and Agents', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Spas', 'Credit Cards', 'Cruises']
abstract: When booking a high-end vacation, using a travel agency can mean scoring perks and benefits that would cost hundreds, at no cost to you.
lead_paragraph: After visiting the Grand Canyon with my 9-year-old daughter in August, I splurged on a two-night stay at the Enchantment Resort in Sedona, Ariz., to cap off our mother-daughter trip. Upon arrival, we were upgraded to a two-bedroom, two-bath suite with a kitchenette, a fireplace and dual balconies facing the breathtaking red rocks of Boynton Canyon — a significant boost from the $299-a-night double queen room we had reserved. Our complimentary daily breakfast could be taken in the room or at the hotel restaurant, a hotel receptionist informed us. And moments after a bellhop whisked us to our spacious suite in a golf cart, a room service attendant arrived with a fruit and cheese platter and a personalized welcome note.

headline: Should Students Be Punished for Not Having Lunch Money?
abstract: What should schools do if students are consistently unable to pay for lunch?
lead_paragraph: Is eating lunch at school a right that all students should be guaranteed, regardless of financial circumstance? Or should school lunch be made available only to those who can afford it? Do you think students should be punished if they cannot pay for lunch once? What if they cannot afford to pay for school lunches over multiple weeks?

headline: Raise Billions From Billionaires? Tax Experts Say It’s Not That Simple
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Income Tax', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Tax Shelters', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Income Inequality', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Name a tax and there’s a way to reduce it, delay it or not pay it. Financial advisers say a wealth tax would be no different.
lead_paragraph: One of the signature initiatives of Elizabeth Warren’s presidential campaign is a wealth tax that, she says, would pay for many of the programs she proposes, like government-paid health care and free college tuition. Bernie Sanders, one of her opponents in the Democratic race, has proposed his own version of a wealth tax that would collect, according to estimates, about $4 trillion over a 10-year period, or $500 billion more than Senator Warren’s plan.

But Mr. Booker acknowledged uncertain times ahead in the race, according to two people in attendance: Every time he turned around, Mr. Booker said, another candidate was ready to jump in.

abstract: Uproar on Instagram. Then, a frank conversation about race.
lead_paragraph: The display appeared in the windows of Daniela Rose’s townhouse in Clinton Hill before Halloween. Four cartoon figures, made of brown craft paper, were taped to the glass. Three wore nooses.

headline: At Howard University, Homecoming Is a Pilgrimage
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Historically Black Colleges and Universities']
abstract: “Coming to Howard for the first time was seeing the beauty of blackness,” one alumnus said.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever seen anything like this?” Ashley Maltbia-Burgess, a 2010 graduate of Howard University, asked. She was standing with a group of fellow alums and her wife, Ashlee, looking out onto the crowded campus lawn. “I always told my wife, you have to come here to believe this, to feel this energy.”

headline: She Grew Up on a Remote Italian Island. Then Came the Holocaust.
abstract: Recalling the once-vibrant Jewish life in prewar Rhodes, an island in the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, while researching the war years in Italy, I was introduced to Stella Levi, now 96, probably the only New Yorker among the handful of remaining members of the Jewish community of Rhodes, a now Greek island with a multinational past.

Her sister, the actor Clementine Ford-Wilcox, hoping to encourage her to move back to L.A., took Ms. Shepherd-Oppenheim to a nightclub in Hollywood to meet people in the local L.G.B.T.Q. community.

A spate of public hearings and private witness interviews with diplomats and White House officials should lay out the details of interactions between President Trump and his allies and the Ukrainian government that are at the center of a whistle-blower complaint.

headline: From Bolivia, Sad Lessons on How to Fix Semi-Democracies
abstract: The fall of Evo Morales is a reminder that fixing a flawed democracy may not always follow the democratic playbook.
lead_paragraph: For liberal democrats lamenting the trend toward democratic erosion worldwide, the collapse of Evo Morales’s administration in Bolivia on Sunday offers a glimmer of hope. At last checks were effectively placed on a government that tried to do away with all checks. That is the good news.

headline: Capitalism on Trial in Chile
abstract: America exported its economic system to the South American country after a coup. Nearly 50 years later, it’s a nation with staggering inequality — and destabilizing protests.

keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Republicans’ impeachment strategy? Storytelling.
lead_paragraph: I came to your house with a gun. At least imagine I did. I tied you to a chair, took a step back and repeatedly fired. But my arm twitched; every bullet missed. Meanwhile, you slipped your knots and fled.

headline: I’m Sorry, Is Impeachment Not Entertaining Enough for You?
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Boredom', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The desire for politics to entertain was one of the things that gave us President Trump.
lead_paragraph: By now, we have a good sense of the playbook Republicans follow when hit with revelations of new Trump administration misdeeds. First comes the heated denial: That never happened. Then, the qualifications: O.K., maybe something happened, but not the way the media says! Finally, the shifted goal post: O.K., it happened exactly the way the media says, but really, is that so bad?

headline: In Strike That Killed 5 Children, Israel Said It Took Out Gaza Militant. Now It Isn’t Sure.
abstract: The Israeli military said it has begun an investigation into who was actually killed in an airstrike that Palestinians said caused the deaths of eight civilians.
lead_paragraph: DEIR El-BALAH, Gaza Strip — Ismail al-Swarka was shaken from slumber after midnight on Thursday by what sounded like four missile blasts. Then he heard his neighbors screaming. What he found outside was horrifying: Eight of his relatives, including five children, had been killed in an airstrike, with several more badly wounded.

headline: Manchester City Appeal Rejected at CAS
abstract: City, the Premier League champion, had tried to block an investigation into its finances by appealing to sports’ highest court even before a punishment was handed down.
lead_paragraph: MONTREUX, Switzerland — An attempt by Manchester City to block an investigation into its finances and spending was rejected Friday by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which ruled that the club’s appeal was “inadmissible” because European soccer officials have not yet issued a ruling in the case.

Yovanovitch was an anonymous career diplomat who served in the kind of unglamorous posts — Kyrgyzstan, Armenia and eventually Ukraine — typically reserved for civil servants because political donors and friends of the president don’t covet them.

headline: A Victim Not Only of Unjust Laws, but of ‘Unjust Authorities’
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media', 'ABORTION']
abstract: An investigative reporter from a prominent Moroccan family was wrongly accused of having had an abortion. Now she wants to hold officials’ feet to the fire.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — When Hajar Raissouni, an investigative journalist with one of Morocco’s only independent news outlets, went to her doctor’s office last August seeking treatment for a vaginal hemorrhage, she was not planning on becoming the center of a national discussion on press freedom, abortion rights and what critics say is the nation’s antiquated penal code.

headline: N.F.L. Week 11 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread

While not exactly resetting expectations, these losses certainly added some spice to a season that was turning stale.

headline: FAFSA Says How Much You Can Pay for College. It’s Often Wrong.
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life', 'Income', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The form opens the door to student aid. But it’s “a terrible measure of what people can actually afford,” one expert said. And many families will be asked to pay more, anyway.
lead_paragraph: Like millions of other parents, Julie Phipps filled out the federal form last November that determined her college-bound daughter was eligible for financial aid. She also learned how much the federal government figured her family could contribute to the bill: $14,000.

headline: Taylor Swift Escalates Battle With Scooter Braun and Big Machine
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Social Media', 'AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: The singer said in a post on Tumblr that her old label was blocking her use of certain songs, and she asked her fans to get involved.
lead_paragraph: After a few months of public détente, a bitter fight between some of the music industry’s most powerful figures was ratcheted up again on Thursday night when Taylor Swift called on her fervent army of fans to express their displeasure with the men she said were controlling her most recognizable music.

headline: Conrad Tao Was Never Just Another Prodigy
abstract: Whipping between the establishment and the avant-garde, this pianist and composer is a rising star at 25.
lead_paragraph: Conrad Tao tends to slip into celestial metaphors. During a recent interview, this musician — a veteran at just 25 — referred to his ideas about concert programming as “constellatory.” When he thought he was rambling, he cut himself off and apologized for “galaxy-braining.”

headline: 7 Podcasts for the Movie Buff
abstract: Whether you’re looking to keep up with the Oscar contenders, understand the changing business or dive into Hollywood history, there’s a show for you.
lead_paragraph: Fall is both the best and busiest time to be a movie fan, as we enter awards season — that thrilling period when the studios (and increasingly the streaming services) trot out their best hopes for Oscar glory. This year’s entries also arrive during a time of remarkable upheaval in Hollywood; a shaky summer at the box office and Disney’s takeover of the storied Fox movie studio were recent shocks to a system that has gone through seismic shifts many times before.

headline: Degas: A Superfan at the Opera, Where Art Tips Into Obsession
abstract: Today’s “age of the fan” is not so new: Audiences have always held more sway over performers than we admit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — You’ll find them up in the balcony, or in standing room, silently mouthing the libretto or humming along with the score. These are the superfans: the compulsive lovers of opera or ballet or theater who see every performance; who travel from city to city for Marilyn Horne or Mikhail Baryshnikov; who know every downbeat of “Così Fan Tutte” or “A Chorus Line.”

headline: Inside Hong Kong’s Battle-Ready Campuses
keywords: ['Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Classrooms may be empty, but universities are bustling with preparation for confrontations with the police.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Across Hong Kong’s university campuses, students and their supporters are bracing for police confrontations in increasingly elaborate ways: constructing Molotov cocktail assembly lines, erecting catapults that use helmets to launch projectiles, and building walls made of brick and mortar or crosshatched bamboo.

headline: Rough Transcript of Trump’s First Phone Call With Ukrainian Leader Released
abstract: The White House’s release of a memo about the call does not mention “corruption,” which appeared in an earlier description of the conversation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday released a memorandum of an April telephone conversation he had with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine that differed from a summary of the call released by the White House months ago.

headline: The Weekend’s Best Beef Stew
abstract: Make David Tanis’s braised beef stew with Vietnamese flavors tonight, let its flavors meld into excellence and eat it all weekend.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Big autumn energy along the Eastern Seaboard these days, air scented with smoke where I stay, and a bite to the breeze off the water. It leaves me wanting stew for dinner, and specifically David Tanis’s braised beef stew with Vietnamese flavors (above). I might make that tonight and let it cure into excellence over the course of a day, serve it for Saturday dinner with rice noodles and a baguette.

headline: To Lower Costs, Trump to Force Hospitals to Reveal Price of Care
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: A proposed federal rule would make hospitals list the prices they negotiate with insurers, allowing consumers to seek better deals for care.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration on Friday announced it would begin forcing hospitals to publicly disclose the discounted prices they negotiate with insurance companies, a potentially bold move to help people shop for better deals on a range of medical services, from hip replacements to brain scans.

lead_paragraph: The director James Mangold narrates a scene featuring Christian Bale and Matt Damon.

headline: T’s Travel Issue: The Great Beyond
abstract: Home will always be a place where I know that there will be water all around me, where the shoreline, and the possibility of another life, is never far.
lead_paragraph: It seems almost unspeakably ungrateful now, but I spent most of my high school years wishing I didn’t live on an island — and not just any island, but one of the Hawaiian islands, among the world’s most remote and yet most visited archipelagos. I lived on Oahu, by far the most densely populated in the chain, yet still small enough to circumnavigate by car in four hours: No matter where you were, the sea was within a 30-minute drive. Living in Hawaii meant being surrounded by blue — blue to your left and blue to your right, blue beneath and blue above.

headline: Fatima Bhutto on the Surge of Bollywood, K-Pop and Turkish TV
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Movies', 'Soap Operas', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Hindi Language', 'Urdu Language']
abstract: A journalist explains how the biggest migration in human history is helping to fuel the erosion of American cultural dominance.
lead_paragraph: “The Bold and the Beautiful,” a staple of American daytime television for more than 30 years, peaked in its worldwide viewership at 26.2 million in 2008. A few years later, “Magnificent Century,” a Turkish drama, was broadcast to 200 million people. That wide gulf in audience is one of the focuses of the book “New Kings of the World,” about how American soft power is being eclipsed around the globe.

headline: How a City Fought Runaway Capitalism and Won
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Greenwood survived the Black Wall Street massacre. It wasn’t going to back down when the dollar stores came to town.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — On a recent Friday afternoon, in the parking lot of a Dollar General in the North Tulsa neighborhood of Greenwood, Jessica Faulk loaded a frozen pizza and other snacks for her grandkids into her car. This was her first trip to the store, which sits near an elementary school and a housing complex for seniors. Though she lives nearby, she’d been avoiding the retailer for more than a year out of principle, and usually shops at a Walmart in the suburb of Sand Springs.

headline: Japan in Bloom
abstract: For more than a thousand years, the country’s cherry blossom season has been a source of fascination and wonderment. How did such an infatuation begin?
lead_paragraph: THE SCENE IS a park in the late afternoon. It is springtime: The trees are a profound, almost bluish emerald; the first reeds are beginning to sprout in the river. The sky is a soft, worn, denimy blue, although above a smudge of cloud is a stripe of near black — it will rain soon. Yet there is no sense of doom, no portent; the rain, you sense, will be welcome when it arrives.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Vows to Expand Health Coverage in First 100 Days
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Warren laid out a blueprint to pass major health legislation at the start of her presidency. But she would wait as long as three years to seek passage of a full-scale “Medicare for all” plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren vowed on Friday to pass major health care legislation in her first 100 days as president, unveiling a new, detailed plan to significantly expand public health insurance coverage as a first step, and promising to pass a “Medicare for all” system by the end of her third year in office that would cover all Americans.

headline: A Brilliant Thanksgiving Strategy: Make Sides Quickly, or Ahead
abstract: The turkey and potatoes may be sacred, but when it comes to the vegetables, you can break from custom. Make them to your convenience.
lead_paragraph: At the Thanksgiving table, the turkey is sacred. The stuffing is imperative, the gravy essential and the mashed potatoes a lumpy rite of passage.
