headline: Vacillating Trump Supporter, Take Two
abstract: If there’s a sure route to a second Trump term, it’s more of the liberal contempt that produced the “deplorables.”
lead_paragraph: The last column I wrote was about a lifelong Republican, Chuck Hardwick, who voted for Trump in 2016 and is unsure how he will vote a year from now. I’d gotten to know Hardwick and concluded he was an interesting man with an open mind, and a good bellwether for how centrist Americans view the election.

headline: The Next Decade Will Be Just as Bad
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media']
abstract: From Trump to Theranos, the main story line of the 2010s was the ascendance of scammers, hucksters and fakery.
lead_paragraph: We will remember the 2010s as a grifter’s paradise. These were the years when our collective sense of objective reality totally fell apart and when politics, business, technology, culture and even ordinary life fell fully under the sway of a new breed of swindler, huckster, influencer, troll and hacker.

headline: Vindman’s Lawyer Asks Fox News to Retract Espionage Allegation

headline: Gordon Sondland Leaves Us With No Other Option
abstract: The case is simple, and the evidence supporting impeachment is now crystal clear.
lead_paragraph: History will remember Wednesday as the day a United States ambassador testified under oath before Congress and laid out a clear, simple and damning case that President Trump abused the power of his office and committed bribery, an act for which the Constitution leaves but one outcome.

headline: ‘I Want Nothing,’ Trump Says, Quoting From Sondland’s Testimony
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: The president, seeking to defend himself from damaging testimony delivered by the ambassador Gordon D. Sondland, said again Wednesday that he wanted ‘no quid pro quo’ in regard to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump sought to defend himself from hours of damaging congressional testimony on Wednesday from Gordon D. Sondland, his ambassador to the European Union, by focusing on one detail of the envoy’s lengthy account: a phone call in September in which the president denied withholding military aid to Ukraine as leverage to pressure that country’s leaders to announce investigations into his political rivals.

headline: Who Is Laura Cooper? Pentagon’s Russia-Ukraine Expert to Testify in Inquiry
abstract: A career Defense Department official, Ms. Cooper will give insight into efforts to release the aid to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the deputy assistant secretary of defense for Russia, Ukraine and Eurasia, Laura K. Cooper was one of multiple Pentagon officials who warned the White House that freezing congressionally approved aid to Ukraine could violate the law.

headline: Who Is David Hale? Top State Dept. Official Will Testify in Impeachment Hearing
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: A veteran diplomat, Mr. Hale will be pressed on the agency’s decision to recall the ambassador to Ukraine after a concerted smear campaign against her.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Why Marie L. Yovanovitch, the ambassador to Ukraine, was recalled from her post two months early has become a central question in the Democratic-led impeachment inquiry into whether President Trump tried to pressure the country to investigate his political rivals. On Wednesday, David Hale, the State Department’s No. 3 official, will be pressed to provide answers.

headline: After False Drug Test, He Was in Solitary Confinement for 120 Days
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Tests (Drug Use)', 'Buprenorphine (Drug)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Solitary Confinement']
abstract: Hundreds of New York State prisoners were locked in cells, denied release or removed from programs when tests erroneously showed they had used narcotics, according to a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kearney could not understand how he had tested positive for drugs. He stared in disbelief at the corrections officers in an upstate New York prison where he was serving time. Though he had once been addicted to crack cocaine, he had been clean for two years.

headline: Climate Warnings: Don’t Blame the Scientists
abstract: Climate change experts take issue with a Sunday Review essay that said scientists got it wrong. Also: Young mothers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tesla’s Winding Road to Berlin
abstract: Elon Musk’s announcement of a factory in Germany took the industry by surprise, but the deal had been in the works for months.
lead_paragraph: GRÜNHEIDE, Germany — The visitors from Palo Alto, Calif., were shown how Berlin, a hive of tech start-ups that likens itself to Silicon Valley, is just a short commute away.

headline: The Flooding of Venice: What Tourists Need to Know
abstract: The high water that devastated Venice in recent months has flooded streets, squares and landmark churches. Tourists are still welcomed, but advised to bring waders.
lead_paragraph: One month after Venice endured devastating high tides, The Associated Press reported on Monday that the Italian city is again facing exceptionally high-water levels.

headline: Oxygen on Mars Adds to Atmospheric Mysteries
abstract: After a perplexing methane burst was measured by NASA’s Curiosity rover earlier this year, scientists were surprised again by variations in atmospheric oxygen.
lead_paragraph: There is not much air on Mars — the atmospheric pressure there is less than one one-hundredth of what we breathe on Earth — but what little is there has baffled planetary scientists.

headline: A Temple to Techno Opens in Queens
abstract: Basement, a new club under the Knockdown Center, is New York’s answer to Berghain.
lead_paragraph: Anyone nostalgic for the Budapest underground club scene circa 1990 will be in their element at Basement, a subterranean nightclub in industrial Queens dedicated to techno music. Drawing inspiration from Berghain in Berlin and the vibrant raves of former Eastern bloc countries, Basement is a conscious (some might say self-conscious) throwback to the pre-iPhone, pre-bottle-service era of clubbing (minus the reek of stale booze and cigarettes).

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Greta Gerwig Reads ‘Sharing a Cab, and My Toes’
abstract: The writer and director of “Lady Bird” reads an essay about an unusual commute.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Trump’s F.D.A. Nominee Sidesteps Questions About Banning Flavored Vaping Products
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-healthcare']
abstract: The nominee, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, said the decision to restrict flavors would not be his, if confirmed, because it was already under final review by the White House.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s nominee for Food and Drug Administration commissioner, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, declined to answer questions from senators in both parties about whether he would push for a ban on flavored vaping products at a confirmation hearing Wednesday.

headline: An Illustrated Guide to Hedi Slimane’s Celine Fragrances
abstract: The creative director’s new perfumes evoke touchstones from his own life, from Parisian nightclubs to California beaches.
lead_paragraph: Hedi Slimane has been the creative director at Celine for just three seasons, but he has been gathering material for his first collection of fragrances for the Parisian house for far longer. The nine unisex scents he released last month (with two more to follow in 2020) draw on the designer’s olfactory journal, a record of scent memories that extends from his childhood in Paris to the decade he lived in Los Angeles before returning to France last year. “I created Celine Haute Parfumerie with the intention to wear every single fragrance of the collection,” he says. “It is all quite personal.” Among the six fragrances designed for the daytime is Saint-Germain-des-Prés, a blend of neroli, petitgrain and white orris butter that harks back to the designer’s 20s, spent skipping between cafes, cinemas and the Jardin du Luxembourg. The three night perfumes, meanwhile, include Reptile, a musky mix of cedar, pepper and leather designed to conjure “the lustrous glimmer of jet-black sequins.”

headline: ‘Pumpgirl’ Review: Gas for Sale but Dreams on Hold
abstract: An exquisite Irish Repertory Theater revival captures a trio of lost souls aching to connect in their constricting small town.
lead_paragraph: If romance is like a pleasurable race that promises bliss at the finish line, tragedy is realizing that you’re running that track completely alone, with no spectators, no cheerleaders, and the end point moves further away the closer you seem to get to it.

headline: 10-Year-Old Boy Who Was Shot at High School Football Game Dies
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Football', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Interscholastic Athletics']
abstract: The victim was a spectator at a Friday night playoff game in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When the Philadelphia Eagles decided to host the remaining minutes of a New Jersey high school football game that was interrupted by gunfire last week, it was supposed to be a chance to write a new narrative: that violence would not win.

headline: The Met Opera’s Credit Outlook Darkens After Modest Deficits
abstract: Rising capital expenses, including the repair of its theater’s travertine exterior, are among the company’s financial challenges.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera has run small deficits for the past two years and faces rising capital expenses — including for the repair of its white travertine exterior — prompting S & P Global Ratings to announce on Wednesday that it was keeping the company’s “A” credit rating but revising its outlook to negative, from stable.

headline: ‘I’m 17 Years Old, and I’m Terrified’: The Issues Our Readers Hope Come Up at the Democratic Debate
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'United States Economy', 'Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Ahead of the Democratic debate on Wednesday, we asked Times readers what issues they most wanted the presidential candidates to discuss, and why.
lead_paragraph: Discussions about health care have dominated the six previous nights of debates among the Democratic presidential candidates. Ahead of Wednesday night’s debate in Atlanta, we asked our readers what issue they most wanted the candidates to address, and why it mattered to them and their families.

headline: 5 Things to Avoid on Black Friday
abstract: Black Friday is a money- and time-sucking vortex. Here’s what not to do this year.
lead_paragraph: To make the most of Black Friday, follow the Wirecutter Deals page, where Wirecutter staff members will be constantly updating their list of researched deals that are actually worth your time.

headline: How to Defuse Tension at the Dinner Table During the Holidays
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: We’re not saying it’s going to happen … but just in case.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, the holidays are the ultimate stress test: travel snags, the pressure to make things perfect, the sometimes overwhelming holiday “cheer” … not to mention the family drama.

headline: Thich Tri Quang, 95, Galvanizing Monk in South Vietnam, Dies
abstract: An orator with “eyes of a tiger,” he helped bring down American-backed governments in Saigon during the Vietnam War and pressed for democratic reforms.
lead_paragraph: Thich Tri Quang, a charismatic Buddhist monk who helped bring down United States-backed governments in South Vietnam during the war-torn 1960s and pushed for a democratic nation with freedom of religion, died on Nov. 8 in the city of Hue. He was 95.

headline: The Big Business of Unconscious Bias
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Vocational Training', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Women and Girls', 'Consultants']
abstract: Companies want to avoid racism, sexism and misgendering. Consultants are standing by.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a story circulated within the diversity, equity and inclusion industry (D.E.I.), one that somehow didn’t go viral on social media: At an unnamed company, co-workers were taking their seats before a sensitivity training workshop began, when some white male employees entered as a group with targets pinned to their shirts — a sartorial statement about their anticipated persecution.

headline: How to Have Closer Friendships (and Why You Need Them)
abstract: Even if you find it easy to make friends — and it’s not, for most people — getting truly close to people is still difficult. Here’s how to make it easier.
lead_paragraph: Like so many people, I grew up watching the TV show “Friends,” dreaming of the day I would be living a glamorous city life surrounded by a group of close friends. Over the years, I’ve made lots of friends: childhood friends, work friends, college friends, writer friends. I have friends who like to hike, and friends who like to chat over coffee and friends who live far away but whom I talk to a few times a year.

headline: Bombshells and Cringe Jokes on a Huge Day of Testimony
abstract: In the explosive impeachment-hearing appearance by Gordon Sondland, drama and farce were never far apart.
lead_paragraph: The explosions at the House impeachment hearings Wednesday were not the work of a mad bomber. The man deploying the bombshells seemed oddly to be enjoying himself.

headline: Arab Thinkers Call to Abandon Boycotts and Engage With Israel
abstract: It’s a viewpoint that is, to put it mildly, politically incorrect in their home countries, but members of a new Arab council say ostracizing Israel simply doesn’t work.
lead_paragraph: Boycotting Israel is a failure, and has only helped that country while damaging Arab nations that have long shunned the Jewish state, according to a small new group of liberal-minded Arab thinkers from across the Middle East who are pushing to engage with Israel on the theory that it would aid their societies and further the Palestinian cause.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the November Democratic Debate
abstract: It was a mostly bloodless evening among the 10 candidates onstage, but there were some standout moments.
lead_paragraph: With polls showing a highly competitive primary race and no clear front-runner, the Democrats in Wednesday’s debate acted as if they had decided ahead of time to avoid taking risks or doing much of anything that might cause them to lose momentum at this stage of the campaign.

headline: Remembering National Book Award Winners of the Past
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'National Book Awards', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: On the day the 2019 honorees were unveiled, we recall recipients who have died in recent years.
lead_paragraph: A historian, two poets, a presidential biographer and two celebrated novelists: They were among the National Book Award winners whose lives were chronicled by The New York Times in obituaries over the past two years. (This year’s winners were announced Wednesday night in a ceremony in Manhattan.) Links to the obituaries are provided below.

headline: Gordon Sondland, Debate, Google: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Surprising Engineering Behind Everyday Objects
abstract: DuPont is designing, developing and testing the materials that propel healthcare forward. Our innovation is everywhere, even if you can’t always see it.
lead_paragraph: DuPont is designing, developing and testing the materials that propel healthcare forward. Our innovation is everywhere, even if you can’t always see it.

headline: Google Policy Change Upends Online Plans for 2020 Campaigns
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The company said political ads would not be directed specifically to audiences based on their public voter records or political affiliations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google will restrict how precisely political advertisers can target an audience on its online services, the company announced on Wednesday in a move that shook up the digital plans for campaigns during the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Uber Embraces Videotaping Rides, Raising Privacy Concerns
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Privacy', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: The company says it is increasing the recording of rides to settle disputes between drivers and passengers and to improve safety.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For several months, some Uber passengers in Texas have been recorded on video as they have been driven to their destinations. The video has been stored online and could have been reviewed by members of Uber’s safety staff if the driver had reported a problem with the passenger.

headline: James Wiseman of Memphis Can Return From Suspension in January
abstract: The N.C.A.A. had declared Wiseman, potentially a top N.B.A. draft pick, ineligible because his family improperly accepted moving funds while the player was still in high school.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. ruled on Wednesday that James Wiseman, the freshman basketball star for Memphis, could return to the court in mid-January, after he has served a 12-game suspension because Memphis Coach Penny Hardaway gave Wiseman’s family $11,500 in moving expenses when he was in high school.

headline: Carolyn Maloney Elected First Woman to Lead House Oversight Panel
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: The Democrat from New York will lead a crucial investigative panel involved in the impeachment inquiry into President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats elected Representative Carolyn B. Maloney of New York on Wednesday to lead the Oversight and Reform Committee, making her the first woman ever to head the crucial investigative panel at a time when it is helping conduct the impeachment inquiry into President Trump.

headline: Taylor Swift, Lizzo, Lana Del Rey: Pop Stars (and Their Fans) Clap Back
abstract: Are artists responsible when their fan armies can be weaponized?
lead_paragraph: This week’s Popcast examines how artists leverage their power, their fame and the crowdsourced enthusiasm of their fans.

headline: Pompeo Emerges as a Major Trump Enabler in Ukraine Affair
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: A top envoy’s testimony places Secretary of State Mike Pompeo at the center of the nation’s biggest foreign policy controversy in nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has for months deflected questions about whether the Trump administration demanded political favors from Ukraine in exchange for military aid. He has refused to explain why he recalled the American ambassador, declared that it was “inappropriate” for his diplomats to testify before Congress and declined to hand over documents to impeachment investigators.

headline: Lawyer With Iconoclastic Bent Navigates Sondland Through Testimony Issues
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The lawyer, Robert Luskin, also represented the Republican strategist Karl Rove and likely spared him a perjury charge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican strategist Karl Rove told a federal grand jury conducting a high-profile investigation in 2004 that he had never talked to a journalist who disclosed the identity of an undercover C.I.A. officer. Eight months later, he advised that he had refreshed his recollection: Actually, he had talked to the journalist.

headline: U.S. Bill Supporting Hong Kong Rights Heads to Trump’s Desk
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: After winning House and Senate approval, the bill could complicate the administration’s already rocky talks with China to end the trade war.
lead_paragraph: A bill compelling the United States to support pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong could arrive on President Trump’s desk as soon as Thursday morning, potentially complicating the administration’s talks with China to end the trade war.

headline: Donald Trump’s Gordon Problem
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Impeachment', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Republicans tried to throw Gordon Sondland under the bus. He took Trump with him.
lead_paragraph: Over the first three days of testimony in the impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump, Republicans have tried out a number of defenses. After the Wednesday testimony of Gordon Sondland, Trump’s ambassador to the European Union, almost all of them have been incinerated.

headline: Prosecutors Subpoena Trump Fund-Raisers Linked to Giuliani Associates
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The authorities are seeking more information about Lev Parnas and Igor Fruman, who worked with Rudy Giuliani in Ukraine and have been charged with campaign finance violations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors in Manhattan issued subpoenas in recent weeks to several players in President Trump’s fund-raising apparatus as part of an investigation into two associates of Rudolph W. Giuliani who have been charged with violating campaign finance laws, according to people familiar with the investigation.

headline: The Strangely Happy Envoy: Sondland Jokes, and Spreads Heat
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Impeachment']
abstract: A plum ambassadorship lands the cheerful hotelier in the red-hot middle of a fast-cooking impeachment crucible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gordon D. Sondland began his day looking strangely happy. The American ambassador to the European Union wore an amused grin as he walked into his hearing and took his seat and oath.

headline: Apple Pulls Samuel L. Jackson Movie From Festival, Citing ‘Concerns’
abstract: “The Banker,” one of the tech giant’s first forays into film, was a day away from its premiere at AFI Fest in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Apple canceled the premiere of “The Banker,” starring Samuel L. Jackson, on Wednesday, yanking the movie from its prestigious closing-night Thursday slot at the American Film Institute’s annual festival in Los Angeles.

headline: In an Echo of Watergate and John Dean, an Adviser Points to Trump
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'Watergate Affair']
abstract: Testimony by Gordon D. Sondland gave Democrats the crisp, accusatory lines they sought. But Republicans elicited an account of one conversation  that they hope will help exonerate President Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gordon D. Sondland had not even finished his testimony on Wednesday before it was being called the “John Dean moment” of the President Trump impeachment drama. With the presidency on the line, a once-trusted lieutenant pointed the finger at Mr. Trump in a proceeding that could lead to Watergate-style charges of high crimes and misdemeanors.

headline: At the Heart of Serbia’s Tennis Success Story
abstract: Janko Tipsarevic practiced in a drained swimming pool that was converted into a court. Now he is part of the core of another strong Davis Cup team.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Before there was Novak Djokovic, there was Janko Tipsarevic.

headline: Impeachment Briefing: What Happened in Sondland’s Hearing
abstract: Gordon Sondland, the ambassador to the European Union, delivered extraordinary testimony implicating the president and a group of top officials.
lead_paragraph: It was a pivotal day in the impeachment investigation, as an ambassador detailed what he said was a clear quid pro quo directed by President Trump. Here’s a recap of the big moments.

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 21, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about testimony in the House impeachment inquiry misstated the country that was said to have conspired with Democrats in 2016, a theory that has been debunked. It was Ukraine, not Russia.

headline: Trump Floats Tariff Exclusions for Apple at Texas Manufacturing Plant
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The president suggested that a trade deal with China remains some distance off, but said he would “look into” Apple receiving exemptions from more tariffs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Wednesday that China had not yet made enough concessions to secure a trade deal with the United States and suggested that he might exempt Apple from an upcoming round of tariffs as he toured a Texas plant that assembles Mac Pro computers.

headline: Live From the National Book Awards
abstract: Photos from this year’s National Book Awards, one of the most prestigious literary prizes in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from this year’s National Book Awards, one of the most prestigious literary prizes in the United States.

headline: On a Dry Spreadsheet, a Stark Difference: A $200,000 Pay Gap
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'News and News Media', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Several shared online documents listing salary information for media industry workers purport to show sharp disparities.
lead_paragraph: With income inequality a focus of the current presidential candidates, workers in journalism, advertising and book publishing have anonymously posted salary information on crowdsourced spreadsheets, many of them hoping their efforts will lead to higher pay.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Says Gordon Sondland Bought His Way to Ambassadorship
abstract: Ms. Warren’s campaign quickly capitalized on her argument with a digital ad. “I’ll never give ambassadorships to unqualified donors just because they wrote me fat checks,” she says in the ad.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment Senator Elizabeth Warren was prepared for on the debate stage, capitalizing on a day of bombshell testimony by the United States ambassador to the European Union in the impeachment inquiry to highlight the fact that her anti-corruption platform included a pledge to not give ambassador posts to big donors.

headline: Massachusetts to Ban Menthol Cigarettes as Well as Flavored Vapes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'State Legislatures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Menthol']
abstract: If signed into law, Massachusetts would be the first state to ban all flavored e-cigarettes and tobacco products through legislation.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Massachusetts has moved a step closer to banning all flavored e-cigarettes and tobacco products, including menthol cigarettes, amid a national push to contend with the risks of vaping.

headline: Susan Choi Wins National Book Award for ‘Trust Exercise’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'National Book Awards', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Sarah M. Broom won the nonfiction prize for “The Yellow House,” one of several memoirs in the category. Arthur Sze won in poetry for “Sight Lines.”
lead_paragraph: Susan Choi won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for “Trust Exercise,” a novel set in the 1980s at a competitive performing arts school, where two students fall in love. The judges praised the novel for blending “the intellectual rigor of post-modern technique with a story that is timely, mesmerizing, and in the end, unsettling.”

headline: With Impeachment as Backdrop, Democrats Direct Fire at Trump in Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry']
abstract: The candidates mostly tempered their criticism of one another and presented a united front on vital issues like climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidates yielded to the furor surrounding the impeachment inquiry in Washington in their primary debate on Wednesday, for the first time training their fire more steadily on President Trump than on one another and presenting a largely united front on vital issues like climate change and abortion rights.

headline: ‘A Christmas Carol’ Review: God Rest Ye Merry, Plutocrats
abstract: This lively reimagining of Dickens’s yuletide perennial, written by Jack Thorne, returns the story’s social conscience to center stage.
lead_paragraph: Have any of the progressive presidential hopefuls still duking it out thought about working “A Christmas Carol” into their campaigns? If so, they would surely benefit from visiting the new, charmingly instructive adaptation of Charles Dickens’s evergreen of Yuletide redemption, which opened Wednesday at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: Review: ‘Einstein’s Dreams,’ Adapted and Muddled in a New Musical
abstract: Alan Lightman’s novel loses its charm in Joanne Sydney Lessner and Joshua Rosenblum’s show, which lacks a sense of a sure artistic voice.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember the Alan Lightman novel “Einstein’s Dreams”? It was such an odd little volume to hit the best-seller list, back in the early 1990s: a playful thought experiment about the nature of time, told in vivid episodes imagined by a young Albert Einstein’s slumbering brain.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard Criticizes Democrats in Democratic Debate, and Kamala Harris Fires Back
abstract: The two candidates reignited a rivalry that dates back to the debate in July.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii offered a striking critique of the Democratic Party on Wednesday from a stage of 10 people vying to be the Democratic nominee for president, accusing the party of being too beholden to the “foreign policy establishment in Washington.”

headline: Fact-Checking the November Democratic Debate
abstract: Our reporters are following all of the exchanges and fact-checking the candidates, providing context and explanation on the policy debates.
lead_paragraph: Ten candidates vying for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination took the debate stage Wednesday night in Atlanta for the fifth round of debates.

headline: ‘Women Are Held to a Higher Standard,’ Klobuchar Says at Debate
abstract: Senator Amy Klobuchar said that she believed Mayor Pete Buttigieg was qualified to be president, but that a woman would struggle to run successfully with his credentials.
lead_paragraph: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota was asked at Wednesday night’s Democratic debate about her recent comment that she and the other women running for president would not be onstage if they had as little political experience as Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind.

headline: Underground Warning
abstract: Aimee Lucido jumps to conclusions.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — We last saw Aimee Lucido in May, but before that, there was a seven-year gap between her crossword puzzles in The New York Times. In that time, Ms. Lucido worked in software development, got married, wrote a book called “Emmy in the Key of Code” and decided to embark on a full-time career as an author.

headline: Border Patrol Agent Who Hit Migrant With Truck Is Sentenced to Probation
abstract: In a text message to another agent, Matthew Bowen referred to immigrants as “murdering savages” and “subhuman,” court documents showed.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — A former Border Patrol agent who hit a fleeing Guatemalan migrant with his truck in 2017 — and who, more than two weeks before the encounter, referred to immigrants in a text message as “subhuman” and “mindless murdering savages” — was sentenced on Wednesday to three years of probation.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sondland Names Top Officials in Ukraine Push
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 21, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone was in the loop. It was no secret.”

headline: No, That Mac Factory in Texas Is Not New
abstract: President Trump said on Wednesday that he opened a facility that makes computers for Apple. It’s been operating since 2013.
lead_paragraph: President Trump on Wednesday toured a Texas plant that makes high-end Apple computers, chatting with Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, and accepting a plate with the words “Assembled in USA.”

headline: Cory Booker Jokes Biden ‘Might Have Been High’ When He Made Marijuana Comments
abstract: At the Democratic debate, the New Jersey senator sparred with the former vice president over legalizing marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Senator Cory Booker, in an attempt to illustrate how some candidates were not campaigning with true attention to the black community, turned his criticism on Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for saying he did not support legalizing marijuana. During the Democratic primary debate in Atlanta on Wednesday, he joked that Mr. Biden “might have been high” when he said that.

headline: Buttigieg Was a Target. But No One Was Attacked Like Warren.
abstract: The debate was often a referendum on a politician who has presented a challenge to the party.
lead_paragraph: Although the Democratic primary debate began with a series of questions about impeaching President Trump, allowing the candidates to take shots at the Republican rival they all hope to face in the general election, it swiftly transformed into a referendum on another politician who has increasingly presented a challenge to the Democratic Party: Senator Elizabeth Warren.

headline: Watch: Key Moments From November Democratic Debate
abstract: Ten presidential candidates took the stage in Atlanta to discuss topics including impeachment, climate change and foreign policy. Also, there were some jokes.
lead_paragraph: Ten presidential candidates took the stage in Atlanta to discuss topics including impeachment, climate change and foreign policy. Also, there were some jokes.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Philharmonia’ and Vanessa Hudgens
abstract: A French thriller series about a Parisian orchestra hits Topic. And Vanessa Hudgens stars in “The Knight Before Christmas” on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: PHILHARMONIA Stream on Topic. Common: A thriller that uses classical music to ramp up tension. Less common: A thriller whose plot revolves around classical music. But both of those attributes apply to this French series, about a fictional Paris orchestra. It begins with the orchestra’s conductor dropping dead midconcert. His replacement, Hélène (Marie-Sophie Ferdane), is a hot shot with a mysterious past who flies from New York to Paris with a handgun in her luggage. The drama begins when Hélène starts making radical changes at the orchestra, like replacing the lead violinist with a young protégée. What follows is a tense story that involves sex, blood and Vivaldi. It will debut in North America on Thursday on a revamped version of the website and streaming platform Topic, alongside the Italian mystery series THE MIRACLE. That show, created by the author Niccolò Ammaniti, centers on the discovery of a statue of the Virgin Mary that weeps blood.

headline: Afghanistan’s Curse: A Bomb From 2 Wars Ago Crushes a Family Today
abstract: This time, it was a Soviet cluster bomb, killing 3 boys on a now-peaceful mountain. War after war has left Afghanistan littered with thousands of deadly next times.
lead_paragraph: DAHANA-E-AHANGARAN, Afghanistan — The three boys were buried on the southern face of the mountain in May. The side-by-side graves of the brothers Amir Khan and Liaqat are marked with a green flag. Mujtaba’s grave is covered in a rocky mound and light from the morning sun.

headline: Literary Classics, Cut Down to Size
abstract: Stage productions of “Anna Karenina” and “Don Quixote” turn sprawling novels into gripping theater.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “Loose, baggy monsters” is how Henry James famously described the long and unruly novels of the 19th century. In Berlin this season, several new productions take on sprawling literary works, trimming them to manageable lengths while still capturing the thrill of their vast, imaginary universes.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Bar Trivia Etiquette
abstract: How should one deal with a teammate willing to “die on this hill”?
lead_paragraph: Zach writes: My friends and I play bar trivia every week. If someone on our team is absolutely sure of an answer, they can say, “I’ll die on this hill,” and we have to submit that answer, no matter what. I believe that this rule can be overturned if everyone in the group knows this person is wrong. My friend Nick contends that this renders the original rule useless.

headline: How to Give Away Your Trust Fund
abstract: Don’t ignore a feeling that you have more than you need. Talk about money — with family and others.
lead_paragraph: “First you need to figure out: What do I actually have? How much can I access?” says Willa Conway, who is 31, currently has $3 million at her disposal and will eventually inherit millions more from a sand-mining fortune. Don’t ignore a feeling that you have more than you need. When Conway was in her mid-20s, a graduate-school adviser told her about Resource Generation, which helps the young and wealthy redistribute their wealth. At a four-day retreat Conway attended, a presenter said, “Give your money to social-justice organizing led by people most impacted by oppression.” After Michael Brown Jr. was shot by the police in Ferguson, Mo., Conway helped lead a campaign that raised $1.4 million for more than 100 organizing groups led by African-Americans.

headline: ‘Queen & Slim’ Could Be One of the Great Love Stories of All Time — if You Let It
abstract: The film is a rare portrayal of black people in our fullness — angry and frightened and hurt, euphoric and loving and free.
lead_paragraph: The person I love and I were among the first members of the public to see the new film “Queen & Slim.” Early in September, we watched it alone on an upper floor of a nondescript office building in downtown San Francisco. It was a phenomenally isolating experience. We sat in a screening room accompanied by two affable white P.R. people and a black security guard who said nothing. The room was otherwise empty. It was 11 a.m.

headline: Don’t Hate Kevin Wilson, but He Wrote His Best Seller in 10 Days
abstract: Holed up in a highway-adjacent rental cabin, there was nothing else to do but get to work.
lead_paragraph: MAN ON FIRE Kevin Wilson writes in concentrated bursts. He’s published five books — his latest novel, “Nothing to See Here,” appears on this week’s hardcover fiction list at No. 15 — but somehow he manages to spend most of his time with his sons, who are 11 and 7. He says, “My wife is a writer too and a couple times a year, one of us will stay home with the kids for 10 days while the other rents a cabin or does a residency.”

keywords: ['Running', 'Exercise', 'Families and Family Life', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: Whether your holidays are merry and bright or the time of year that you grit your teeth to get through, if you are a regular runner, you’re probably going to want to run.

headline: Do You Need Expert Advice on Being a Grandparent?
keywords: ['Grandparents', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: While grandparenting may feel familiar, it is a whole different gig. But there are workshops and classes to help.
lead_paragraph: The first grandparent to arrive, Rohna Paskow, had taken the train from suburban Philadelphia. She saved seats for her daughter-in-law’s parents, Charles and Michele Buchbauer, who were driving 50 miles from rural New Jersey to join her.

headline: Susan Sontag’s Mind Games
abstract: The author and public intellectual wrestled with a new medium and a foreign language in her now restored first feature, “Duet for Cannibals,” a dry comedy made in Sweden.
lead_paragraph: The 1969 New York Film Festival was the first to feature four movies directed by women and three made in Swedish. Susan Sontag’s “Duet for Cannibals,” which she wrote and directed, fit both categories. Given the chance to make her debut film in the land of the reigning cinematic genius Ingmar Bergman, Sontag seized the opportunity to direct in a foreign language while supplying her own English subtitles. In those days her name was synonymous with zeitgeist.

headline: Poem: La Migra
abstract: This poem examines what it means to be an immigrant on the edge.
lead_paragraph: In his elegant third collection of poems, “This American Autopsy,” José Antonio Rodríguez examines what it means to be on the edge, between nationalities, acceptances and dismissals by la migra — immigration agents. When did anxiety become a birthright for whole groups of people? From the very beginning? How has a country made of immigrants come to this current moment of walls and detention facilities? His poems are humanizing testaments of life, penetrating headlines, inviting readers into real rooms and families. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

headline: ‘Shooting the Mafia’ Review: Crime Through a Watchful Lens
abstract: This documentary about the Sicilian photographer Letizia Battaglia is short on the whens and the hows of her story.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, too many people reflexively associate the murderous Italian-born crime entity called the Mafia with the pop culture products it inspires. But for the common people of Sicily, and its capital, Palermo, the Mafia has been a long-term waking nightmare, yielding incredibly high murder rates and viral, nearly all-encompassing corruption.

headline: A London Warehouse District Hopes to Keep Its Edge
abstract: Creative Hackney Wick is thriving after a boost from the 2012 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hackney Wick seems one of the few areas of London that’s still on the cusp of gentrification. Around the corner from the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, it’s benefiting from upgrades tied to the 2012 Olympics and has become a hipster haunt brimming with bars, breweries and a smattering of shops.

headline: $26 Million in Missing Paychecks, One Mysterious Swindler Charged
abstract: When MyPayrollHR shut down, thousands of companies and a quarter of a million workers were left in the lurch.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Ingram was at the supermarket when she got a confusing text. Her payroll check for working as a nursing assistant in New Jersey, which had been deposited into her account, was being withdrawn.

headline: Where Cars Try to Hit Mach 1, the Salt of the Earth Is Crumbling
abstract: The Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah have hosted speed chasers for decades, but the course is distressed. An advocacy group has a plan, but not the money.
lead_paragraph: Not even 30 years after Karl Benz built what is said to be the first automobile, Teddy Tetzlaff climbed into a Blitzen Benz racecar and blasted across the snow-white surface of the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, clocking in at 142.8 miles per hour and setting an unofficial land-speed record.

headline: Who Won the Democratic Debate? Campaign Experts Weighed In
abstract: Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar and Cory Booker stood out at the fifth Democratic primary debate in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Twitter can’t tell us whether, or how, Wednesday’s MSNBC/Washington Post debate will change voters’ minds. But it can give us the perspectives of some of the people with expertise on primary races: veteran campaign strategists, consultants and advocates from both parties.

headline: The Travel Industry’s New Fix for Jet Lag
abstract: Circadian science, newly embraced by airlines, hotels and airport lounges, prescribes bright light for wakefulness and warm light to prepare to rest.
lead_paragraph: If I had to fly standing on my head to avoid the jet lag unleashed by 13 time zone changes, I would have. Instead, while everyone else dined on the night flight to Singapore, I sat in the dark, and, after we arrived, rotated like a sundial around a south-facing office window.

headline: Leading AARP, With No Plans to Retire
abstract: After decades of government service, Jo Ann Jenkins could have stopped working and enjoyed her pension. Instead, she set about bringing AARP into the modern age.
lead_paragraph: Jo Ann Jenkins could have called it quits. She had worked in various posts in the federal government long enough to qualify for retirement, and she would have enjoyed a comfortable life unencumbered by a day job.

headline: Like Restaurants, Buildings Will Get Grades (D’s for Energy Guzzlers)
abstract: Next year, New York City buildings will be required to display their marks on energy efficiency.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers are used to seeing letter grades on restaurants and bagel shops. Soon offices and residential buildings will be getting something similar.

headline: A Wet Year Causes Farm Woes Far Beyond the Floodplains
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Global Warming', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Floods', 'Rain']
abstract: Last year was the wettest on record for the United States and flooded towns got much attention in the spring, but farm statistics show longer-lasting effects.
lead_paragraph: The damage from the destructive spring flooding in the Midwest has been followed in parts of the country by a miserable autumn that is making a bad farming year worse, with effects that could be felt into next spring.

headline: He Wanted to Be a Pro Basketball Player. He Became a Teacher Instead.
abstract: Jeff Duncan-Andrade, an associate professor at San Francisco State University, is driving a public conversation challenging traditional assumptions about how to reform schools.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a continuing series on Visionaries. The New York Times selected people from all over the world who are pushing the boundaries of their fields, from science and technology to culture and sports.

headline: Republicans Seek to Muddy Impeachment Evidence as Their Defense of Trump
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Impeachment', 'Foreign Aid', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: They put forward a shifting array of arguments to defend the president against impeachment — some of which conflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans mounted an array of defenses of President Trump at this week’s impeachment hearings — making arguments that at times seemed to conflict with one another logically, but that dovetailed in a key way: All served to undermine Democrats’ allegations that Mr. Trump abused his power.

headline: 36 Hours in Belgrade
abstract: Rich Serbian cuisine and an inspired bar scene are only the start of a stay in this Balkan city, where the people are outgoing, and history awaits around every corner.
lead_paragraph: While tourists are flooding European cities like Barcelona, Venice and Dubrovnik, the Serbian capital is quietly molding itself into a very fun and accommodating Balkan metropolis. Chefs are getting creative with Serbian cuisine and the cocktail bar scene has taken off, much to the delight of sophisticated locals. The National Museum and the Museum of Contemporary Art have just reopened after unexpectedly long renovations. Now the residents of the former capital of Yugoslavia are just waiting for the world to make a beeline to this affordable, friendly city with so much to offer.

headline: ‘Voodoo Is Part of Us’
abstract: Inside a religious Haitian soiree in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In a dark club in Downtown Brooklyn, surrounded by more than 100 people, Agathina Ginoue Nozy took a sip of Haitian rum. She stood near an altar stacked with skulls, lit candles, cigars, rum, coffee and bowls filled with charred salt fish, boiled plantains, cassava and piman (spicy peppers).

headline: Is There Anything We Can All Agree On? Yes: Dolly Parton
abstract: At 73, the enigmatic country star is captivating a whole new generation and riding high as the subject of a podcast and the inspiration behind a Netflix series.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve heard the rumor about the tattoos.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — At a synagogue west of London, a rabbi made an astonishing plea: Vote against the Labour Party in the coming general election, he urged his congregants, because its leader, Jeremy Corbyn, poses “a danger to Jewish life as we know it.”

headline: One of World’s First Printed Christmas Cards Goes on Display
abstract: The card, dating from 1843, is a symbol of an enduring holiday tradition in an era of e-cards and GIFs. Only 21 of the originals are known to have survived.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For many, Christmas would not be the same without a house brimming with cards from their nearest and dearest, stamped and sent by mail or hand-delivered in the heart of the season.

headline: An Unexpected, Yet Precisely Perfect Pairing
abstract: Andrew Shackett and Patrick O’Keefe discovered how opposite their personalities were early on in their relationship, during a trip to England.
lead_paragraph: The old maxim that you don’t really know a person until you live with him does not apply to Andrew Shackett and Patrick O’Keefe. In their case, all they had to do to really get to know each other was hop on a plane from New York to Birmingham, England.

headline: One Thing Trump Gets Right
abstract: Israel’s settlements are not the principal obstacle to peace with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Mideast news, the Iranian regime has reportedly killed more than 100 of its own people as it attempts to suppress another wave of nationwide demonstrations. The Islamic State is taking advantage of Turkey’s invasion of northern Syria to regroup. Governments in Lebanon and Iraq remain paralyzed by popular discontent. And Israel has struck dozens of targets near Damascus after intercepting Iranian rockets fired from Syria.

headline: The Left Shouldn’t Freak Out About Trump’s Judges (Yet)
abstract: The federal appeals courts are not irretrievably lost for liberals.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are celebrating how they’ve packed the 12 regional federal appeals courts (excluding a specialized federal appellate court) with conservative judges. Earlier this month, President Trump hosted Senate Republicans at the White House to cheer their 45th confirmation. Stephen Bannon recently said, in praising Don McGahn, the former White House counsel who chose many of the new appointees, “Why the left is triggered by Trump is because they understand they’re in a Kafkaesque nightmare, that Donald Trump is going to be in their personal lives 10, 20 and 30 years from now.”

headline: Debating in Georgia, Democrats Make Their Case on Voting Rights

abstract: The 2018 governor’s race in the state was marred by accusations of rampant voter suppression, particularly of black voters.

headline: Can the Supreme Court Save Itself?
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Trump Tax Returns']
abstract: Two cases threaten to reinforce its image as a political captive of the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: I’m often asked these days whether there is anything the Supreme Court can do to extract itself from the partisan trap into which the rancid confirmation process and the court’s own behavior have driven it. It’s a hard question because, of course, individual justices have deeply held views that happen for the most part to map onto the views of the presidents who named them to their seats.

headline: To Take on the Religious Right, We Need a Religious Left

headline: Trump’s Bizarre Apple Factory Visit
abstract: President Trump didn’t rule out exempting Apple from tariffs, while the company’s C.E.O., Tim Cook, stood in silence as the president made inaccurate claims about the firm.
lead_paragraph: Charles Schwab is reportedly in talks to buy TD Ameritrade in a $26 billion deal that could be announced as early as today. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘21 Bridges’ Review: Catch Us if You Can
abstract: In this sturdy thriller, Chadwick Boseman plays a Manhattan detective on the hunt for two squirrelly cop killers.
lead_paragraph: Hedging its bets, the manhunt movie “21 Bridges” both flatters and reviles the police. On the one hand, its somber hero, a remorseless homicide detective named Davis (Chadwick Boseman), is the closest thing the N.Y.P.D. has to a perp whisperer. On the other, Davis manages to shoot almost one suspect a month. Unapologetic about his kill rate, he explains to Internal Affairs that they all deserved their fates, so let’s move on, shall we?

headline: ‘Hala’ Review: Girl, Disrupted
abstract: Geraldine Viswanathan is astonishingly resonant as a teenager testing the boundaries of faith, tradition and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: The title character of “Hala” — a Pakistani-American teenager in her final year of high school — is cautious with her words, but avidly curious with her eyes and ears. Floating in a limbo between two cultures, she’s gently pulling back from her Muslim faith and tentatively testing her crush on Jesse (Jack Kilmer), a tousled blond classmate with a sensitive soul. She’s a fascinating paradox, at once subdued and adventurous: One moment, she’s meekly enduring the affectionate nagging of her anxious mother (Purbi Joshi); the next, she’s racing through their Chicago suburb on her skateboard. Right away, we want to know her better.

headline: Debate Night: The ‘On Politics’ Breakdown
abstract: I thought Pete Buttigieg would have a target painted on his back. But no one really stopped him.
lead_paragraph: Hi, and welcome to a special post-debate edition of On Politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: ‘The Courier’ Review: Gary Oldman Plays Bad. The Movie Plays Worse.
abstract: This action thriller set in a parking garage with a female butt-kicking lead doesn’t even reach the level of watchable novelty.
lead_paragraph: In this unfortunate action thriller, Gary Oldman plays an eye-patch-sporting baddie named Mannings. In a church where he’s about to be arrested, he says to his daughter, “There are several things that need to be done very quickly so that everything is in order.”

headline: ‘Mr. Toilet’ Review: Getting a Handle on the World’s Toilet Shortage
abstract: This profile of Jack Sim, an activist for toilet construction, is a more serious documentary than its title suggests.
lead_paragraph: A film called “Mr. Toilet: The World’s #2 Man” had better be prepared to tank at the box office. At minimum, concession sales at any theater showing Lily Zepeda’s documentary are bound to take a plunge.

headline: Key Moments From Hill and Holmes’s Testimony in the Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: President Trump’s former adviser testified that the pressure campaign on Ukraine was a “domestic political errand” that diverged from U.S. foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Fiona Hill, the former top Russia expert on the National Security Council, said President Trump’s demands for Ukraine to announce investigations into former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the 2016 elections amounted to a “domestic political errand” that diverged from American foreign policy goals.

headline: ‘Donald Trump Got Punked’: The Best One-Liners From the Debate

Wade, reproductive rights have become a major issue in the 2020 campaign. Some candidates and abortion-rights advocates, however, have noted the relative lack of questions on the issue in the Democratic presidential debates so far.

(No pun intended.)

headline: ‘A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood’ Review: You Are My Friend
abstract: Tom Hanks plays Mister Rogers, the beloved children’s television host, as he comes to the aid of a suffering magazine writer.
lead_paragraph: “A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood” celebrates the virtues of patient listening, gentleness and the honest expression of feelings. It’s about how a man who has devoted his life to being kind helps a man with a professional investment in skepticism to become a little nicer. The appeal of such a movie at the present moment is obvious enough, and so perhaps are the risks. This modest, quiet story — based on a magazine article published more than 20 years ago — could easily have turned into something preachy, sentimental and overstated.

headline: More Than 140 Nazca Lines Are Discovered in Peruvian Desert
abstract: A team of Japanese researchers combined on-the-ground archaeology with modern technology, including artificial intelligence, to identify the 2,000-year-old images.
lead_paragraph: A huge carving of a monkey with its tail twirled in a spiral; vast, geometric images of a condor and a hummingbird; an immense spider — the 2,000-year-old Nazca Lines in Peru have awed and mystified modern viewers since they were first seen from the air last century.

headline: Retirement Home Told a Nun She Couldn’t Wear Religious Attire
keywords: ['Nuns', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Politics and Government', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Officials apologized and said the case was an incorrect interpretation of France’s secularism law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Catholic nun who was told she could stay in a retirement home in France only if she stopped wearing religious clothing was wronged, French officials say, in a case that they say misinterpreted the country’s laws prohibiting religious attire in some public spaces.

headline: ‘Frozen 2’ Review: The Cold Still Never Bothers Them
abstract: The sisters and sidekicks from “Frozen” reconvene for another adventure with storms of feeling and a new power ballad.
lead_paragraph: “Let It Go,” the warble heard around the world, wasn’t just the signature song from “Frozen.” It was an anthem (“Here I stand!”) for the mighty, mighty girl power that helped push Disney into industry dominance. The company’s supremacy is often pinned on its highest profile franchises: Lucasfilm, Marvel and Pixar, which have historically featured male-driven stories. But Disney has also heavily profited from a sparkly pink world of adventure and aspirational uplift for spirited girls and women who “dream big,” to borrow a motto from its princess franchise.

headline: Who Is Julia Sweeney Coming to Terms With? It’s Pat
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” character has been used as an insult for decades. Sweeney and some of her most prominent critics address the enduring legacy of her role.
lead_paragraph: In her current one-woman show, Julia Sweeney shares the story of how she acquainted her teenage daughter with her most famous “Saturday Night Live” character, an adenoidal social misfit of uncertain gender named Pat.

headline: Can Our Lease Weather Unrequited Love?
abstract: A reader wonders what to do about his live-in BFF who has expressed feelings for their third roommate.
lead_paragraph: My best friend (a gay man) confessed to our roommate (a straight man) that he’s been madly in love with him for two years and “always will be.” I expected this to ruin their relationship. But after our roommate explained that he wasn’t interested, everything was fine — until recently. My BFF began pushing boundaries. Last night, for instance, he jumped into our roommate’s bed and begged to sleep with him. Our roommate asked him nicely to leave, but finally had to yell at him. I’ve advised my BFF to move on to available men, but he won’t (and says he can’t). Help! There are two years left on our lease.

headline: The Last Time America Turned Away From the World
abstract: The unknown story behind Henry Cabot Lodge’s campaign against the League of Nations.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, on Nov. 19, 1919, Alice Roosevelt Longworth threw a late-night party. Longworth, the daughter of Theodore Roosevelt and wife of Nicholas Longworth, the future speaker of the House, was celebrating the defeat in the Senate that day of the Treaty of Versailles, which encapsulated President Woodrow Wilson’s grand project for world peace, the League of Nations. “We were jubilant,” she recalled later, “too elated to mind the reservationists. And by we, I mean the irreconcilables, who were against any League, no matter how ‘safeguarded’ with reservations.”

headline: Why We’re Impeaching Our Student Body President Over Trump Jr.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The president’s son spoke at the University of Florida for a $50,000 fee. We dug deeper.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — On Oct. 10, Donald Trump Jr. and the former Fox News host Kimberly Guilfoyle gave a speech at the University of Florida for $50,000 at the invitation of our student body president, Michael Murphy. Students protested, and normally that would have been the end of the story.

keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: According to a report released on Tuesday by the Department of Defense inspector general, President Trump’s withdrawal from Syria has allowed ISIS to “reconstitute capabilities and resources within Syria and strengthen its ability to plan attacks abroad.”

headline: Pete Buttigieg Is in Bad Shape With Black Democrats. Here’s Why.
abstract: No Democrat in modern times has won the party’s nomination without claiming majorities of black voters, the most crucial voting bloc in South Carolina and an array of delegate-rich states.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has 154 endorsements from current or former black or Hispanic elected officials. Senator Kamala Harris has 93. Senator Bernie Sanders has 91. Senator Cory Booker has 50. Senator Elizabeth Warren has 43.

headline: Good Leaders Make Good Doctors
abstract: Most people think of doctors as scientists, caregivers or educators. But we must also understand doctors as leaders.
lead_paragraph: During our final year of medical training, I would take turns with the other senior residents responding to cardiac arrests in the hospital. We’d spend weeks camped out in the doctor’s lounge, our hearts racing at the prospect of a patient’s heart stopping, bracing for the moment a shrill pager or overhead speaker would signal an emergency.

headline: In Chelsea, a Little Piece of Prerevolutionary Iran
abstract: A Persian-Jewish artist collects works that kindle memories of his ancestral culture.
lead_paragraph: Jojo Anavim may be a contemporary pop artist himself, but he says that his personal art collection is informed mostly by his Persian-Jewish roots. His parents, Immanouel and Ladan Anavim, both fled Iran before the country’s 1979 revolution — a time when Jews were among those facing persecution — and settled on Long Island.

headline: After Trauma, a Silenced Vocalist Sings Again
abstract: Lucy Dhegrae begins a four-concert series exploring the complex relationship between mind and body.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2013, the vocalist Lucy Dhegrae performed a solo called “Dithyramb.” The five-minute piece, written by Jason Eckardt, consists of cries, truncated syllables and sharp sibilant sounds that appear to resemble someone angrily shushing herself.

headline: A Dance That Stops 2 of Neptune’s Moons From Colliding
abstract: Astronomers detected an orbital resonance between the two innermost satellites of the mysterious ice giant planet.
lead_paragraph: Neptune is the loneliest planet in the solar system. The ice giant, orbiting the sun at a distance of 2.8 billion miles, is the only planet that cannot be seen by the naked eye. Along with Uranus, we have only paid it a single visit, back when Voyager 2 zipped by in the late-1980s.

headline: WeWork Will Lay Off 2,400 Workers
abstract: The troubled office space company is slashing its total work force as it sells businesses and outsources some jobs.
lead_paragraph: WeWork said on Thursday that it was laying off 2,400 employees around the world, weeks after huge losses at the co-working company brought it close to financial collapse.

headline: Israel’s Netanyahu Indicted on Charges of Fraud, Bribery and Breach of Trust
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The first prosecution of a sitting Israeli premier deepens the political paralysis in a country that has had two inconclusive elections this year, and may be headed to a third vote.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was indicted Thursday on charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in a set of long-running corruption cases, throwing his political future into doubt and heightening the uncertainty and chaos surrounding Israel’s fitful, yearlong struggle to choose its next leader.

abstract: This restaurant in Woodside, Queens, focuses on the same homey fare found in Little Manila, and is attuned to newer developments in Filipino cooking.

headline: Thinning Hair All Over

lead_paragraph: Does every woman lose their pubic hair with age? Why doesn’t the medical profession tell us these things “upfront”? When did women wear merkins, and how did they stay on?

headline: Charlotte Perriand, Stepping Out of Corbusier’s Shadow
abstract: Did he, or did she, conceive some of the best modernist furniture in a packed career? A show at Fondation Vuitton shows her mastery of design.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was 1927, and Le Corbusier had already declared, “The house is a machine for living in.” But like Charlie Chaplin in “Modern Times,” he hadn’t quite figured out how to live with the machine from a practical, everyday point of view in the living room, for example, or the bedroom. Yes, the machine was the messiah of the new Modernism, but how do you sit on one? How do you sleep and eat on it? Just how do you furnish modernity?

headline: What We’ve Learned From Hill’s and Holmes’s Impeachment Testimonies
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Two career foreign policy experts delivered new details about the inner workings of President Trump’s foreign policy on Ukraine as well as some history lessons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Holmes, a career diplomat and political counselor to the United States Embassy in Ukraine, and Fiona Hill, a former Europe and Russia expert at the White House, schooled lawmakers on Thursday on the United States’ geopolitical relationship with Ukraine and provided some new details about the efforts to pressure Ukraine to announce investigations into President Trump’s political rivals.

headline: Review: A Fearless, Barefoot Pianist Makes a Carnegie Debut
abstract: Conrad Tao, wearing a black T-shirt for his first recital at the hall, inventively juxtaposed old and new works.
lead_paragraph: Many have long begged for classical music to loosen up the dress codes for its performers. The pianist Conrad Tao must have taken this to heart on Wednesday at Weill Recital Hall: He wore black slacks and a black T-shirt — sometimes with a black jacket, sometimes not — and, most unusual, went barefoot.

headline: 2 Die During Training Exercise at Air Force Base in Oklahoma
abstract: The deaths, involving two training jets, occurred at Vance Air Force Base in Enid, about 60 miles north of Oklahoma City, the Air Force said.
lead_paragraph: Two airmen were killed during a training exercise on Thursday at Vance Air Force Base in Oklahoma, according to military officials.

headline: ‘Varda by Agnès’ Review: A Final Visit With an Irreplaceable Filmmaker
abstract: In her last film, Agnès Varda sums up a six-decade career.
lead_paragraph: Admirers of Agnès Varda, who died in March at 90, may be looking for a fitting remembrance. Especially in the last two decades of her long career, she was an unusually and deeply companionable filmmaker. Her death feels like the loss of a friend, even to people who never met her. At the same time, those who are unfamiliar with and curious about Varda’s work may be wondering where to begin. With characteristic generosity, her final film, “Varda by Agnès,” answers both needs. It’s a perfect introduction and a lovely valediction.

headline: Senate Approves Spending Bill to Avoid Shutdown, and Trump Signs It
abstract: The measure delays the threat of a government shutdown until just before Christmas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Thursday to a stopgap spending bill that would punt the threat of a government shutdown to just before Christmas, setting up a potential clash over federal spending just as the House could be weighing whether to impeach President Trump.

headline: Review: Six Dancing Eccentrics in Search of Some Seriousness

lead_paragraph: As is fitting for a show with an address for a title, the setting of “32 rue Vandenbranden” is a definite place: a couple of trailer homes somewhere isolated and snowy. The characters, too, are distinctive: six eccentrics all up in one another’s business. But what to call the action? Mimed soap opera? Slapstick horror?

lead_paragraph: The fountainhead of the historian Bill Katz’s immersion in African-American culture was his father’s passion for jazz. Ben Katz had derived more pleasure from the music and its historical roots than from his day job as an art director for an advertising agency.
