headline: What Students Are Saying About Marriage, Paying for School Lunch, and Saying ‘No’
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered what Generation Z thinks about marriage? Or how students feel about being publicly shamed by schools for not having lunch? Or teenagers’ advice for fellow teenagers on how to set healthy boundaries?

headline: ‘Bikram: Yogi, Guru, Predator’ Review: The Toxic Man behind Yoga’s Hottest Trend
abstract: This unsettling expose about the founder of Bikram yoga is the opposite of a meditative reprieve.
lead_paragraph: The new Netflix documentary “Bikram: Yogi, Guru, Predator” is the Oscar-winning filmmaker Eva Orner’s portrait of the rise and fall of the yoga magnate Bikram Choudhury. The film first traces how Choudhury built his “Bikram” empire of hot yoga studios, training celebrities and amassing devotees as America’s favorite yogi. The narrative then turns to the accusations of sexual abuse that unmasked the sordid man behind the wellness phenomenon.

headline: What’s Next for Netanyahu, and Israel?
abstract: The corruption case against Benjamin Netanyahu, the first Israeli prime minister indicted while in office, has raised unprecedented legal questions for both him and the country.
lead_paragraph: The corruption charges brought against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday not only threaten his political future, they also present the country with an unprecedented legal quandary.

headline: ‘Dark Waters’ Review: The Killing Fields of West Virginia
abstract: In Todd Haynes’s latest, Mark Ruffalo plays a corporate defense lawyer who switches sides to defend a poisoned community.
lead_paragraph: Outrage mixes with despair in “Dark Waters,” an unsettling, slow-drip thriller about big business and the people who become its collateral damage. It’s a fictional take on a true, ghastly story about a synthetic polymer that was discovered by a chemist at DuPont, which branded it Teflon.

headline: Branko Lustig, 87, Dies; Holocaust Survivor Turned Film Producer
abstract: Mr. Lustig’s experiences as a concentration camp inmate informed his work on “Schindler’s List,” for which he won an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years after his liberation from the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, Branko Lustig stood onstage at the 1994 Academy Awards ceremony to accept an Oscar for best picture as one of three producers of Steven Spielberg’s “Schindler’s List.”

headline: Watchdog Report on Russia Investigation to Come Out Next Month
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inspectors General', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The highly anticipated report will examine aspects of the inquiry, including how and why F.B.I. officials opened it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A highly anticipated Justice Department inspector general’s report on aspects of the Russia investigation, including its origins and whether the F.B.I. abused its surveillance powers, will be released early next month, according to a letter released on Thursday.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Makes Pitch to Black Women In Speech About Racial Inequities
abstract: In events across Atlanta, Ms. Warren, Bernie Sanders and others described how they would address the concerns and priorities of black voters.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — One day after a televised debate featuring significant exchanges about race, Democratic presidential candidates fanned out across this capital of black political power to pitch their message to black voters and send a clear signal: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should not take support from African-Americans for granted.

headline: Republicans Now Support a Form of Paid Leave. So What’s the Holdup?
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Law and Legislation', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: Democrats debated the issue Wednesday, but the real debate is with Republicans: over which workers would qualify and whether to pay for it by borrowing from their future benefits.
lead_paragraph: Paid leave has long been a Democratic cause, one that candidates rallied around at the debate Wednesday night. Now it’s also one for Republicans, who’ve recently embraced a version of it, with a flurry of new bills and a White House summit next month. The debate revealed minor divisions in the candidates’ approaches; the bigger differences, though, are between the two parties.

headline: The T List: What to See, Drink and Wear This Week
abstract: A nonalcoholic aperitif, Mike Kelley’s “paintings” and more ideas from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we are eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

headline: Failing to Decipher Black Voters
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Voting and Voters', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This group is multifaceted. Understanding that is key.
lead_paragraph: There was quite a bit of talk about the black vote and the black community at Wednesday night’s presidential debate.

headline: Violin Stars Will Celebrate Isaac Stern at Tanglewood
abstract: The Boston Symphony’s summer festival in the Berkshires will also feature a new tradition: Wagner led by Andris Nelsons.
lead_paragraph: A small string section’s worth of violin stars will celebrate the centenary of the violinist Isaac Stern. Andris Nelsons will conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the third act of Wagner’s “Tannhäuser.” And Paul Lewis will play the five Beethoven piano concertos.

headline: Dozens of Babies Died Because of U.K. Hospital Failings, Report Finds
abstract: Problems at the Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital Trust over 40 years led to what some say may be the biggest maternity scandal in the history of the National Health Service.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dozens of babies and three mothers died at hospitals in England over four decades because of major staff failings, in what experts said could become the biggest maternity scandal in the history of Britain’s National Health Service.

headline: $93.6 Million Verdict Threatens to Bankrupt One of America’s Most Powerful Unions
abstract: What started as a dispute over two jobs in Portland, Ore., escalated to a jury verdict that could devastate the storied International Longshore and Warehouse Union.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For decades, the International Longshore and Warehouse Union has solidified its power with aggressive demonstrations of solidarity across its Pacific ports.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: China’s anger, Benjamin Netanyahu, royal scandals: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Beijing are furious over a U.S. bill compelling the government to support Hong Kong protesters. Passed by Congress this week, it awaits President Trump’s signature.

headline: Catherine Pugh, Former Baltimore Mayor, Pleads Guilty in Children’s Book Fraud
abstract: Ms. Pugh, who was accused of federal crimes, resigned as mayor earlier this year. She could face decades in prison.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Catherine Pugh, the former mayor of Baltimore, who swept into office three years ago pledging to restore integrity in a city grappling with corruption, entrenched economic inequality and pervasive violence, pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal crimes tied to a children’s book series she wrote.

headline: Changing the World, One Foster Kid at a Time
abstract: Bianca knows the foster care system inside and out. After growing up in it, she set her sights on changing it for the better.
lead_paragraph: Bianca knows the foster care system inside and out. After growing up in it, she set her sights on changing it for the better.

headline: Jim Meehan Has Left PDT, the Influential Bar He Helped Found
abstract: The East Village speakeasy’s general manager, Jeff Bell, has plans to buy the business.
lead_paragraph: The bartender Jim Meehan, a pioneering figure in the craft-cocktail revival, is no longer involved in PDT, the acclaimed East Village speakeasy that he helped found 12 years ago. He confirmed this week that he was forced out of his position as a managing partner, as part of an organizational restructuring in March.

headline: What’s Better Than Seeing a Hopper Painting? Sleeping in One
abstract: Every detail of Edward Hopper’s “Western Motel” has been brought to life at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, where you can spend the night.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Behind a pane of glass at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, a wooden bed frame anchors a sparsely decorated motel room. Vintage suitcases have been arranged at the foot of the bed, and light streams in diagonally through a window, just beyond which a green Buick is visible, parked in the foreground of a mesa landscape.

headline: How Churches Fight the Stigma of H.I.V.
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Religion and Belief', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: In the South, black houses of worship are reducing the social suffering of H.I.V. with an approach that recalls Dr. King’s teachings.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The second Wednesday of the month is always crowded in the parking lot of Bible Way Ministries. That’s the day the church offers its community food bank — and as of this year, it’s also the day when an AIDS Healthcare Foundation mobile testing unit rolls up to provide H.I.V. testing to anyone who wants it.

headline: Fiona Hill Testifies ‘Fictions’ on Ukraine Pushed by Trump Help Russia
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former top White House aide denounced a theory that Ukraine interfered in the 2016 election, as she tied the president’s pressure campaign to Russian efforts to sow political divisions in America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former White House Russia expert on Thursday sharply denounced a “fictional narrative” embraced by President Trump and his Republican allies that Ukraine, not Russia, interfered in the 2016 election, testifying that the claim was a fabrication by Moscow that had harmed the United States.

headline: N.F.L. Upholds Myles Garrett’s Indefinite Suspension
abstract: Garrett, the Cleveland Browns star, told N.F.L. officials that Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Mason Rudolph used a racial slur during an in-game brawl.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. appeals officers on Thursday upheld the indefinite suspension for Cleveland Browns defensive end Myles Garrett for hitting Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Mason Rudolph in the head with a helmet during a game last week.

headline: At Chelsea, Hard Work as High Art
abstract: Chelsea midfielder N’Golo Kanté is soccer’s ultimate artisan: a player who does the running and the fetching and the retrieving so others can score the goals. That diligence has its rewards.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For Andrea Pirlo, it was the satisfaction of a free kick, sweetly struck, sweeping “a couple of centimeters over” a defender’s head, beyond the goalkeeper’s despairing reach, whistling into the corner of the goal. There could be, he wrote in his autobiography, “no greater feeling in life.”

headline: An Adrenaline Junkie’s Dream Job
abstract: David was a machinist, and a very good one at that. But when his contract ended, he decided it was time for something new. Learn how he turned his passion for motorcycles into a career.

Hartley’s “The past is a foreign country,” two quotes that live on in the hoary files of English composition instructors everywhere. Compare and contrast, please.)

headline: Virus Outbreak Closes Colorado Schools for More Than 20,000 Students
abstract: The “extremely contagious” virus forced a school district to close all of its schools for the first time, officials said.
lead_paragraph: When a virus appeared last week, a Colorado school district closed one high school in an attempt to stymie an outbreak. A few days later, a nearby middle school was closed. By Thursday, administrators were forced to close an entire school district that serves more than 22,000 students.

headline: Wat Misaka, 95, First Nonwhite in Modern Pro Basketball, Dies
abstract: A son of Japanese immigrants, he starred for the University of Utah on national championship teams before joining the Knicks for a short but history-making run.
lead_paragraph: Wat Misaka, the son of Japanese immigrants, was a 5-foot-7 guard who starred for the University of Utah on teams that won two national tournament championships at Madison Square Garden in New York and then joined the Knicks there in 1947.

headline: Edward Gallagher, the SEALs and Why the Trident Pin Matters
abstract: The Navy SEAL insignia is tough to earn and, except when the White House intervenes, easy to lose.
lead_paragraph: It is a ritual that has been repeated at many funerals of Navy SEALs and dramatized in Hollywood movies: SEALs approach a gravesite one by one, remove the gold-colored pin from the left breast of their dress uniforms and pound them into the coffin of a fallen comrade. The living mourn, with the primary symbol of their brotherhood missing, to be replaced only after the dead have been buried.

headline: Campaigns Say Google Ad Policy Sidesteps Problem of Disinformation

abstract: Campaigns and some digital experts say the restrictions limit a tactic — microtargeting of voters — that they heavily rely on, while not aggressively addressing misinformation.
lead_paragraph: Google’s new restrictions on political advertising, following an outright ban on such ads by Twitter, amount to a one-two punch on 2020 campaigns: The online platforms are creating a big new headache for them, while failing to address a different problem they fear most.

headline: ‘She Saved Us’: Mourners Pay Tribute to Toni Morrison

headline: Smashing Good Times
abstract: Emily Carroll blasts us off into the weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This grid! So effervescent and refreshing — every other entry got a reaction, usually a chortle, once or twice a cringe (because of a personal association, I promise, no shade intended for the puzzle). Emily Carroll has ramped up production this year and is now one day of the week away from hitting for the cycle. That will be a Saturday, which gives us something to look forward to, especially after solving today’s endeavor, which is Ms. Carroll’s first Friday and first themeless puzzle for The Times.

headline: Man Who Threatened 2 Members of Congress Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison

headline: Face It, Mom and Dad: I’m Not Special

My parents believe in the power of positive thinking.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Dolly Parton’s Heartstrings’ and a New Comedy
abstract: A Dolly Parton series comes to Netflix. And “Brittany Runs a Marathon” hits Amazon.
lead_paragraph: DOLLY PARTON’S HEARTSTRINGS (2019) Stream on Netflix. “Songs: they’re just stories put to music,” Dolly Parton said in the trailer for “Dolly Parton’s Heartstrings,” a scripted anthology series inspired by her music. Parton is an executive producer of the show, which features eight of her songs, including favorites like “Jolene,” “Two Doors Down” and “If I Had Wings.” For each song, an individual narrative is drawn and added to the series, which stars Julianne Hough, Kimberly Williams-Paisley and Ginnifer Goodwin, among others. “Much of her music is grounded by an authentic sense of insecurity that she’s worked hard to overcome,” Lindsay Zoladz wrote of Parton in The New York Times. “She’s not a one-dimensional paper Dolly. She has bled.”

headline: Colette’s Burgundy
abstract: A painstaking renovation of the writer’s childhood home provides a compelling centerpiece for an exploration of the corner of France she loved.
lead_paragraph: With her wry sense of humor honed by a coquettish but self-doubting vanity, the French novelist Colette would doubtless have been flattered to see the painstakingly authentic renovation of her childhood home by the Paris decorator Jacques Grange in Saint-Sauveur-en-Puisaye. Born Sidonie-Gabrielle Colette in 1873 in this Burgundian village 115 miles south of Paris, she went on to become a legend of French letters. Colette wrote more than 30 books and was made a member of the Belgian Royal Academy, the prestigious French Académie Goncourt and a grand officer of the French Legion of Honor, before becoming the first Frenchwoman ever accorded a state funeral in 1954 (she’s buried at Père Lachaise Cemetery in Paris).

It was his first encounter with Hieronymus Bosch — who painted like a contemporary of Salvador Dalí even though he began work on his wild masterpiece “The Garden of Earthly Delights” way back in 1490. (“I’ve always intended to try and write an album based on that painting,” Beck, 49, said. “I’m not sure how that would work.”)

abstract: A prime time matchup on Sunday between the Packers and the 49ers makes the rest of the schedule seem like a series of appetizers.
lead_paragraph: The Patriots are trying to improve to 10-1 with the Cowboys in their way; the Seahawks are seeking an important road win at Philadelphia; and the Falcons — yes, the Falcons — are trying to stay red hot. These games make for solid appetizers, but the real meal will take place near San Francisco, where Aaron Rodgers and the Packers will try their best to find room to pass against the dominant pass rush and secondary of the 49ers.

headline: A Beresford Duplex for Broadway Royalty
abstract: The former home of the Broadway veterans Phyllis Newman and Adolph Green, where they dazzled a long list of showbiz friends, is on the market.
lead_paragraph: The former home of the Broadway veterans Phyllis Newman and Adolph Green, where they dazzled a long list of showbiz friends, is on the market.

headline: A Theatrical Duplex at the Beresford Is Listed for $24 Million
abstract: The Broadway veterans Phyllis Newman and Adolph Green raised their family there and dazzled a long list of showbiz friends.
lead_paragraph: A duplex at the landmark Beresford tower on the Upper West Side that served as both home and creative space for the Broadway veterans Phyllis Newman and Adolph Green is coming to market for the first time in more than half a century.

headline: Building a Better Bonfire in Berkeley
abstract: Friday: Flame on, but make it eco-friendly. Also: Los Angeles’s rent crisis.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Attacks Impeachment Inquiry and Accuses a Witness of Lying
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Trump said a career diplomat made up a conversation between him and his ambassador to the European Union, dismissing sworn testimony in the impeachment inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump unleashed a series of falsehoods on Friday in an effort to invalidate the impeachment inquiry and counter sworn testimony from officials in his own administration, after a week of damaging public hearings.

headline: Israelis Call Netanyahu Indictment an ‘Earthquake,’ but Agree on Little Else
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Some of the prime minister’s supporters are sticking by him, while others are wavering. All are nervous and unsure about what comes next.
lead_paragraph: LOD, Israel — Watching Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu attack the prosecutors who had just indicted him, watching him beg for compassion for his family’s suffering through years of corruption investigations, Tzion Hagag said he began to question whether the rule of law was really all that worth preserving if it could be so unfair to such a great man.

headline: Afghan Vote Crawls Toward Crisis, With No Results After 2 Months
abstract: A dispute over a decisive slice of votes in the country’s presidential election is again exposing the fragility of Afghan democracy, as President Trump pushes for a drawdown of troops.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nearly two months after Afghans braved hundreds of Taliban attacks to cast ballots in a vote for president, the results have been repeatedly delayed, and protests have blocked election officials from auditing and recounting problematic votes in several provinces.

headline: The Family Meal: Tips for Staying Sane and Sated
abstract: Worries about overeating, family conflicts and dinner guests with special dietary needs can bring extra stress when it comes to planning a holiday meal.
lead_paragraph: Holiday time is stressful for a variety of reasons, particularly when it comes to eating. Worries about overeating, family conflicts and dinner guests with special dietary needs are enough to make you want to cancel the holiday meal altogether!

headline: Will Instagram Ever ‘Free the Nipple’?
abstract: For years, artists have put pressure on Facebook and Instagram to treat female and male nipples equally, but such a change may be too radical for Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Photographers have learned to be inventive in evading Instagram’s ban on female nipples. They’ve used paint, glitter, hair and flower petals to obscure them. They’ve covered them up with leaves, cornstarch, a spatula, handbags, shot glasses, strands of bubble gum, and sand.

headline: She’s the Queen of Tap. Is Her Moment Now?
abstract: Long considered a master by her peers, Dormeshia is entering her prime.
lead_paragraph: Like Beyoncé or Prince, the tap dancer Dormeshia is singular enough to need no surname. In her field, she is unsurpassed in all-roundedness. Other tap dancers make artistic compromises. They sacrifice elegance for complexity, or sound for visual beauty, or the reverse. Not Dormeshia. In her dancing, nothing is missing. Music and motion are a unified impulse, a perfect whole, and every time she improvises, the history of tap meets its cutting edge.

headline: The Pop Musical: Go Big (and Loud) or Go Home
abstract: It’s time for Broadway to embrace what’s most joyous about songbook shows. Not biography, not coherence, but excess. Even “Moulin Rouge!” doesn’t quite get it right.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, I crave a musical where grandiosity is unencumbered by logic and good taste. I don’t need a book that makes sense when I can feast on eye-popping visuals backed by an eardrum-busting sound system. It’s O.K. for the brain to take a rest while the senses work overtime. Broadway knew that once, or at least Florenz Ziegfeld did.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Just when you think you’ve seen everything, here comes a Brazilian mini-series about an aviation pioneer. Airships ahead.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Viking Treasure Could Have Made Them a Fortune. Instead, They Stole It.
abstract: Two British men who uncovered a 1,100-year-old trove were sentenced to years in prison for failing to report the find and selling the items piecemeal to dealers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 1,000 years ago, a Viking hoard of gold jewelry, coins and silver bars was buried for safekeeping.

headline: Leftovers Never Tasted This Good
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton’s latest recipe is for risotto al salto, a pancake made with day-old risotto Milanese.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. You’ll be making pie dough this weekend. (Right?) You’ll be buying wine for the feast. (Or farming out that job to siblings?) You’ll be standing in the dining room and staring at the table and wondering how many people really can fit around it before you have to bust out the plywood and sawhorses, the extra-long runner, the chairs from upstairs. (Or is that just me?) Anyway, you’re looking at two days of lists, check marks and lots of Thanksgiving self-instruction this weekend, and a lot of physical work on top of that if you’ve got a yard and it’s filled with leaves.

headline: Protesters Confront Warren and Biden at Campaign Events
abstract: In Georgia, Senator Elizabeth Warren was interrupted by protests because of her plan to cut charter school funding. And in South Carolina, immigrants’ rights activists clashed with former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. over Obama-era deportation policies.
lead_paragraph: In Georgia, Senator Elizabeth Warren was interrupted by protests because of her plan to cut charter school funding. And in South Carolina, immigrants’ rights activists clashed with former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. over Obama-era deportation policies.

headline: Trump Says He’s ‘Standing’ With Xi (and With Hong Kong’s Protesters)
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a Fox News interview, the president called the Chinese president “a friend” and suggested he might not sign a tough human rights bill to secure a trade pact with China.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump refused to commit Friday to signing legislation overwhelmingly passed by Congress to support pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong, saying that he supported the protesters but that President Xi Jinping of China was “a friend of mine.”

headline: Barr Says Epstein’s Suicide Resulted From ‘Perfect Storm of Screw-Ups’
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr acknowledged his own initial suspicion that Jeffrey Epstein may have been murdered but said the evidence ultimately showed the financier hanged himself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr said in an interview published on Friday that the death of Jeffrey Epstein, the financier accused of sex trafficking, in a secure federal prison resulted from “a perfect storm of screw-ups,” rather than any nefarious act.

headline: France Vowed to Return Looted Treasures. But Few Are Heading Back.
abstract: The country seemed to be leading the way on the restitution of Africa’s cultural heritage. But a year after a pioneering report, little has happened.
lead_paragraph: A year ago this week, in a pioneering announcement, President Emmanuel Macron of France said that his country would give back 26 looted treasures to the African state of Benin. It was a bold statement by the leader of a former colonial power. He also took delivery of an independent report he had commissioned, which sent shock waves through museums around the world.

headline: Why Fox News Slimed a Purple Heart Recipient
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As a former talk-show guest host on the channel, I can explain the art and purpose behind attacking Colonel Vindman.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect additional information about the author.

headline: The 10 Best Books of 2019
abstract: The editors of The Times Book Review choose the best fiction and nonfiction titles this year.
lead_paragraph: In the first chapter of this assured debut novel, two young girls vanish, sending shock waves through a town perched on the edge of the remote, brooding Kamchatka Peninsula. What follows is a novel of overlapping short stories about the various women who have been affected by their disappearance. Each richly textured tale pushes the narrative forward another month and exposes the ways in which the women of Kamchatka have been shattered — personally, culturally and emotionally — by the crime.

headline: What Is Netanyahu’s Game Plan?
abstract: Israel’s prime minister is under indictment. A third election is on the way. If his allies don’t make him stand down, we are headed for chaos.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israelis who enjoy political drama just had a great week. Israelis who care about the future of their country, not so much.

headline: To Help Holiday Crowds, New York to Close Streets Near Rockefeller Center
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan to provide more pedestrian space to ease congestion on Fifth Avenue during the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Countless visitors make the pilgrimage to Fifth Avenue in Manhattan during the holidays to bask in the glow of the towering Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center, gawk at glittering window displays, and take selfies with sidewalk Santas.

headline: Your Thanksgiving May Be Classic, but Your Leftovers Don’t Have to Be
abstract: There are no rules to making turkey sandwiches: Pack them with bright flavors, and salty pickles.
lead_paragraph: My dad always said that the best part of the Thanksgiving turkey was nibbling the crisp, fatty bits of skin that fell off his knife as he carved. The turkey sandwiches the next day were the second best part.

headline: Dogs Can’t Help Falling in Love
abstract: One researcher argues that a dog’s ability to bond has more to do with forming emotional attachments than being smart about what humans want.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Xephos is not the author of “Dog Is Love: Why and How Your Dog Loves You,” one of the latest books to plumb the nature of dogs, but she helped inspire it. And as I scratched behind her ears, it was easy to see why.

headline: Stuck in Arctic Ice, Dodging Polar Bears. All for Science.
abstract: An international research team is now adrift about 300 miles from the North Pole. It’s for a yearlong expedition to study the Arctic’s changing climate.
lead_paragraph: Despite difficult ice conditions and curious polar bears, a German research icebreaker with 100 scientists and crew members is comfortably adrift in the frozen Central Arctic, two months into a yearlong expedition to study the region’s changing climate.

headline: Jake Burton Carpenter, Who Ushered in Snowboarding as a Sport, Dies at 65
abstract: After his fascination with the Snurfer, a crude version of a snowboard created in the 1960s, he built the first successful snowboard company.
lead_paragraph: Jake Burton Carpenter, whose once-modest plan to make 50 snowboards a day turned into something far bigger — a global business that helped drive snowboarding into a popular Olympic sport — died on Wednesday in a hospital in Burlington, Vt. He was 65.

headline: Review: At the Philharmonic, a Much-Needed Dose of Joy
abstract: The conductor Jakub Hrusa lent the New York Philharmonic a sense of dance and delight it’s too often missing.
lead_paragraph: While the New York Philharmonic’s music director, Jaap van Zweden, has been away over the past month, the orchestra has engaged in a form of speed dating with different conductors who have shown just how malleable this ensemble’s sound can be.

headline: Charlotte Brontë and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Before the World Knew Them
abstract: New graphic biographies of the novelist and the Supreme Court justice show the determined paths they followed, from quietly rebellious girlhoods to full-on iconhood.
lead_paragraph: Glynnis Fawkes’s graphic biography of Charlotte Brontë opens with the 20-year-old aspiring writer receiving a letter from the poet Robert Southey. He warns her, “Literature cannot be the business of a woman’s life.” Find yourself a husband, he says; write poems on the side if you must. But creative aspirations? Forget about it.

headline: Squatters Were In and Out of Abandoned House Where 3 Died in Fire
abstract: The fatal fire brought renewed attention to the worsening homeless crisis in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For years, residents in Queens had been concerned about an abandoned house in their neighborhood, telling officials the property was unsafe and had become a home for squatters.

headline: Can South America Produce a Superclub?
abstract: Flamengo, which faces River Plate in Saturday’s Copa Libertadores final, might be the best bet. But can it break through in a Eurocentric soccer world?
lead_paragraph: Get Rory Smith’s weekly newsletter on world soccer in your inbox every Friday. It’s free! Sign up here at nytimes.com/rory.

headline: Eight Audiobook Classics Written, and Narrated, by Women
abstract: Contemporary recordings breathe new life into such books as “To the Lighthouse,” “Jane Eyre” and “The Handmaid’s Tale.”
lead_paragraph: Some audiobooks you listen to when you don’t have time to sit down and read the physical book. And others you listen to even if you’ve read their corresponding hardcovers again and again, the voices revivifying timeworn texts.

headline: Pakistan Blames India for Its Air Pollution. Its Citizens Disagree.
abstract: Pakistan’s minister for climate change blames India for toxic smog. But residents of Lahore, one of the world’s most polluted cities, blame their country’s government.
lead_paragraph: A new front in the decades-long rivalry between India and Pakistan has emerged: which country is more responsible for the choking air pollution that straddles their shared, hostile border.

headline: The Impeachment Inquiry Goes Public
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A look at the scene from inside the room.
lead_paragraph: The past two weeks of public impeachment testimony before the House Intelligence Committee produced indelible scenes of drama and confrontation. The photographs here are images that will fill American textbooks for generations, whatever the outcome of the proceedings. Unseen but vividly present was the most important character of all, the 45th president of the United States, Donald J. Trump, only the fourth president to face possible impeachment.

headline: Larry David: Imagining What Keeps Trump Up at Night
abstract: In this fictional conversation, the president chats with his wife at 3 a.m. and comes up with a tremendous idea.
lead_paragraph: July 2019. The White House — 3 a.m. Donald Trump tosses and turns.

headline: U.K. Takes Back Children From Former ISIS Territory
abstract: The Kurdish authorities said three children in Syria had been handed over to British officials.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Several unaccompanied children have been repatriated from former Islamic State territory in Syria to Britain, as European nations grapple with questions about what to do with the potential return of citizens who joined the terrorist group.

headline: The Modern Life of Origami, an Art as Old as Paper
abstract: Precision is key, whether folding a humble crane or an interlocking modular structure. So is enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: “I would say the biggest rule is no cutting,” said Wendy Zeichner, the president and chief executive of OrigamiUSA. It’s “one piece of paper and no glue.”

headline: The Martians Are Coming!
abstract: ‘The War of the Worlds’ has been a novel and a radio broadcast. Now, an artist reimagines H.G. Wells’s extraterrestrial tale in graphic form.

headline: The Playlist: Paul McCartney’s Upbeat Outtakes and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Soccer Mommy, Wye Oak, Lewis Capaldi and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: ‘No Longer Forgotten’: Ohio Students Have Headstone Made for Black Settlers
abstract: A group of eighth graders found two unmarked cemetery plots where black inhabitants were buried. They placed a plaque on the graves this week to remember the families.
lead_paragraph: On a barren patch of grass in a cemetery in North Olmsted, Ohio, a group of students this week commemorated two black families believed to be buried in unmarked plots there.

headline: Kids Have Questions. These Picture Books Have Answers.
abstract: New books from Isabelle Arsenault, Grant Snider and more speak to children’s curiosity about everything from the color of nighttime to difficult stuff in the news.
lead_paragraph: WHAT COLOR IS NIGHT?

headline: The No-Turkey Zone
abstract: We’ve got all the sharp, bright flavors you need to make sure all your other meals next week taste nothing like Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. I realize that you may need either potato recipes (make this one!) or pie recipes (so many options here). But I believe that what we really need are ideas for all the other meals next week, dishes that have nothing to do with turkey or, even better, taste nothing like Thanksgiving whatsoever.

headline: Dissecting the 2020 Grammy Nominations
keywords: ['Grammy Awards', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Lizzo, Billie Eilish and Lil Nas X lead the way. But has the Recording Academy’s relationship to pop changed?
lead_paragraph: With each year’s Grammy nominations comes the griping: the Grammys are too old, the Grammys are too male, the Grammys are too white. But the nominations for the 62nd Grammy Awards, which will take place on Jan. 26, were a surprise. The most-nominated artists are young and forward-looking. The enthusiastically upbeat singer-rapper Lizzo received eight nominations. Billie Eilish, the year’s most vivid young breakthrough, received six, as did Lil Nas X, who at this time last year was still a social-media gadfly looking for a meme-assisted breakthrough into the music world.

headline: Review: A Must-Hear Maestro Leads ‘Requiem’ at the Shed
abstract: Teodor Currentzis and MusicAeterna made their American debut with Verdi’s Requiem and an accompanying film.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of MusicAeterna, the orchestra and chorus he founded 15 years ago in Siberia, the conductor Teodor Currentzis worked in relative obscurity.

headline: It’s Enrollment Time for Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Many people will find more choices and lower premiums, but it’s still “buyer, beware” on plans outside government marketplaces.
lead_paragraph: Shop, compare — and beware, when shopping for health insurance outside official government marketplaces.

headline: What Josephine Baker and a Maharajah Teach Us About Design
abstract: In Paris, fresh takes on an exotic dancer, the Villa Savoye and a modern patron in Indore reflect multicultural shifts
lead_paragraph: In Paris, the deep design shift that occurred during the interwar years when Modernism superseded Art Deco has long kept architecture historians scribbling. But two events in Paris — a recent week of performances in Le Corbusier’s famous Villa Savoye and “Moderne Maharajah,” a show at the Museum of Decorative Arts through January — open up our understanding of a period we thought we knew cold. Each of the two events sees design through a polarizing cultural lens.

headline: Famous Voices Take Center Stage at Italy’s ‘Dubbing Oscars’
abstract: In Rome, a glitzy ceremony celebrated the stars of an industry, which may be the best in the world but is often dismissed and overstretched.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Just like the Oscars, the gala held Thursday night at Rome’s music auditorium included a red carpet complete with a noisy cluster of paparazzi snapping pouting actors. Most people, however, would have struggled to put a name to the faces.

headline: Moderate Voters Could Decide the Democratic Nominee. What Do They Want?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many of the existential questions gripping the Democratic Party center on one mysterious figure: the “moderate” voter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Poll Watch, our weekly look at polling data and survey research on the candidates, voters and issues that will shape the 2020 election.

headline: Charges of Ukrainian Meddling? A Russian Operation, U.S. Intelligence Says
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Impeachment']
abstract: Moscow has run a yearslong operation to blame Ukraine for its own 2016 election interference. Republicans have used similar talking points to defend President Trump in impeachment proceedings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans have sought for weeks amid the impeachment inquiry to shift attention to President Trump’s demands that Ukraine investigate any 2016 election meddling, defending it as a legitimate concern while Democrats accuse Mr. Trump of pursuing fringe theories for his benefit.

headline: Debating U.S. Policy on the West Bank Settlements
abstract: Differing perspectives on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Michael J. Pollard, Character Actor in ‘Bonnie and Clyde,’ Dies at 80
abstract: A familiar face in movies and on television, he rose to fame in 1967 as the outlaw couple’s dimwitted accomplice, earning an Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Pollard, who rose to fame in the 1967 hit film “Bonnie and Clyde” as C.W. Moss, the dimwitted gas station attendant who became a criminal accomplice, and went on to a long career as a Hollywood character actor, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: Ex-Fox News Host’s Business Partner Charged in Real Estate Scheme
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Herbert Whalen, who worked with Clayton Morris selling investment properties in Indianapolis, was charged with defrauding clients.
lead_paragraph: The former business partner of Clayton Morris, the Fox News host turned financial guru, was indicted by a federal grand jury and arrested at his home in Indianapolis on Thursday on charges that he defrauded real estate investors recruited by Mr. Morris.

headline: Huawei Funds Are Cut Off by F.C.C. Over Security Threats
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Politics and Government', 'Blacklisting', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The commission put new restrictions on money aimed at helping wireless carriers provide broadband to rural areas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission voted on Friday to bar cellular carriers from using federal subsidies to buy equipment from Huawei and ZTE, two Chinese companies, saying the companies endangered national security.

headline: Love Letter: Let’s Eat Together!
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life', 'Movies', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: Because (surprise!) gathering is good for you.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up here to receive Love Letter, a weekly newsletter about relationship highs, lows and woes, in your inbox every Friday.]

headline: New Rating System for Charities Aims to Measure Impact of Gifts
abstract: Donors don’t want their money misused or used less effectively than it could be. ImpactMatters joins several well-established rating sites.
lead_paragraph: It has become the holy grail of philanthropy: measuring the impact of a charitable contribution. Donors don’t want their money misused or used less effectively than it could be, but how can impact be measured?

headline: The Likability Trap Is Still a Thing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Debates (Political)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Even with a record number of qualified female presidential candidates, that hard-to-define concept continues to impact how voters perceive them.
lead_paragraph: — Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democratic presidential candidate

headline: White Alabama Officer Guilty of Manslaughter for Killing Black Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The officer shot Greg Gunn after initiating a stop-and-frisk encounter as the unarmed man was walking home from a card game in 2016.
lead_paragraph: An Alabama jury found a white police officer guilty of manslaughter on Friday in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man in Montgomery in 2016, the latest case in which an officer has been held to account for using lethal force.

headline: Guido Badano, Officer in the Andrea Doria Crash, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Badano scrambled to rescue passengers and fellow crew members when two ocean liners collided in 1956, resulting in the deaths of 51 people.
lead_paragraph: Guido Badano, a 29-year-old officer aboard the glamorous Italian ocean liner Andrea Doria, was asleep in his bunk, relieved of his duties for a while, when two short blasts from the ship’s whistle, signaling an impending turn to the left, jolted him awake. It was shortly after 11 o’clock on the night of July 25, 1956.

headline: Takeaways From the Impeachment Hearings
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers voice frustration that “Republicans seem to be immune to facts” and that the scope of the inquiry was limited to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Life and Death of the Local Hardware Store
abstract: It’s cheaper and more efficient than ordering from Amazon. But American capitalism has turned against small business.
lead_paragraph: On Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, not far from where I live, there’s a small neighborhood hardware store called Chelsea Convenience Hardware, which is distinguished by its unlikely display of dozens of Russian nesting dolls in the storefront window. Inside, tools and supplies are piled to the ceiling, and when you enter, the owner, Naum Feygin, an immigrant from Boris Yeltsin’s Russia, looks up to ask you what you need.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The jungle prince of Delhi. The Mister Rogers no one saw. How a girls’ soccer team healed a broken coach. Thanksgiving in a war zone. Worn-out voters and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It might be the one to clean out your fridge ahead of Thanksgiving. After the avalanche of news this week, perhaps you’re looking for a bit of cleaning zen. Or maybe it’s time to make some mulled cider or mulled wine and catch up with friends. Whatever you’re doing, make time for some great journalism.

headline: The Artist Couple Making Ceramics on a 19th-Century Farm in Paris
abstract: Michel and Andrée Hirlet have lived and worked together for over 50 years. Now, they’re gaining recognition beyond their native France.
lead_paragraph: The branches of the quince tree hanging over the front gate of the Parisian home of the ceramic artists Michel and Andrée Hirlet heave with knobbly yellow fruit, adding color to an otherwise gray streetscape. “There were more a few days ago, but we put a note on the gate saying that we are giving out quinces, and now we have the jam the neighbors have made,” Andrée reports, gesturing through the open kitchen door to the glass pots resting on a bench.

headline: Canadian Official Calls for Removal of Key Software From 737 Max
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Software']
abstract: “MCAS has to go,” a manager at Canada’s aviation regulator said in an email to global peers, referring to software in the Boeing plane.
lead_paragraph: A manager at Canada’s aviation regulator believes that Boeing should remove software that played a role in two deadly crashes of its 737 Max before the plane is cleared to fly again, according to emails between global aviation regulators this week that were reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Our National Parks Are in Trouble
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Blame overcrowding, invasive species, climate change and money woes.
lead_paragraph: CARBONDALE, Colo. —  Deep inside Alaska’s six-million-acre Denali National Park and Preserve, I could see miles of space beneath my feet as I stood on the summit of the tallest mountain in North America. The startling view from the 20,310-foot Denali of rugged wilderness spreading out in all directions, plus the challenge of climbing it, were just two of the many wonders and adventures that I’ve experienced in America’s national parks.

headline: Mark Cuban Buys Democracy.com
abstract: The billionaire said he bought the  domain name this month “to make sure someone didn’t do something crazy with it.”
lead_paragraph: Well, you had your chance.

headline: Wait — Are You Thankful?
abstract: A collection of stories to read either way.
lead_paragraph: Some tragedies, or some reasons to be grateful.

headline: Russia Inquiry Review Is Said to Criticize F.B.I. but Rebuff Claims of Biased Acts
keywords: ['Inspectors General', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: A watchdog report will portray the pursuit of a wiretap of an ex-Trump adviser as sloppy, but it also debunks some accusations by Trump allies of F.B.I. wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A highly anticipated report by the Justice Department’s inspector general is expected to sharply criticize lower-level F.B.I. officials as well as bureau leaders involved in the early stages of the Trump-Russia investigation, but to absolve the top ranks of abusing their powers out of bias against President Trump, according to people briefed on a draft.

headline: An Outtake From ‘The Daily’
abstract: Astead Herndon sings.
lead_paragraph: Astead Herndon sings.

headline: For Those Who’ve Seen ‘Parasite’ and Want More
abstract: “Relentless Invention” at Film at Lincoln Center is filled with highlights from a relatively recent period in Korea’s 100-year-old cinema tradition.
lead_paragraph: “Parasite” has burrowed in deep. The South Korean class satire, directed by Bong Joon Ho, is poised to be this year’s highest-grossing subtitled release in the United States. In May, when it became the first Korean-language movie to win the top prize at Cannes, the director noted that the festival had chosen to honor the film in the centennial year of Korean cinema, and called the award a “very great gift.”

headline: Latest in the N.B.A. Injury Crisis: Kemba Walker on a Stretcher
abstract: Superstars, All-Stars, role players, rising youth: Injuries have reached them all, and that’s hurting the league.
lead_paragraph: Injuries happen in all professional sports. Players get hurt, even when they are in top physical shape.

But in the past few decades, the mental health community and the military have come to understand that there is a related, intensifying phenomenon called moral injury.

headline: Review: At the Bolshoi, ‘Giselle’ Is Rethought, Refreshed, Revivified

Do they need a new one? If it’s Alexei Ratmansky’s exquisitely faceted re-creation, which had its premiere here on Thursday, the answer is: absolutely.

They were “vile and stupid,” she said, and “more consistent with someone who lived in the 18th century than the 21st.”

headline: Fred Cox, Vikings Kicker and an Inventor of Nerf Football, Dies at 80
abstract: He was a mainstay of a Vikings team that lost four Super Bowls and, while playing, helped create a squeezable foam toy that brought him decades of royalties.
lead_paragraph: Fred Cox, a place-kicker for the Minnesota Vikings who scored the most points in the team’s history and, while still playing, helped conceive the Nerf Football, a squishy faux pigskin that sold in the millions, died on Wednesday at his home in Monticello, Minn. He was 80.

headline: Navy SEALs Case Reveals Broad Scope of a President’s Military Powers
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: President Trump raised eyebrows when he said he would reverse a decision to remove a convicted sailor from the Navy SEALs. But on military matters, a president has few limits.
lead_paragraph: In an October White House photo, President Trump presented the military’s ultimate symbol of heroism, the Medal of Honor, to a dog. It was a joke, a doctored photo reposted on the president’s Twitter account. But even though the president didn’t actually award the Medal of Honor to a dog, legal scholars agree that as commander in chief of the military, he could have.

headline: Would-Be Chinese Defector Details Covert Campaigns in Hong Kong and Taiwan
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defectors (Political)', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The claims by an asylum seeker in Australia couldn’t be independently verified, but Western officials are treating them seriously.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A man claiming to be a disillusioned Chinese intelligence operative has told the Australian authorities that China’s military intelligence agencies were directly intervening in politics in Hong Kong and Taiwan, buying media coverage, infiltrating universities, funneling donations to favored candidates and creating thousands of social media accounts to attack Taiwan’s governing party.

headline: Bolton Teases a City Eager to Hear His Story
abstract: John R. Bolton, President Trump’s former national security adviser, said he was breaking his silence — on Twitter. But what he meant was that he was taking back control of his Twitter account. He kept quiet on Ukraine and impeachment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, Washington has waited to hear what he had to say. So when John R. Bolton, the president’s former national security adviser, popped back up on Twitter on Friday morning with a teasing message, it sent the town, well, all atwitter.

headline: Trump’s Long List of Inaccurate Statements on ‘Fox & Friends’
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: The president was wrong or misleading or exaggerated about topics related to impeachment, Ukraine and the Democrats, among other inaccuracies.
lead_paragraph: In a freewheeling 53-minute interview on Friday morning on Fox News, President Trump rattled off exaggerations, falsehoods and debunked conspiracy theories, often related to the impeachment inquiry. Many of them have previously been fact-checked by The New York Times and found false, including his claim that Ukraine, rather than Russia, was behind the hacking of the Democratic National Committee in 2016; his accusation that the Obama administration wiretapped him; and his characterization of the whistle-blower’s report as baseless. Here’s a check of some of his newer assertions.

headline: The Yankees Hired a Hitting Coach. Her Name Is Rachel.

headline: Netanyahu’s Cry of Attempted Coup Sounds Familiar

lead_paragraph: When the Israeli attorney general filed corruption charges against Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday, his political rivals were quick to dredge up a statement he made 11 years ago, when his predecessor as prime minister fell afoul of the law.

headline: The United States Is Starting to Look Like Ukraine
abstract: Why the president must be impeached and removed.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump ought to be impeached and removed from office. This isn’t what I thought two months ago, when the impeachment inquiry began. I argued that the evidence fell short of the standards of a prosecutable criminal act. I also feared impeachment might ultimately help Trump politically, as it had helped Bill Clinton in 1998. That second worry might still prove true.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates: The Cancellation of Colin Kaepernick
keywords: ['United States National Anthem Protests (2016- )', 'Football', 'Social Media', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Discrimination']
abstract: “Cancel culture” has always existed — for the powerful, at least. Now, social media has democratized it.
lead_paragraph: We are being told of the evils of “cancel culture,” a new scourge that enforces purity, banishes dissent and squelches sober and reasoned debate. But cancel culture is not new. A brief accounting of the illustrious and venerable ranks of blocked and dragged Americans encompasses Sarah Good, Elijah Lovejoy, Ida B. Wells, Dalton Trumbo, Paul Robeson and the Dixie Chicks. What was the Compromise of 1877, which ended Reconstruction, but the cancellation of the black South? What were the detention camps during World War II but the racist muting of Japanese-Americans and their basic rights?

headline: Fiona Hill and the American Idea
abstract: A naturalized American exposes Trump’s attack on what America is and must be.
lead_paragraph: For a naturalized American, raised in Britain, I found Fiona Hill’s testimony at impeachment hearings this week to be a powerful reminder of what makes America great and of how President Trump has taken a sledgehammer to “its role as a beacon of hope in the world.”

headline: Justice Dept. Urges Supreme Court to Back Trump in Tax Records Case
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS']
abstract: In a friend-of-the-court brief, the department urged the justices to hear the president’s appeal in a clash with Manhattan prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed a friend-of-the-court brief on Friday urging the Supreme Court to hear President Trump’s appeal seeking to keep his financial records private. Mr. Trump is trying to block a subpoena from Manhattan prosecutors that would require his accounting firm to turn over eight years of his personal and corporate tax returns.

headline: A Senate Trial Could Put Trump’s Use of Aggressive Defense Tactics to Their Biggest Test
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Impeachment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s campaign against the Mueller report and its author is a road map of what is likely to lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over four decades in public life, President Trump has sought to bend business, real-estate and political rivals to his will. Facts that cut against his position have been declared false. Witnesses who have questioned his motives have been declared dishonest. Critics of his behavior are part of a corrupt, shadowy effort aiming to damage him.

headline: Term(s) of Endearment
abstract: Finish Trenton Charlson’s puzzle, enjoy some warm fuzzies.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Tough cluing today, as well as a formidable layout, made this grid intimidating to get started on. The “pinwheel” formation makes four quadrants that don’t help each other at all; also, there are only 62 entries (an average Saturday is 69), which means fewer black boxes and longer (and usually harder) entries, as a whole. Sometimes the constraints of a grid like this can make for some blooper entries, but anything boring in the grid today was brought to life by a sparkling clue.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 23, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 23, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a family in India who masqueraded for decades as Oudh royalty misstated the dollar value of 10,000 rupees in 1975. It was about $1,200, not $90,000.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Will Ferrell on ‘S.N.L.’ and ‘The Feed’
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” veteran returns to host for a fifth time, and a dystopian sci-fi series begins streaming on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE 11:29 p.m. on NBC. It’s hard to believe that Will Ferrell, who was an “S.N.L.” cast member for seven years and is credited with some of the show’s most memorable characters, will just now be hosting the show for a fifth time. On Saturday, Ferrell will be inaugurated into the so-called Five-Timers Club, joining a group of stars that includes Bill Murray, Justin Timberlake and Tina Fey. Before becoming a major movie star, Ferrell got big laughs as the cowbell-happy member of the Blue Öyster Cult and as Craig, the pep rally-ready Spartan cheerleader, as well as for his spot-on impressions of George W. Bush, Robert Goulet and Alex Trebek. The musical guest will be the 20-year-old songwriter King Princess, making her “S.N.L.” debut.

headline: The Phoenix Suns’ Hot Start Has Cooled, but They’re O.K. With That
abstract: Devin Booker’s long-suffering time with the Suns is finally paying off, with the team’s ups and downs coalescing into success.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The Suns are familiar with adversity. Long considered one of the league’s more dysfunctional franchises this side of Madison Square Garden, Phoenix has not tasted the postseason since 2010, back when many of the players on the current roster were in high school.

headline: No Zion, RJ or Cam Means More Balance for Duke
abstract: Duke is the top team in college basketball even though three players from last season went as top N.B.A. draft picks.

headline: The Broken Promise of a Panda: How Prague’s Relations With Beijing Soured
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations']
abstract: When a new mayor of the Czech capital refused to toe the line on Taiwan, Beijing severed its sister-city relationship. Broader repercussions followed.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — On the top floor of an opulent Art Deco building in the heart of old Prague, the new lord mayor was standing with a glass of sparkling wine in hand, greeting diplomats as they made their way into his official residence for a New Year’s gathering.

headline: Merkel and Macron Publicly Clash Over NATO
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With relations at a new low, Chancellor Angela Merkel berated President Emmanuel Macron over his comments about the alliance’s ‘‘brain death.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, was uncharacteristically furious. At a dinner to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, she huddled with President Emmanuel Macron of France, who had just given an interview in which he cited the “brain death” of NATO and wondered whether its commitment to collective defense still held.

headline: What Is Intermittent Fasting and Does It Really Work?
abstract: The best diet is the one where you are healthy, hydrated and living your best life.
lead_paragraph: Generally, intermittent fasting is a diet strategy that involves alternating periods of eating and extended fasting (meaning no food at all or very low calorie consumption). “There’s quite a bit of debate in our research community: How much of the benefits of intermittent fasting are just due to the fact that it helps people eat less? Could you get the same benefits by just cutting your calories by the same amount?” said Courtney M. Peterson, Ph.D., an assistant professor in the Department of Nutrition Sciences at the University of Alabama at Birmingham who studies time-restricted feeding, a form of intermittent fasting.

headline: Inside the War for California’s Cannabis Churches
keywords: ['Cannabis Foods and Products', 'Marijuana', 'Religion and Belief', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Illegal marijuana dispensaries outnumber legal ones more than three to one in California. What’s the role of the cannabis church?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Every Sunday, about two dozen people gather at a green cabin along the main drag of Big Bear, Calif., a small mountain town known for its namesake lake. They go there for Jah Healing Church services, where joints are passed around.

headline: Can Fan Fiction Bridge the Partisan Divide?
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Literary revisions may help us empathize with political figures across party lines.

Perhaps you were one of them; the public hearings, after all, are the reality show everyone seems to be talking about these days.

headline: 5 Gift Ideas for Travelers
abstract: A truly thoughtful gift for frequent travelers has to go beyond the basics, or be something they wouldn’t splurge on for themselves.
lead_paragraph: People who are constantly on the road — whether for work or for fun — likely have most of the essentials that travelers need, which means that a truly thoughtful gift for them has to go beyond the basics or be something they wouldn’t splurge on for themselves. Here, a range of experts, including Wirecutter staffers and Sebastian Modak, this year’s 52 Places Traveler, share their picks for the most compelling gifts for your favorite frequent flier.

headline: The Men’s Cardigan Makes a Comeback
abstract: The versatile sweater is cozy on Mister Rogers, cool on Kurt Cobain and chilling on Logan Roy.
lead_paragraph: Paternal. Sexless. Infinitely square. The cardigan sweater is generally considered the Mister Rogers of men’s wear, and for good reason: Fred Rogers made sure of it.

headline: Fitting in Family Fitness at the Holidays
abstract: Experts’ top tip on ways to get moving? Involve the relatives who might otherwise stay inactive.
lead_paragraph: Milk-gallon dead lifts, shared inchworms, synchronized walking and a little misdirection could be the keys to staying in shape and in harmony with loved ones during the holiday weeks ahead, experts say.

headline: When U.S.C. Plays U.C.L.A., They Play Too
abstract: Marching band is a team of its own.
