headline: Make Room at the Table for Difficult People
abstract: Our son makes the holidays challenging, but I treasure every moment of grace and connection.
lead_paragraph: “I am not going to hit you on Thanksgiving,” our 37-year-old son with autism says to me anxiously on the telephone.

headline: Trump Signs Hong Kong Democracy Legislation, Angering China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)']
abstract: The measure, which could lead to sanctions on Chinese officials for cracking down on the protesters, drew bipartisan support from Congress.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump on Wednesday signed tough legislation that authorizes sanctions on Chinese and Hong Kong officials responsible for human rights abuses in Hong Kong, signaling support for pro-democracy activists and escalating tensions with Beijing as Mr. Trump tries to negotiate a trade deal with Chinese leaders.

headline: Marilyn Yalom, Feminist Author and Historian, Is Dead at 87
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Research']
abstract: In books about the history of wives, the history of the breast and other subjects, she examined how cultural forces led over time to feminist thinking.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Yalom, a prolific feminist author and cultural historian whose subjects included the history of women as partners in marriage as well as the history of the female breast, died on Nov. 20 at her home in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 87.

headline: Asthma Control Is Critical During Pregnancy
abstract: Asthma attacks during pregnancy can be bad for both mother and child.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women with asthma should take special care to keep their asthma in check.

headline: Navy Drops Effort to Expel From SEALs 3 Officers Linked to Gallagher
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: After President Trump intervened to stop the Navy from disciplining Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher, the service called off reviews of three SEAL officers who were the chief’s superiors in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The Navy is dropping its efforts to expel three officers from the elite SEAL commando force over their involvement in the war crimes case surrounding Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher, the service said on Wednesday.

headline: University of North Carolina Gives ‘Silent Sam’ Statue to Confederate Group
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']
abstract: The move was part of a settlement with a group that had sued over the fate of the statue, which was toppled in 2018. The group plans to make the statue available to the public.
lead_paragraph: Ever since protesters toppled a Confederate statue known as Silent Sam at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill last year, the college has hidden the monument from view, stashing it in storage and refusing to disclose its location.

keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Impeachment', 'Foreign Aid']

lead_paragraph: Three women have accused Gordon D. Sondland, the United States ambassador to the European Union, of making unwanted sexual advances toward them years before his recent turn as a star witness at the impeachment proceedings against President Trump, according to a news report.

headline: UPS Employees Are Arrested in Scheme to Ship Drugs and Cash
abstract: The operation, which was said to have run for more than a decade, has led to the arrest of 11 people on drug and money laundering charges.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials said this week that they had taken down a “sophisticated” decade-long operation to ship drugs and cash through the United Parcel Service, leading to the arrests of 11 people and the seizure of commercial-grade equipment to manufacture illegal drugs.

headline: Cantankerous Sort
abstract: Timothy Polin burns things up.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Timothy Polin is back and if you are not careful, you might just burn yourself on his theme.

headline: Editors’ Note: Nov. 28, 2019
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 28, 2019.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday reported on a series of online posts said to have been written by Joycelyn Savage, a girlfriend of the singer R. Kelly, in which she accused him of physical and emotional abuse. After publication, the website Patreon deleted the posts, saying it could not verify that they were written by Ms. Savage. An article about these developments can be found on Page C6.

headline: Boys, 10 and 14, Are Among 5 People Shot in the Bronx
abstract: A gunman fired into a crowd on a block with stores, a day care center and students heading to after-school classes.
lead_paragraph: Five people, including two boys, ages 10 and 14, were shot in the Bronx on Wednesday by a man firing into a crowd, the police said. The hail of bullets caused chaos on a block with stores, a day care center and students headed to after-school classes the day before Thanksgiving.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Farmers Grow Old, Who Will Replace Them?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 28, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Many farming families are in the Hulls’ situation or getting near it. They’re land-rich and cash-poor, and they’re saying, ‘What do we do with this family business we’ve created?’ ”

headline: TikTok Reverses Ban on Teen Who Slammed China’s Muslim Crackdown
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Censorship', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The video app said it would review its policies after a 17-year-old in New Jersey who discussed Chinese detention camps was locked out of her account.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The video app TikTok on Wednesday reversed its decision to block an American teenager who posted a clip in which she discussed the mass internment of minority Muslims in China, and acknowledged that its moderation system had overreached in shutting her out of her account.

headline: On a Military Base in Japan, Football as a Tie to Home
keywords: ['Football', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Interscholastic Athletics']
abstract: Football and homecoming weekend are among the comforts of home at Zama Middle High School. “You can take the Americans out of America, but we are still going to bring football with us.”
lead_paragraph: CAMP ZAMA, Japan — A deafening silence hung over the athletic office on this United States Army post where roughly 40 teenagers were lying on the floor, nearly on top of one another.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Servant’ and ‘The Godfather Part II’
abstract: A psychological thriller series debuts on Apple TV Plus. And the first two “Godfather” movies air on IFC.
lead_paragraph: SERVANT Stream on Apple TV Plus. A recent trailer for this series has all the ingredients of a shocking story: an unsettling doll, foreboding rain and a title card that reads “from M. Night Shyamalan.” That filmmaker is an executive producer of the series, a psychological thriller about a couple (Lauren Ambrose and Toby Kebbell) who have lost a child. As part of a form of therapy meant to help them cope, the pair start taking care of a lifelike baby doll. They even enlist a nanny (Nell Tiger Free) to help — which is when matters begin to take a turn for the exceedingly strange.

headline: For Fans, by Fans, Against the Club
abstract: Arsenal Fan TV is a YouTube sensation. But what makes it a success is not the same thing as what makes Arsenal a success — in fact, it’s often the opposite.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chris Davies walked out of the Emirates Stadium feeling, he said, as if he was “filled with fire.” As most of his fellow Arsenal fans trudged dolorously away from last Saturday’s 2-2 draw with lowly Southampton, seeking shelter in the pubs of the Holloway Road or the sanctuary of the Tube, he strode toward the statue of Dennis Bergkamp on the perimeter of the club’s North London home.

headline: Apple, Bowing to Russian Pressure, Recognizes Crimea Annexation on Map
abstract: The tech giant, following Google and others, has bowed to Russian demands that its apps not show Crimea as belonging to Ukraine on digital maps seen in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Since it grabbed Crimea from Ukraine five years ago, Russia has made no headway in getting the United States or the European Union to recognize the annexed Black Sea peninsula as Russian.

headline: Modern Black Friday Work Force: Postal Clerk, Influencer, Robot
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: They’re still selling you stuff, but the e-commerce era has redefined who, exactly, works in retailing.
lead_paragraph: A postal employee who processes one Amazon return after another. A part-time stockroom clerk who works spotty hours for minimum wage and no health benefits. A social media influencer who pitches products to her 83,000 Instagram followers. A robot that scans the shelves at Walmart.

headline: For These Hunters, Every Day Is Turkey Day
abstract: Got turkey on the brain? Not as much as these fanatical hunters, who spend all year “dreaming and scheming and thinking about turkey.”
lead_paragraph: For most Americans, life revolves around turkey for just one day each year: From the making of the stuffing to the basting and the baking, it all leads up to that delectable moment when the golden brown bird graces the Thanksgiving table.

headline: Late Night: It’s Not Turkey, It’s ‘Emotional Support Meat’
abstract: Stephen Colbert says stranded travelers can have “a perfectly good Thanksgiving eating Hudson News almonds while charging your phone in the pet relief area.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: ‘99 Problems but My ABCs Ain’t One’: Jay-Z Sues Over Children’s Book
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Little Homie, a small Australian online retailer, says it is celebrating hip-hop. Jay-Z, who has spoken out about black identity and equality, says it is engaging in theft.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When the children’s alphabet book “A B to Jay-Z” was released by a small Australian online retailer more than two years ago, the company said it sold out within days. But it also drew criticism on social media as a particularly cringe-worthy example of cultural appropriation.

headline: North Korea Launches 2 Rockets, South Says
abstract: The short-range projectiles were launched off the North’s east coast, days after Kim Jong-un ordered artillery fire near a disputed sea border.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea launched two rockets from its east coast on Thursday, days after firing artillery near a disputed sea border, South Korean defense officials said.

abstract: After 16 years of rent-stabilized life on West End Avenue, Alan Murray and Marcelo Jara left the city for a place they could afford to buy. Here’s where they landed.

headline: Thanksgiving N.F.L. Guide: Which Outcomes Help Your Team Most (Even if It Isn’t Playing)
abstract: Giving fans of every team someone to root for — or at least something to do.
lead_paragraph: There are three N.F.L. games this Thanksgiving — Bears at Lions (12:30 p.m. Eastern), Bills at Cowboys (4:30 p.m.) and Saints at Falcons (8:20 p.m.) — but the outcomes of these games have implications for nearly every N.F.L. team. Below, a guide for all 32 teams.

headline: Uphill Skiing: Subtract Crowds and Lift Lines, Add Cardio
abstract: The practice of uphill skiing — better known as skinning or alpine touring — is everywhere in snow country these days.
lead_paragraph: The fastest growing trend in Alpine skiing is all about ditching the very thing that built the sport: mechanized lifts.

headline: A Comedy of Manners, and Multiple Homicide
abstract: A man snuffs out his aristocratic relatives one by one in the 1949 British film “Kind Hearts and Coronets,” now showing at Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: A mannerly cad murders his way to a dukedom, dispatching eight relatives all played by Alec Guinness. Obviously, “Kind Hearts and Coronets” is a comedy. In fact, a recent British Film Institute poll ranked it as Britain’s greatest.

headline: Can Dance Make a More Just America? Donald Byrd Is Working on It
abstract: The choreographer’s commitment to dance as a catalyst for social change can be seen at a museum show in Seattle and in a new work for the Alvin Ailey company.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The choreographer Donald Byrd stood before a video of his younger self, observing a dance he created 33 years ago. In a button-down T-shirt, loose khaki pants and bare feet, the man onscreen floated through swift turns and bobbing leaps with the continuity of rushing water, letting the phrase resolve in a simple first position.

headline: They Gave Me Oxy. I Didn’t Want It. Now What?
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Opioids and Opiates']
abstract: There would be no herbs, or diffusers, or mysticism. There would be Oxycodone or Vicodin, and I would need to take it.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in early October I sat with a pain management specialist at the Hospital for Special Surgery, during a long day of orientation in advance of an operation that would replace the joint sockets and femoral heads on both my right and left hips, driving metal rods into my thigh bones. Reading about the procedure, I imagined something that happened in the service aisles at Home Depot, but with the addition of nerve endings.

headline: Broken Promises and Debt Pile Up as Loan Forgiveness Goes Astray
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Student Loans']
abstract: A federal loan forgiveness program made a promise to students: Stick with your vital but low-wage professions and your debts will be wiped clean. Then they weren’t.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Congress created a student loan forgiveness program in 2007, lawmakers wanted to draw people to vital but relatively low-paid careers with a promise: after a decade, if borrowers faithfully paid their debts and pursued their work, they would have the remainder of their student loans written off.

headline: Capturing a Shooting Survivor’s Long Recovery, With Humanity
abstract: Manny Fernandez, our Houston Bureau Chief, and Tamir Kalifa, a photographer, discuss spending nearly three months with Luis Calvillo, who was seriously wounded at the Walmart shooting in El Paso, and his family.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Prosecutors Usually Send People to Prison. These Are Getting Them Out.
abstract: Prisoners who fought for years to prove their innocence couldn’t win in court, no matter how much evidence they amassed. Then the offices that put them away got involved.
lead_paragraph: After Aaron Salter was convicted of murdering a man he had never met, he immediately began trying to track down the real killer from behind bars. When another inmate described the crime in detail, Mr. Salter began investigating him. Eventually that other man signed an affidavit swearing that Mr. Salter was innocent.

headline: A Detroit Doctor Who Loves Art and Loathes Labels
abstract: Lorna Thomas has filled her home with African-American pieces; she believes their beauty transcends categorization.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Lorna Thomas thought she knew a thing or two about art from her classes at Wellesley College in the 1960s. But after graduation, she discovered the world of African-American-owned galleries. “All of a sudden, the light went on, and I thought, ‘Oh my gosh, we have this entire body of work out here that should be celebrated,’” she recalled.

headline: 36 Hours in Steamboat Springs
abstract: You won’t see too many luxury stores or fancy condos here. This Colorado ski resort is a place of indie flair, Western appeal and, yes, plenty of champagne powder.
lead_paragraph: About 70 miles north of the I-70 corridor that feeds Colorado’s busiest ski areas, Steamboat Springs seems removed from the usual luxury designer shops and rampant condo development so often seen in ski towns these days. Local craft makers, artists, brewers and restaurant owners lend indie flair to the town’s main street, lined mostly with early-20th-century buildings. Supplementing Steamboat’s “champagne powder” and Western appeal, improvements at Steamboat Ski Resort by its owner, Alterra Mountain Company — which also owns Deer Valley in Utah, and Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows in California in its 14-resort portfolio — include a new gondola that shortens the ride from 12 to less than 10 minutes and boosts capacity 38 percent to 3,600 people an hour. Given Steamboat’s in-town diversions, hot springs and variety of winter sports (including snowshoeing and biking), many visitors come without Alpine ambitions. The town makes it easy even for those without a car — free buses circulate nearly every 10 minutes in winter between downtown and the ski resort, supplemented by ride-sharing services.

headline: When Is a Star Not Always a Star? When It’s an Online Review
abstract: Customer reviews are incredibly important in e-commerce, but they can be unreliable or downright dishonest.
lead_paragraph: In the world of e-commerce, the online review is king, the internet’s answer to walking into a store and trying out a product for yourself.

headline: Musicals of Various Shapes and Sizes Arrive on London Stages
abstract: “Dear Evan Hansen” is the latest Broadway musical to open in the West End, along with the pop bonanza “& Juliet” and nearby, the quietly powerful “Ghost Quartet.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For proof that theatrical lightning can indeed strike twice, consider the happy case of “Dear Evan Hansen.” The Tony Award-winning Broadway musical has opened in London at the Noël Coward Theater, introducing us to yet another newcomer with genuine talent. This time, the title role is played by 21-year-old Sam Tutty, a recent drama school graduate, who is more than capable of standing shoulder-to-shoulder with the show’s previous leading men.

headline: Should I Break Up With My Boyfriend?
abstract: He says he doesn’t want to think about the future. That’s all I can think about.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend of four years is everything I want in a man — intelligent, kind and adventurous — and I would really like to get married. We’ve discussed it several times. He’s made it clear that he loves me, but is not interested in thinking about the future because the concept of his mortality terrifies him. While I am happy in our daily life, I have made sacrifices to keep us together (two cross-country moves for his career), but he has not shown a similar long-term commitment to me. Should I walk away from a man I love because he can’t commit, or should I stay and enjoy my happiness?

headline: It’s a Terrible Day in the Neighborhood, and That’s O.K.
abstract: Fred Rogers’s belief that we should validate emotions, not suppress them, is wisdom for all ages.
lead_paragraph: On the 51st anniversary of the first taping of the classic children’s show “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood,” Google published an animated “doodle” commemorating him. It depicts Mister Rogers walking through the neighborhood interacting with a variety of people, including a small child with his head hung low. Rogers fashions a paper airplane for the boy, which instantly cheers him up. People commonly caricature Mister Rogers this way — a gentle man intent on making everyone happy — but that may be more a reflection of America’s discomfort with dark emotions than of the man himself. The last thing Fred Rogers would do for a sad boy is distract him from his sadness.

headline: Time Is Running Out for Trump’s North Korean Diplomacy, Analysts Say
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Analysts fear a looming crisis as North Korea warns of a Dec. 31 deadline for a new proposal from the United States on denuclearization.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The clock is ticking.

headline: Roadside Bomb Kills 13 People on Their Way to Afghan Wedding
abstract: Most of the victims were from a single family. “I am dead, I am finished, I am destroyed,” said one of the survivors.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 13 people, most of them members of the same family, were killed this week when their car struck a roadside bomb on the way to a wedding party in northern Afghanistan, officials said.

headline: ‘Temblores’ Review: Torn Between His Faith and His Sexuality
abstract: Jayro Bustamante’s drama is vividly imagined, but lacks depth.
lead_paragraph: “Temblores” begins where other dramas of its ilk might end. On a rainy night in Guatemala City, the suave, wealthy Pablo (Juan Pablo Olyslager), a married father of two, comes home to find that his evangelical family has discovered his relationship with another man. After a histrionic confrontation, Pablo is evicted from the house.

headline: ‘Les Misérables’ Review: Injustice Still Stalks the Poor of Paris
abstract: In modern-day Montfermeil, the setting of Victor Hugo’s novel, the filmmaker Ladj Ly stages his own impassioned cry against oppression.
lead_paragraph: “Les Misérables” opens with a sequence in Paris as pointed as it is exuberant. In dozens of quick cuts, scads of teens and young adults hop metro turnstiles and crowd into bistros, packing alleyways and streets. They’re mostly people of color, and they’re watching their country’s football team win the 2018 World Cup.

headline: ‘My Friend the Polish Girl’ Review: The Outsider
abstract: In this faux documentary, the relationship between an American filmmaker and her troubled immigrant subject takes on a darkly controlling hue.
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers who swing for the fences are inherently more interesting than those who play it safe. And no one can accuse Ewa Banaskiewicz and Mateusz Dymek, the writers and directors of “My Friend the Polish Girl,” of embracing safety in their singular, if somewhat forced attempt to query society’s callous treatment of immigrants.

headline: ‘Melody Makers’ Review: Another Go-Round With the Old-School British Rockers
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: In a new documentary, Leslie Ann Coles explores the history of 1960s and ’70s rock ’n’ roll through the eye of a British music magazine.
lead_paragraph: The story of 1960s and ’70s rock ’n’ roll has been told over and over in books and documentaries, to the extent that it has become, as a non-rock ’n’ roll song puts it, a tale as old as time. In this hardly epochal but largely pleasant documentary directed by Leslie Ann Coles, the tale is told through the eye of Melody Maker, the British music weekly that printed its first issue in 1926.

headline: ‘White Snake’ Review: A Chinese Demon Slithers to the Screen
abstract: Love is the answer, even when Romeo is a snake-catcher. Luckily, he’s not great at his job.
lead_paragraph: “The Legend of the White Snake” is a famous Chinese folk tale that originated in the Ming dynasty. Its newest adaptation, the animation feature “White Snake,” which features a Disney-esque damsel-in-distress treatment, is a prequel, set 500 years before the main story.

headline: ‘Feast of the Epiphany’ Review: Farm to Table, but Not in That Order
abstract: It’s a drama. It’s a documentary. It’s both, but this film is a perplexing amalgamation.
lead_paragraph: Film reviewers are often portrayed as recommending cryptic or difficult movies. In “Feast of the Epiphany,” Michael Koresky, Jeff Reichert and Farihah Zaman have actually made one. All have written as critics, but Reichert and Zaman are primarily filmmakers.

headline: ‘After Parkland’ Review: Gun Violence Reverberates Through Time
abstract: A new documentary follows the friends and families of those died in the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in 2018.
lead_paragraph: About nine hours before I saw “After Parkland,” a student in Santa Clarita, Calif., opened fire at his high school, killing two of his classmates. It was impossible to watch the movie without thinking about those events — or about how a similar documentary might eventually be made there.

headline: When Does the New Decade Begin: This Week, or a Year From Now?
abstract: In recent years there has been debate about when a decade begins and ends. We break it down for you.
lead_paragraph: Oh, to revel in New Year’s Eve. Cheer with good friends! A glass of Champagne or two. And, this year, ringing in a new decade.

headline: ‘Cavale’ Review: Riding in Cars With Girls on the Run
abstract: In Virginie Gourmel’s drama, three teenage girls escape a psychiatric facility, however therapeutically or legally ill-advised.
lead_paragraph: The drama “Cavale” starts out with its hero, Kathy, kicking and screaming. Kathy (Lisa Viance) is being committed to a psychiatric facility for teenage girls in the Belgian countryside. Doctors and orderlies promise stability — using pills and calorie-burning trips to the pool to regulate the wildness of their young charges. But Kathy is not interested in stabilizing.

headline: ‘Ximei’ Review: An AIDS Activist Fights Medical Injustice in China
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Blood Donation', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: In taking the time to get to know his subjects, Andy Cohen paints a compelling portrait of those suffering from a public health crisis.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 300,000 residents of Henan Province in China contracted H.I.V. during a local epidemic that dates to the 1990s, according to the documentary “Ximei.” At that time, officials encouraged peasants to sell their blood for pittances. The virus spread through contaminated equipment and transfusions. Years later, AIDS patients in Henan are still shunned — scorned by their families, denied care by certain hospitals and made to fill out complicated forms for reimbursement (even though many are illiterate).

headline: China Condemns U.S. Over Hong Kong. That Won’t Stop Trade Talks.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Hong Kong Protests (2019)', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Legislation signed by Trump poses a direct challenge to Beijing’s rule, but trade and the softening Chinese economy present bigger problems.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China vented on Thursday after President Trump signed new human rights legislation covering the protest-wracked city of Hong Kong. It denounced the new law as illegal interference in its own affairs. It summoned the American ambassador for the second time in a week. It vowed retaliation.

headline: ‘The Body Remembers’ Review: One Prospers, the Other Doesn’t
abstract: Two indigenous women collide in an urgent, intimate drama about race, motherhood and domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: There’s a crucial scene near the midpoint of the Canadian drama “The Body Remembers When the World Broke Open,” and it brilliantly illuminates the experiential chasm between its two leads. It takes place in a taxicab where Aila (Elle-Maija Tailfeathers, who also wrote and directed the film with Kathleen Hepburn) is accompanying Rosie (Violet Nelson), a woman she has only recently met, to a safe house. Both women are indigenous; but where Aila is willowy and elegantly dressed, Rosie is stocky and awkward, her pregnant body wrapped in mismatched clothing and her hair clotted over the bruises left by her boyfriend’s knuckles.

headline: Review: M. Night Shyamalan’s Thanksgiving Feast of Twists
abstract: “Servant,” on Apple TV Plus, offers his usual tasting menu of surprises, starting with an unusually quiet baby.
lead_paragraph: The list of things you could potentially give thanks for grows by one this Thanksgiving, with the premiere on Thursday of the new sort-of-horror series “Servant” on Apple TV Plus. Turkey, football, family, M. Night Shyamalan. It’s a full day.

headline: Happy Thanksgiving
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Who makes me thankful.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade: Phew! Giant Balloons Fly — Just Not Very High
abstract: At 8:12 a.m., the police department gave the all clear for the big character balloons that have made the event so famous.
lead_paragraph: A forecast of gusting winds threatened to ground the big balloons of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade but they flew as planned on Thursday morning — in a manner of speaking.

headline: The T List: A New Place to Indulge One’s Sweet Tooth, and More
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Art', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Ceramics and Pottery', 'Design']
abstract: What to eat, wear and see this week, from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we’re sharing things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. We hope you’ll join us for the ride. (Sign up here, if you haven’t already, and you can reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.)

headline: Donald Trump Jr., Debut Author, Sees Sales Bolstered by G.O.P. Allies
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Orders from the Republican Party and other conservative groups helped push Mr. Trump’s best-selling book, records show.
lead_paragraph: Boxes began arriving in early November at the Phoenix headquarters of Turning Point USA, a conservative student group with ties to the Trump family.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are in Forest Hills, Queens, Kensington, Brooklyn, and the Beekman neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Forest Hills, Queens, Kensington, Brooklyn, and the Beekman neighborhood.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom in Port Washington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom in Port Washington, N.Y.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Forest Hills, Queens, Kensington, Brooklyn, and the Beekman neighborhood.

abstract: This week’s properties include a three-bedroom in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom in Port Washington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: The Best New York Neighborhoods for Your First Home
abstract: Where you can find homes on the market that are affordable to the typical first-time buyer.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s real estate market is favorable to buyers right now, making this an opportune moment for people who have managed to save enough for a down payment to purchase their first home.

headline: Diablo Cody’s Week: ‘I’m a Phone Addict’
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Theater', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Oscar-winning screenwriter and first-time Broadway librettist shares what she watched, read and listened to in a week.
lead_paragraph: Diablo Cody, the Oscar-winning screenwriter behind “Juno,” “Young Adult” and “Tully,” is a master of the endless hustle. But her latest routine — commuting between Hollywood and Broadway every week — is admittedly gnarly.

headline: Muhammad Ali in a Broadway Musical? It Happened
abstract: Fifty years ago this week, “Buck White” opened, and very quickly closed. What does this footnote to theater history still have to tell us?
lead_paragraph: So, as the sportscaster Howard Cosell used to ask great boxers: What went wrong out there, champ?

headline: O.K., Mayor: Why 37-Year-Old Pete Buttigieg Is Attracting Boomers
abstract: Calling himself the “retirement guy” and pitching a “Gray New Deal,” Mr. Buttigieg has crafted a message that resonates among older white Americans, helping him rocket past other candidates in some polls.
lead_paragraph: DENISON, Iowa — Pete Buttigieg likes a crisp white button-down — no fuss, no flash — and his favorite novel is by a man who died in 1941.

headline: A Star Pianist Brings Soft-Spoken Virtuosity to Scriabin
abstract: Daniil Trifonov begins his artist-in-residence season at the New York Philharmonic with an exciting performance of Scriabin’s youthful concerto.
lead_paragraph: The 24-year-old Alexander Scriabin had completed his studies at the Moscow Conservatory but never written a work for orchestra when in a rush of enthusiasm in 1896, he composed his Piano Concerto in F sharp minor. (He never wrote another.)

headline: Police Commander Not Guilty in Hillsborough Soccer Disaster
abstract: A crowd crush at a 1989 match in England killed 96 people, and officials initially faulted the fans. Investigations later showed poor crowd control was to blame.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A retired British police commander was not guilty of manslaughter, a jury decided on Thursday, 30 years after a crowd crush at a soccer match that killed 96 people, the worst disaster in modern British sports history.

headline: Kevin Talks Turkey
abstract: My brother dishes on Trump, impeachment and the 2020 field.
lead_paragraph: No matter how bad your Thanksgiving is, mine will be worse, and I’ll tell you why. My sister thinks Jim Jordan is hot. Well, she didn’t say “hot” exactly, but the words “admire,” “forceful” and “fighter” have been thrown around. And then there’s Kevin. It has been a crazy year, even by Trump standards. So I asked my brother to tell us, in his annual Thanksgiving column, if he has any regrets.

headline: The Death of the Black Utopia
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'African Burial Ground (NYC)', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Underground Railroad (19th Century)']
abstract: An exhibition on Seneca Village, which was destroyed to build Central Park, pays homage to a forgotten chapter in New York City history.
lead_paragraph: New York City embraced willful amnesia when landscapers working at the western edge of Central Park unearthed two coffins in August of 1871. An engraved plate on a richly appointed rosewood coffin identified the deceased as Margaret McIntay, buried two decades earlier at the age of “sixteen years, three months and fourteen days.” A more modest box found not far away contained the remains of an unidentified black person described in the press as “decomposed beyond recognition.”

headline: At the Heart of a 19th-Century Opera: Modern Gun Culture
abstract: With a new version of Weber’s “Der Freischütz,” Heartbeat Opera has done its latest rethinking of a classic.
lead_paragraph: In a cramped rehearsal room in Manhattan one recent morning, a tenor was pretending to line up with the target at a Texas shooting range. His concentration soon turned to horror, though: The girl he planned to marry had appeared in front of his gun.

headline: After Misty Comes Marie: Breaking Barriers in ‘The Nutcracker’
abstract: This year, for the first time, New York City Ballet’s “Nutcracker” has a black Marie, the young heroine whose life is charged with magic.
lead_paragraph: She may not remember it, but during the first summer of her life Charlotte Nebres canvassed for Barack Obama with her mother, Danielle, who carried her in a sling. She attended political rallies. And on a frigid day in January 2009, she accompanied her parents and older sister to his inauguration.

headline: NATO Offers Trump a Budget Bonbon as Summit Nears
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States and Germany will now pay the same amount into the military alliance’s relatively small central funding pot, its secretary general said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In another gesture to President Trump, NATO announced on Thursday that it had agreed to reduce the United States’ contribution to the alliance’s relatively small central budget, a move aimed at ensuring a calm leaders’ meeting next week in London.

headline: Less Plastic With ‘Bags for Life’? Try Again, Campaign Groups Say
keywords: ['Plastics', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Plastic Bags', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: A surge in sales of thicker reusable plastic bags in British supermarkets is worsening their “plastic footprint,” a report says.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the British government introduced a 5-pence levy on plastic bags four years ago, it encouraged shoppers to help reduce environmental damage by bringing their own reusable “bags for life.”

headline: James Holloway III, 97, Dies; Navy Chief Under Three Presidents
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: A combat veteran of three wars, he led an inquiry that criticized the planning behind a failed 1980 mission to rescue hostages in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Adm. James L. Holloway III, a combat veteran of three wars who served as the chief of naval operations in the 1970s and later headed an investigation that strongly criticized the military’s planning of the failed 1980 mission to free hostages held at the American Embassy in Iran, died on Tuesday in Alexandria, Va. He was 97.

headline: Violence Rises in Iraq’s South Amid Crackdowns on Protests and Press
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: An elite Iraqi security force gunned down more than two dozen mostly unarmed people blocking bridges, in a day of violence that saw at least 35 killed.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi security officers opened fire on protesters in southern Iraq on Thursday, killing at least 35, as the government sought to quell violence that started with an attack on the Iranian Consulate in the city of Najaf, but then spread to other areas in the country’s south.

headline: Love Conquers All in Italy’s Parliament, at Least for One Day
abstract: In a surprise move, an Italian lawmaker proposed to his girlfriend ahead of a discussion in the normally volatile lower house.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The Chamber of Deputies in Italy’s Parliament, the arena where lawmakers berate each other, betray alliances and sometimes brawl, is not where Italians usually go to find affection for their fellow citizens.

headline: In Albania, a Race to Save Lives on Ground That Keeps Shaking
abstract: With time running out to find survivors under the wreckage of a devastating earthquake, crews keep searching, while thousands of people search for shelter.
lead_paragraph: DURRES, Albania — With each piece of rubble pulled off the twisted pile of steel and concrete that used to be a four-story home, Luca Martino and his rescue dog, Foglia, were called into action.

headline: Trump Visits Afghanistan and Says He Reopened Talks With Taliban
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Details were unclear. The declaration came on an unannounced trip as the president seeks to highlight a record of achievement while he campaigns for re-election.
lead_paragraph: BAGRAM AIR FIELD, Afghanistan — President Trump paid an unannounced Thanksgiving visit to American troops in Afghanistan on Thursday and declared that he had reopened peace negotiations with the Taliban less than three months after scuttling talks in hopes of ending 18 years of war.

headline: The World Trade Organization Is Dying. What Should Replace It?
abstract: Two decades after Seattle, it has failed to deliver on its promises.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago this weekend, 50,000 people converged on Seattle to protest the World Trade Organization, which was holding a ministerial-level meeting in the city, and a plan championed by the world’s largest corporations to increase the organization’s authority over even more facets of people’s lives.

headline: Garth C. Reeves, 100, Activist Newspaper Publisher, Is Dead
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Newspapers', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: He advanced the cause of civil rights through the venerable Miami Times, the city’s most influential black newspaper, which his father founded in 1923.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Garth C. Reeves, the publisher emeritus of The Miami Times, the city’s most influential black newspaper, which he used to advance the cause of civil rights, died on Monday in Aventura, Fla. He was 100.

headline: 3 Choice Museums and a Treat for Kids, No Subway Trips in Between
abstract: These midsize institutions, all in Midtown, are close enough for a single afternoon’s tour (and with enough time in there for a bite).
lead_paragraph: You’ve shot your selfies in Rockefeller Center, you’ve combed the sale racks at Bloomingdale’s — and now you’re ready to discover the museums of New York like a proper local. Join me! I’ve got a plan to introduce you to three midsize institutions and one little diversion, all close enough for a single afternoon’s tour (and with enough time in there for a bite). We’ll be walking from 36th to 47th Streets, on the eastern stretches of Midtown Manhattan; this guide proceeds south to north, but it works just as well in the other direction. Check opening times before you go; Monday is a day off for most of these destinations, and hours can change around the holidays.

headline: Flames Coach Bill Peters Resigns After Being Accused of Using Racial Slur
abstract: Akim Aliu said Peters “dropped the N bomb” against him a decade ago while Aliu was playing in the minor leagues. Peters apologized in a letter to the team manager on Wednesday. He resigned on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Bill Peters resigned as the coach of the Calgary Flames, a National Hockey League team based in Alberta, on Friday, just days after he was accused of using a racial slur against a player a decade ago.

headline: The Wisdom Your Body Knows
abstract: You are not just thinking with your brain.
lead_paragraph: This has been a golden age for brain research. We now have amazing brain scans that show which networks in the brain ramp up during different activities. But this emphasis on the brain has subtly fed the illusion that thinking happens only from the neck up. It’s fed the illusion that the advanced parts of our thinking are the “rational” parts up top that try to control the more “primitive” parts down below.

headline: Holiday Museum Guide: Where to See Art This Season
abstract: We’ll not only help you figure out what exhibitions to visit, but also offer some tips before you head out.
lead_paragraph: This season can make even the grouchiest New Yorker an urban romantic, and encourages local residents and visitors alike to rediscover the museums and monuments we sometimes take for granted. Prepare for good cheer, special programming — and big crowds.

headline: 3 Film Series to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to film series and special screenings happening this weekend and in the week ahead. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: 6 Dance Performances to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 9 Plays and Musicals to Go to in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

headline: 20 Art Exhibitions to View in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

headline: 9 Things to Do With Your Kids in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 12 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: 5 Classical Music Concerts to See in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: Where to Eat and Drink at 14 N.Y.C. Museums Right Now
abstract: Dine while overlooking Central Park, sip mezcal in East Harlem or get a taste of Pierre Cardin’s Parisian bistro in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Museums, like department stores and airports, are now counting food among their attractions. They recognize that after a few hours of John Singer Sargent or Betye Saar visitors might have an appetite for a plate of pasta or a juicy burger instead of basic coffee-shop fare. The following museum restaurants would be worth a meal even if not surrounded by masterpieces. Most of them can be visited independently of the museums.

headline: Why Trump Should Hate Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After all, it celebrates the better angels of our nature.
lead_paragraph: So the imaginary “war on Christmas” wasn’t enough. Donald Trump and Fox News are now accusing progressives of waging a war on Thanksgiving, too, based on, well, nothing. But do Trump and his band of bigots even understand what Thanksgiving is about? If they did, they would hate this most American of holidays.

headline: 5 Comedy Shows to Catch in N.Y.C. This Weekend
abstract: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 2, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Students

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: The holiday weekend brings a Danish medical drama for fans of “Call the Midwife,” along with a chilly British thriller.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every week for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Center-Right Candidate Wins in Uruguay, Ending 15 Years of Liberal Rule
abstract: Luis Lacalle Pou, the son of a former president, will take office after his rival conceded defeat, four days after a close and contentious runoff election.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidate of the center-left coalition that has governed Uruguay for 15 years conceded defeat on Thursday, four days after a close and contentious runoff election, as the nation joined others in the region in shifting rightward.

headline: Explosions Shake a Texas Town, and Its View on Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Explosions (Accidental)', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Chemicals', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Two explosions forced tens of thousands of people to leave the area around a chemical plant. “As long as we know that we’re O.K., that’s all that really matters,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: PORT NECHES, Texas — It was a Thanksgiving of pies abandoned at homes that had been left in a hurry, turkey eaten in hotel rooms, and naps on cots handed out by Red Cross volunteers.

headline: Robert F.X. Sillerman Dies at 71; Built Entertainment Empires
abstract: A brash figure in the financial pages, he bought and sold lucrative radio and concert businesses and controlled the Elvis Presley estate.
lead_paragraph: Robert F.X. Sillerman, an investor and media executive who built and sold radio empires, controlled the Elvis Presley estate and consolidated the American concert industry, died on Sunday. He was 71.

headline: Marion McClinton, Interpreter of August Wilson, Dies at 65
abstract: He directed numerous productions of Wilson plays, including two on Broadway, but some of his best work was done in regional theaters.
lead_paragraph: Marion McClinton, a noted director who was a favorite of the playwright August Wilson and took two of his plays to Broadway, earning a 2001 Tony Award nomination for best direction for the first, “King Hedley II,” died on Thursday in St. Paul, Minn. He was 65.

headline: Ice Sculpture Steals Show at U.K. Climate Debate That Boris Johnson Skips
abstract: A melting block of sculpted ice stood in for a missing prime minister at a televised debate, infuriating Conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Five leaders of British political parties called for dramatic action to confront climate change in a televised debate on Thursday, just two weeks before the country’s general election.

headline: 7 Killed in Plane Crash in Ontario
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The authorities in Canada said they were still investigating what caused the plane to crash on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Seven people were killed when a small plane crashed north of Kingston, Ontario, on Wednesday evening, the authorities in Canada said Thursday.

headline: Fantasy Concoction
abstract: Sam Buchbinder stumps the “expert.”
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I hope you all had a lovely and restful Thanksgiving, cooking notwithstanding. Wordplay wishes you a peaceful holiday season, no matter how you celebrate.

headline: Suddenly, the Chinese Threat to Australia Seems Very Real
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations']
abstract: After a businessman said Chinese agents sought to implant him in Parliament, that revelation and other espionage cases have finally signaled the end of a “let’s get rich together” era.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — A Chinese defector to Australia who detailed political interference by Beijing. A businessman found dead after telling the authorities about a Chinese plot to install him in Parliament. Suspicious men following critics of Beijing in major Australian cities.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 29, 2019
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, November 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, November 29, 2019.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Bringing Hollywood Glamour to Real Estate
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 29, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “Focusing too much on story takes away from the home. I’m not Quentin Tarantino.”

headline: Yasuhiro Nakasone, Assertive Prime Minister of Japan, Dies at 101
abstract: He called for a stronger military and a larger global role for Japan and was one of the few Japanese leaders to win recognition on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: Yasuhiro Nakasone, the former prime minister of Japan who entered politics during the post-World War II American occupation of his country and spent the rest of his career championing the re-emergence of a more assertive and independent nation, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 101.

headline: A Simple Question That’s Too Hard to Answer
abstract: The loss of a loved one can complicate family math.
lead_paragraph: When my son was in third grade, I went to his school for a pre-Thanksgiving Day concert. I found a folding chair next to a fellow parent, a father with an easy laugh. We made small talk, looked over and around the heads in front of us to find our boys, shy and awkward, onstage. Eventually I asked, “Do you have others, or is he an only child?”

headline: Espionage and Interference? Australia Grapples With Its China Relationship
abstract: This talk of Australia this week was China, after revelations that a businessman said Chinese agents sought to implant him in Parliament and other espionage allegations raised questions about foreign interference.

headline: Families of Hillsborough Victims Are Again Left Without Answers
abstract: A not-guilty ruling related to the 1989 disaster presented a difficult reality: The 96 who died were unlawfully killed, but nobody, most likely, will ever be held responsible.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — It has been more than 30 years, now, since 96 Liverpool fans went to a soccer game and did not come home. For 30 years, their families have struggled not only to deal with the pain and anguish of loss, but to find out why their parents, their siblings, their children died that day; how the Hillsborough disaster was allowed to happen at all.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Atlantics’ and ‘The Report’
abstract: A Cannes prize winner hits Netflix. And a political drama with Adam Driver and Annette Bening comes to Amazon.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTICS (2019) Stream on Netflix. This debut feature from the French-Senegalese director Mati Diop won one of the top prizes at this year’s Cannes Film Festival. Set in Dakar, the film centers on Ada (Mama Sané), a young woman with a problem: She’s in love with Souleiman (Ibrahima Traoré), a construction worker, but she’s engaged to a businessman. The plot kicks off when Souleiman unexpectedly sets off on a boat bound for Spain. “It’s around this point that ‘Atlantics’ transforms itself, almost imperceptibly, into something entirely different from what it had seemed to be,” A.O. Scott wrote in his review for The New York Times. “Without letting go of its grounding in the lives and desires of its characters, especially Ada, it becomes an unusual kind of ghost story, more unnerving than terrifying, a supernatural fable of resistance and revenge.”

headline: Hong Kong Police End 2-Week Campus Siege
abstract: The police found no protesters during a final search of Polytechnic University, the site of some of the most violent clashes the city has seen this year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police returned control of Hong Kong Polytechnic University’s campus to school officials on Friday, bringing to an end one of the most intense periods of conflict since protests began to engulf the city earlier this year.

headline: Art Basel Miami, Where Big Money Meets Bigger Money
abstract: The art world’s tribes converge in Miami Beach for the country’s most important art fair. Here’s your guide to the cultural fray.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — As the global art world descends on South Florida for next week’s Art Basel fair, which is celebrating its 17th anniversary, it’s worth remembering how truly small the art world once was.

headline: Meet the Man Loosening Bank Regulation, One Detail at a Time
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some say Randal Quarles is giving big banks a gift, little by little. Others call it needed fine-tuning. He pledges allegiance to efficiency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first 21 months on the job, Randal K. Quarles, the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman for supervision and regulation, met at least 22 times with partners at his former law firm, Davis Polk & Wardwell, which represents many of the nation’s largest banks.

headline: The 72-Hour War Over Christmas
abstract: The mayor of Charleston, W.Va., wanted her city to be more welcoming to all faiths and people, so she changed an annual celebration to the ‘Winter Parade.’ It didn’t last long.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The first shot was fired in the middle of the afternoon in early October, back when the Appalachian leaves had barely turned orange and store shelves were lined with Halloween candy.

headline: News Quiz: Richard Spencer, Uber, Thanksgiving
abstract: Did you stay up-to-date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up-to-date this week?

keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Stroke', 'Diabetes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Heart', 'E Coli (Bacteria)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Exercise', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Food', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Here’s What’s Happening in the American Teenage Bedroom
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'your-feed-selfcare', 'your-feed-internet-culture']
abstract: Rowan Winch is 15. He’s a businessman.
lead_paragraph: For years, Rowan Winch was nothing if not online. Each day his alarm went off at 6 a.m. and he would roll over in his twin bed, grab his iPhone and start looking for memes — viral images and videos — to share on Instagram. He’d repost a handful to his suite of popular accounts before getting into the shower. Afterward, he would keep searching, and posting, until it was time to board the bus for school.

headline: Not Lost in Translation: Provocative Foreign Fiction
abstract: Writers cast light on other countries’ shadows: from a sinister factory in Japan to a secret-filled Yugoslav town to a prisonlike kitchen in the south of India.
lead_paragraph: THE FACTORYBy Hiroko OyamadaTranslated by David Boyd 116 pp. New Directions. Paper, $13.95.

headline: Plating Memory
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Miscarriages', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: When I moved from country to country, I kept friends and relatives close through recipes, each morsel an ode to remembrance.
lead_paragraph: I grew up an immigrant child, spending my formative years in three countries, England, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. In a time before keeping in touch was an internet call away, I’d have to say goodbye forever to bedrooms, to classrooms, to friends. I learned to rely for continuity on two constant companions: books and food.

headline: Helping Artists Find Studio Space
abstract: Some of the organizations and programs that connect artists with places where they can work.
lead_paragraph: Though market-rate studio space is increasingly out of the reach of many artists, a number of programs and organizations in the city offer affordable work spaces on both a short and long-term basis.

headline: She Sang. So Did His Heart.
abstract: John Schreiber realized Virginia McEnerney was special after she began singing an obscure cabaret song during a long car ride. He knew every word.
lead_paragraph: The first time Virginia McEnerney met John Schreiber she was unaware of what she calls his “big man on campus” reputation in arts circles. In fact, she admitted to him something she now finds embarrassing: She thought NJPAC — short for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, where Mr. Schreiber is president and chief executive — was a political action committee.

headline: Money-Saving Secrets From Ski Bums
abstract: To get nitty-gritty, budget-saving tips, we turned to ski-town locals and winter fanatics for advice.
lead_paragraph: Downhill skiing is rarely cheap. The booking site Hipmunk found the median price for two people over two nights in a popular ski town like Vail, Colo., or Park City, Utah, with round-trip economy flights, runs about $1,700 to $2,200.

headline: ‘Brown Water for Brown People’: Making Sense of California’s Drinking Water Crisis
abstract: In the wealthiest state in the wealthiest country on earth, hundreds of thousands don’t have access to potable water. I wanted to know why.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: The Hunt for Jeffrey Epstein’s Hidden Files
abstract: A mysterious man told us he had surveillance footage from Jeffrey Epstein’s properties. Then his story took a turn.
lead_paragraph: When a big bear of a man in flip-flops showed up with a bottle of Japanese whiskey promising to deliver evidence implicating some of the world’s richest and most powerful men in an epic cover-up of sexual misconduct, our reporters were hooked.

headline: German Catholic Church Debates Sexuality, Celibacy and Women’s Roles
abstract: With the German church’s global influence, a meeting of bishops and laypeople to take up hot-button topics has led to warnings of a new schism, originating in the home of the Protestant Reformation.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Roman Catholic Church in Germany has a split identity. At home, attendance is falling and many Germans say they regard the church’s teaching on social issues as hopelessly out of touch.

headline: The Very (Very) Slow Rise of Lesbianism on TV
keywords: ['Television', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Women and Girls', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Early efforts to introduce thoughtful story lines about women who love women gave way to gimmicks in the 1990s, before returning with force this century.
lead_paragraph: Picture it: American living rooms, 1986. A TV juggernaut with a devoted weekly audience of 15-20 million viewers introduces a lesbian story line, and it is both hilarious and eye-opening — and not so much a “very special episode” as just a great episode.

headline: How Michelle Buteau, Actress and Comedian, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Home alone with infant twins, it’s all a blur. But at night, the husband comes home. He’s cooking.
lead_paragraph: This year Michelle Buteau had a breakout role in the Netflix movie “Always Be My Maybe” and starred in the BET Plus television series, “The First Wives Club,” among other projects. She is also a co-host of the WNYC podcast “Adulting.”

headline: Warming Waters, Moving Fish: How Climate Change Is Reshaping Iceland
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Cod (Fish)']
abstract: Ocean temperatures are on the rise and warming waters are causing fish to swim for their lives, causing financial disruption and international conflicts.
lead_paragraph: ISAFJORDUR, Iceland — Before it became a “Game of Thrones” location, before Justin Bieber stalked the trails of Fjadrargljufur, and before hordes of tourists descended upon this small island nation, there were the fish.

headline: Stumped for Gift Ideas? Ask Us
abstract: Tell us about the trickiest person on your holiday gift list and we’ll try to help.
lead_paragraph: The holiday shopping season is now upon us, with all its associated festivities and gatherings — as well as the sometimes overwhelming task of finding the perfect gift for everyone on your list. Our gift guide, and its 400-plus recommendations, is a good place to start. But if you’re still stumped, we’re here to help. Submit your questions below by Dec. 6.

keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Textbooks', 'Research', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Poverty', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Discrimination', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: The winners of this year’s Nobel in economics did pioneering field experiments that sometimes didn’t work as expected.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Kremer looked at the data for a study underway in Kenya in the 1990s, he was taken aback.

headline: A Change in Medicare Has Therapists Alarmed
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Elderly', 'Nursing Homes', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Elder Care', 'Physical Therapy', 'Home Health Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'your-feed-health']
abstract: Medicare revamped its reimbursement policy for physical, occupational and speech therapy in nursing homes. That has left some patients with less help.
lead_paragraph: In late September, a woman in her 70s arrived at a skilled nursing facility in suburban Houston after several weeks in the hospital. Her leg had been amputated after a long-ago knee replacement became infected; she also suffered from diabetes, depression, anxiety and general muscular weakness.

headline: He’s a Young Black Magician. People Ask: ‘Are You the New Houdini?’
abstract: From Wisconsin to New York, RJ the Magician has followed the showman’s path. He now directs the Houdini Museum of New York.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Rajon Lynch, 23, was teaching magic in Shanghai when he got an email from the Houdini Museum of New York.

headline: Real Estate Thought It Was Invincible in New York. It Wasn’t.
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Politics and Government', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: How the industry that ruled the city plans to rebound after a rough year.
lead_paragraph: This was the year that New York bit back against big real estate.

headline: New Jersey Grapples With Far-Right Extremism After Arrests
abstract: “The concern is those acts of hate are the embers and then they begin to get radicalized,” an official said.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, N.J. — New Jersey investigators were looking into a routine complaint from a woman who said her ex-boyfriend was harassing her, when they uncovered something far more dire: The 25-year-old man had stockpiled weapons and far-right propaganda and had talked about shooting up a hospital.

headline: Black Friday 2019: What You Need to Know
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Whether you’re hitting the stores or buying online from your couch, we’re here to see you through all the doorbuster deals and Black Friday blowouts.
lead_paragraph: In the age of e-commerce, Black Friday can feel like an anachronism. But don’t be fooled. The Friday after Thanksgiving remains enormously important — at least symbolically — to the retail industry. Millions of shoppers headed out to stores on Friday, working off that turkey and stuffing by racing to find the best deals.

headline: Warren Wealth Tax Has Wide Support, Except Among One Group
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Taxation', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Most college-educated Republican men oppose the plan, which otherwise finds wide backing. On Medicare for all, divisions are more starkly partisan.
lead_paragraph: Senator Elizabeth Warren’s plan to tax the assets of America’s wealthiest individuals continues to draw broad support from voters, across party, gender and educational lines. Only one slice of the electorate opposes it staunchly: Republican men with college degrees.

headline: Artist’s Studio: How About the Living Room?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Art', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: As rents for studios and lofts rise, many young artists find themselves working from home and adjusting their art to fit into smaller spaces.
lead_paragraph: Erin Lorek is an artist whose practice involves casting sheets of glass using large iron plates, work that would ideally be done in a concrete-floored, industrial warehouse with a freight elevator, rather than the living room of a shared, three-bedroom apartment in a Bedford-Stuyvesant brownstone.

headline: How Racism Ripples Through Rural California’s Pipes
keywords: ['Water', 'Shortages', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Income Inequality', 'Politics and Government', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: In the 20th century, California’s black farmworkers settled in waterless colonies. The history endures underground, through old pipes, dry wells and shoddy septic tanks.
lead_paragraph: TEVISTON, Calif. — Bertha Mae Beavers remembers hearing stories as a child about the promises of California, a place so rich with jobs and opportunity that money, she was told, “grew on trees.” So in the summer of 1946 she said goodbye to her family of sharecroppers in Oklahoma and set out for a piece of it.

headline: The Men’s Wear Designer Keeping a Heritage Brand Cool
abstract: Berluti’s Kris Van Assche shares the art — and fries shop — that inspires him the most.
lead_paragraph: Kris Van Assche, the artistic director of Berluti, grew up an only child in Belgium’s Flemish-speaking region of Londerzeel, between Antwerp and Brussels. “Nobody I knew was interested in art or fashion, so there was no predestination,” says the designer, 43. He credits his paternal grandmother with sparking his love of beauty, saying, “She always set a lovely table and she made all her own clothes — and mine.” After graduating from the Royal Academy of Fine Arts Antwerp, where he studied women’s wear, in 1998, Van Assche was offered an internship designing men’s wear for Yves Saint Laurent; unsure if he wanted to live in Paris, he decided it would be a good placeholder until he found other work in London, Milan or New York. But then he met Hedi Slimane, at the time the brand’s creative director of men’s wear, whom he followed to Dior Homme in 2000. Four years later, Van Assche started his own label — conceptual suiting with a sportswear bent — only to return to Dior in 2007 to replace Slimane in the top job.

headline: Looking for Frederick Douglass in Savannah
abstract: Savannah, Ga., is a pilgrimage destination for those interested in the abolitionist’s life, with artists interpreting his legacy in riveting shows and a film.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Frederick Douglass passed through this elegant Southern city only once, for the briefest of visits — a half-hour whistle-stop on his rail journey to a speaking engagement in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: How Kamala Harris’s Campaign Unraveled
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Harris is the only 2020 Democrat who has fallen hard out of the top tier of candidates. She has proved to be an uneven campaigner who changes her message and tactics to little effect and has a staff torn into factions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early November, a few days after Senator Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign announced widespread layoffs and an intensified focus on Iowa, her senior aides gathered for a staff meeting at their Baltimore headquarters and pelted the campaign manager, Juan Rodriguez, with questions.

headline: They Keep Times Square in Order, and a Statue Front and Center
abstract: Several Times Square security officers have been doing double duty as “public art ambassadors” for a Kehinde Wiley monument, which ends its New York visit this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Damon Dorsey was 23 and searching for a job when he stumbled upon an opening in Times Square’s security department.

headline: ‘The L Word’ Is Back With Sex, Glamour and a Wider Lens
keywords: ['Television', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Women and Girls', 'Dating and Relationships', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: A decade after the pioneering original ended, “The L Word: Generation Q” includes a group of new young cast members from across the L.G.B.T.Q. spectrum. Can the series still break ground in 2019?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Why aren’t there any lesbian bars in L.A.?” the actress Jennifer Beals asked recently, perched in the center of a tufted sofa in her office. It was a good question — the kind her passionate, Ivy-educated character Bette on “The L Word” might ask, half in despair, half in hopes of rousing debate.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Leonard Lauder and Tony Bennett on the Gala Circuit
abstract: Benefits were held for the Child Mind Institute, Lincoln Center Corporate Fund and Central Park Conservancy.
lead_paragraph: Benefits were held for the Child Mind Institute, Lincoln Center Corporate Fund and Central Park Conservancy.

lead_paragraph: The Child Mind Institute held a benefit dinner on Nov. 19 at Cipriani 42nd Street. The Lincoln Center Corporate Fund honored Leonard Lauder at its fashion gala on Nov. 18 at Alice Tully Hall. And the Central Park Conservancy held a winter party at Rumsey Playfield on Nov. 20.

headline: Donald Trump, Meet Your Precursor
keywords: ['Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Andrew Johnson pioneered the recalcitrant racism and impeachment-worthy subterfuge the president is fond of.
lead_paragraph: Last week, in defense of her father, Ivanka Trump tweeted out a quotation she wrongly attributed to Alexis de Tocqueville: “A decline of public morals in the United States will probably be marked by the abuse of the power of impeachment as a means of crushing political adversaries or ejecting them from office.”

headline: Le Bernardin Keeps Top Spot on La Liste
abstract: The chef Eric Ripert’s seafood restaurant shares the best restaurant honors with Guy Savoy in Paris on this French ranking.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, La Liste, a global restaurant-ranking system from France, has named Le Bernardin the best restaurant in the world. And like last year, it shares the honor with Restaurant Guy Savoy.

headline: In Defense of ‘Woke’
abstract: Donald Trump and his supporters want the rest of us to stay asleep.
lead_paragraph: It was quaint, really. That feeling I had in the months after the 2016 presidential election, where I convinced myself I’d do everything possible in the next four years to prevent Donald Trump from becoming normalized.

headline: Britain’s Dirty Election
abstract: A serial liar. A campaign of online disinformation. The risk of foreign meddling. Sound familiar?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Pity British voters.

headline: Beloved Berlin Currywurst Stand Delivers a Bite of History
abstract: For 43 years, Waltraud Ziervogel has presided over Konnopke’s, the iconic sausage business that her father started in 1930 in what became East Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The night the Berlin Wall fell, 30 years ago this month, Waltraud Ziervogel’s husband, Kurt, came home with the news and urged his wife to join him in the joyous celebrations and a stroll through West Berlin, suddenly accessible to them for the first time in nearly three decades.

headline: Two K-Pop Stars Sentenced to Prison for Rape
abstract: The two men raped women who were too drunk to resist, and one of them shared videos of the assaults, a court found.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Two K-pop stars were sentenced to prison on Friday for raping women who were too drunk to consent to sex, and one of the men was also convicted of making videos of the assaults and sharing them with friends online.

headline: Can the S.E.C. Force Repayment of Ill-Gotten Gains?
abstract: The regulator will argue before the Supreme Court that judges can order a defendant to disgorge money obtained by fraud or insider trading.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission will be in front of the Supreme Court again to argue whether a federal court has the power to order a defendant to repay money obtained by fraud or insider trading.

headline: Brad Gobright, Renowned Rock Climber, Is Dead After Fall in Mexico
abstract: The American free solo climber, one of the world’s best, fell nearly 1,000 feet on Wednesday while using a rope. He was 31.
lead_paragraph: Brad Gobright, an acclaimed American free solo climber, has died after falling nearly 1,000 feet while rappelling a well-known route in Mexico with a rope, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Queen & Slim’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Melina Matsoukas narrates a sequence from her film featuring Jodie Turner-Smith and Daniel Kaluuya.
lead_paragraph: Melina Matsoukas narrates a sequence from her film featuring Jodie Turner-Smith and Daniel Kaluuya.

headline: Black Is Still the Only Color for Pierre Soulages
abstract: An exhibition at the Louvre will celebrate the French painter’s 100th birthday. The only other artists given shows there during their lifetimes were Picasso and Chagall.
lead_paragraph: SETE, France — To get to work, the French artist Pierre Soulages must navigate about a dozen steps, from his house overlooking the Mediterranean to his studio downstairs, just above a sparkling blue pool. At age nearly 100, he is finding this a little difficult lately.

headline: How Love Begins in ‘Queen & Slim’
abstract: The director Melina Matsoukas narrates a lyrical scene from her film where the lead characters fall for each other for the first time.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: How to Follow Up ‘Frozen’? With Melancholy and a Power Ballad
abstract: For the music of “Frozen 2,” Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez found inspiration in a Latin hymn, grief and Bryan Adams.
lead_paragraph: There’s a story that the married duo behind the catchy numbers from the movie musical “Frozen” tell about being disparaged. It goes like this:

headline: Iraq Prime Minister Says He Will Resign Amid Protests
abstract: The announcement comes after demonstrators set fire to the Iranian Consulate and hundreds died in antigovernment unrest.
